a rented room used for both living and sleeping in
Sense.TRAN: 〔租用的〕起居室兼卧室的两用房间

Sense.DEF: a sore place on your skin caused by lying in bed for a long time
an attractive cover for a bed that goes on top of all the other covers
the wooden or metal frame of a bed
the time when you usually go to bed
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s way past your bedtime!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你早该上床睡觉了！
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bedtime story
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 睡前故事

Sense.DEF:
another word for a
Bedouin

the problem that some children have of passing
urine
liquid from the body
while they are asleep

a black and yellow flying insect that makes
honey
and can sting you
Sense.EXAMPLE: a swarm of bees
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一群蜜蜂
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bee sting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蜜蜂蜇伤

Sense.LEXUNIT: have a bee in your bonnet (about sth)
Sense.DEF: to think something is so important, so necessary etc that you keep mentioning it or thinking about it
Sense.TRAN: 一心想着（某事）﹐念念不忘（某事）
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dad’s got a bee in his bonnet about saving electricity.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸一心想着要省电。

Sense.DEF: an occasion when people, usually women, meet in order to do a particular type of work
Sense.TRAN: 〔妇女聚在一起的〕缝纫会/缝被会等

Sense.DEF: someone who enjoys being busy or active
to be very good
Sense.EXAMPLE: She thought the party was just the bee’s knees.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她觉得这次聚会棒极了。

Sense.DEF: the BBC

a large tree with smooth grey
bark
outer covering
, or the wood from this tree
the meat from a cow
Sense.EXAMPLE: roast beef
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤牛肉
Sense.EXAMPLE: We have both dairy and beef cattle on the farm.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们农场里奶牛和菜牛都有。

Sense.DEF: a complaint
Sense.EXAMPLE: OK, so what’s the beef this time?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好了﹐这一次又有什么苦要诉？

Sense.DEF: used when you think someone’s promises sound good, but you want to know what they actually plan to do
to complain a lot

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They’re always beefing about something.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们总是有这样那样的不满。

Sense.DEF: to improve something or make it more interesting, more important etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: a beefed-up news story
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个内容充实的新闻报道
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need to beef the campaign up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的宣传活动要加把劲儿。

Sense.DEF:
a
hamburger
strong attractive men with large muscles
Sense.TRAN: 肌肉发达的男子﹐健美男子

Sense.DEF: a traditional guard at the Tower of London

a hot drink made from
beef
that used to be given to people when they were ill
Sense.TRAN: 〔过去给病人吃的〕牛肉汤﹐牛肉汁

Sense.DEF: someone who is beefy is big, strong, and often quite fat

a structure where
bee s
are kept for producing
honey
a way of arranging a woman’s hair in a high pile on the top of her head, that was popular in the 1960s
Sense.TRAN: 〔20世纪60年代流行的〕蜂窝式发型

Sense.DEF:
someone who owns or takes care of
bee s
to go quickly and directly towards someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rob always makes a beeline for beautiful women.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗布总是直奔漂亮的女人。

Sense.DEF:
the past participle of
be

Subsense.DEF: used to say that someone has gone to a place and come back

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ve never been to Japan.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从未去过日本。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Have you been to see the Van Gogh exhibition yet?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你去看过凡•高画展了吗？

Subsense.DEF: used to say that someone has come to a place and left again
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The postman hasn’t been yet.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 邮差还没有来过。

Sense.LEXUNIT: been there, seen that, done that
Sense.DEF: used to say that you are no longer interested in doing something, because you already have a lot of experience of it
Sense.TRAN: 已经司空见惯﹐已经太熟悉了〔表示已对某事失去兴趣〕

F2NBox.HEADING: GRAMMAR 语法:been in, been to, gone to, went to
F2NBox.EXPL: Use have been in to talk about living or staying in a place
F2NBox.TRAN: 表示在某地居住或逗留﹐用have been in
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: How long have you been in London?
F2NBox.EXPL: Use have been to to talk about having visited a place and come back again
F2NBox.TRAN: 表示去过某地之后又回来了﹐用have been to
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: She’s been to the hospital for a check-up.
F2NBox.EXPL: Use have gone to to talk about having travelled to a place and not come back
F2NBox.TRAN: 表示去了某地尚未回来﹐用 have gone to
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: He had gone to Australia not long before.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 他不久前去了澳大利亚。
F2NBox.EXPL: Use went to to talk about a specific trip that someone made in the past
F2NBox.TRAN: 表示某人过去的某次出行﹐用went to
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Last May I went to a conference in Montreal.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年五月份我去蒙特利尔参加了一个会议。

Sense.DEF: if a machine beeps, it makes a short high sound
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why does the computer keep beeping?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为什么电脑不断哔哔响？

Sense.DEF: if a car horn beeps, or if you beep your car horn, it makes a loud noise

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Leave your message after the beep.

Sense.DEF: a small machine that you carry with you that makes short high electronic sounds to tell you that you must telephone someone

an alcoholic drink made from
malt
and
hop s
Sense.EXAMPLE: a pint of beer
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一品脱啤酒
Sense.EXAMPLE:
We sell draught beer
beer served from a large container, not a bottle
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们出售散装啤酒。

Sense.DEF: a glass, bottle, or can of beer
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you fancy a beer?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你想来瓶啤酒吗？

RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那带有啤酒味的口气

Sense.DEF: an unattractive fat stomach caused by drinking too much beer
if someone is beered up, they have drunk a lot of beer

a small piece of
cardboard
that you put under a glass, especially in a bar
a little extra money to buy a drink or have fun with
Sense.EXAMPLE: The job was never going to make me rich, but it kept me in beer money for a while.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 干这活儿是发不了财的﹐不过暂时也能让我弄点小钱花花。

Sense.DEF:
a substance produced by
bee s
, used especially for making furniture
polish
and
candle s
Sense.TRAN: 蜂蜡〔尤用于制造家具上光油和蜡烛〕

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone that what they have asked you is private or personal
a vegetable that sugar is made from
a plant with a round dark red root that you cook and eat as a vegetable
having a red face, especially because you are embarrassed
an insect with a round hard back that is usually black
to go somewhere quickly and leaning forward
Sense.EXAMPLE: He went beetling off down the corridor.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他从走廊急匆匆地走掉了。

Sense.DEF: a plant with a round dark red root that you cook and eat as a vegetable
to become red in the face, especially because you are embarrassed
if something unpleasant or dangerous befalls you, it happens to you
Sense.TRAN: 〔不幸或危险〕降临到﹐发生在〔某人身上〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We prayed that no harm should befall them.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们祈求他们平安无事。

Sense.DEF: to be proper or suitable for someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: As befits a castle of such national importance, there are many stories connected with its history.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是一个对国家而言如此重要的古堡﹐理所当然流传着许许多多和它有关的历史故事。

Sense.DEF: earlier than a particular event or action
Sense.EXAMPLE: Say goodbye before you go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你走之前要告别。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I saw her a few days before she died.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她去世的前几天我见过她。

Sense.DEF: so that something does not or cannot happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: Put that money somewhere safe before it gets stolen.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把那些钱放在安全的地方﹐以防被窃。
Sense.EXAMPLE: That dog ought to be destroyed before it attacks any more children.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那条狗应该宰掉﹐免得它伤害更多的孩子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Before I could say anything more, Holmes had rushed off towards the station.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没等我把话说完﹐福尔摩斯已经急匆匆离去﹐直奔车站了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something happens after a period of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was several minutes before we realised what was happening.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 几分钟以后我们才明白发生了什么事情。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It will be a while before we know the results.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们要过一会儿才能知道结果。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something must happen in order for something else to be possible
Sense.TRAN: 在…之前〔必须做某事〕﹐…之后才能
Sense.EXAMPLE: You have to pass a test before you can get a licence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你得通过考试才能拿到执照。

Sense.DEF: used to warn someone that something bad will happen to them if they do not do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get out before I call the police!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 滚出去﹐要不然我叫警察了！

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that someone does not want to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: She would die before she would admit she was wrong.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她死也不肯承认自己有错。

F2NBox.HEADING: GRAMMAR 语法
F2NBox.EXPL: In a clause beginning with before that refers to the future, use the present tense or present perfect, not 'will'
F2NBox.TRAN: 在以before开头的表示将来的分句中﹐要用现在式或现在完成式﹐而不用will
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: I want to get home before it rains (NOT before it will rain).

Sense.DEF: earlier than something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The new road should be completed before the end of the year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条新公路应该在年底前完工。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s meet at our house before the show.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看演出前在我们家碰头吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Larry arrived home before me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 拉里在我之前到家。

GramExa.PROPFORM: five minutes/two hours etc before sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Hugh arrived just five minutes before the ceremony.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 修在仪式开始前五分钟才到。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I usually take a shower before having my breakfast.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我通常先洗个澡再吃早餐。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
We only got back from Scotland the day before yesterday
two days ago
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们前天才从苏格兰回来。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Other students joined in the protest, and before long
soon
there was a crowd of 200 or so.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 其他学生也加入了抗议队伍﹐不久就有200人左右了。

Sense.DEF: ahead of someone or something else in a list or order
Sense.TRAN: 〔名单或次序上〕较…为先﹐在…之前
Sense.EXAMPLE: You were before me in the queue.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你排在我前面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The files are in alphabetical order, so B1 comes before C1.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 文件是按字母顺序摆放的﹐所以B1在C1之前。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something happens where it can be watched by people
Sense.EXAMPLE: Italy will face Brazil this afternoon before a crowd of 100,000 spectators.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天下午意大利队将在10万名观众面前迎战巴西队。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an actor who had performed before the Queen
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 曾在女王面前献演的一名演员

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone or something comes to be judged or considered by a person or group of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: The proposal was put before the planning committee.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 提议已交计划委员会审议。

Sense.DEF: used to say that one thing or person is considered more important than another
Sense.EXAMPLE: I put my wife and kids before anyone else.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把妻子和孩子看得比任何人都重要。
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the air transport business, safety must always come before profit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在航空业中﹐安全必须始终放在盈利之前。

Sense.DEF: in front of something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The priest stood before the altar.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 牧师站在圣坛前面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sea stretched out before them.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们面前是一望无际的大海。

Sense.DEF: if one place is before another place on a road or journey, the first place is nearer to you than the second, so you will reach it first
Sense.TRAN: 〔路上或旅途中的某个地方〕在〔另一个地方〕前面
Sense.EXAMPLE: The pub is 100 m before the church on the right.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小酒馆在不到教堂100米处靠右侧的地方。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the last station before the Simplon Tunnel
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到辛普龙隧道前的最后一站

Sense.DEF: if there is a job or situation before you, you will have to do the job or face the situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: The task of emptying the house lay before us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们面前的任务是把房子腾空。

Sense.DEF: if a period of time is before you, it is about to start and you can do what you want during it
Sense.EXAMPLE: We had a glorious summer afternoon before us to do as we pleased.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们有一个阳光灿烂的夏日下午做自己喜欢的事。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You have your whole life before you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你有一生的时间随你享用。

Exponent.DEF: earlier than something or someone
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She could read before she started school.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在上学前就会阅读了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Do you want to have a shower before me?
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 你想在我之前先洗澡吗？

Exponent.DEF: before something happens
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Please arrive at the airport two hours prior to departure.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 请在飞机起飞前两小时到达机场。

Exponent.DEF: no later than a particular time or date
Exponent.TRAN: 在〔某一特定时间或日期〕之前﹐不迟于
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The children are usually in bed by 9 o'clock.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们一般在9点钟之前上床。

Exponent.DEF: before now, or before the time you are talking about
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I saw her earlier.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我先前见过她的。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I had sent the letter earlier in the week.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个星期早些时候我把信寄出了。

Exponent.DEF: before now, or before a time in the past
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He previously worked as an electrician.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他以前做过电工。

Exponent.DEF: before something happens – used especially when talking about the arrangements for something
Exponent.TRAN: 预先﹐提前〔尤用于某事的安排〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Let me know in advance if you are going to be late.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 你要晚到的话提前告诉我。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The landlord wants three months’ rent in advance.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 房东要求预付三个月的租金。

Exponent.DEF: before something happens, especially so that you are ready
Exponent.TRAN: 事先﹐预先〔尤指便于准备〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I wish we had known about all this beforehand.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 要是我们预先知道这一切就好了。

Sense.DEF: at an earlier time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Haven’t I met you before somewhere?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我以前在哪儿见过你吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Never before had he seen so many people starving.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他以前从未见过这么多的人在挨饿。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She looked just the same as before.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她看上去就和以前一样。

Sense.DEF: the previous day, week, month etc
Sense.TRAN: 前一天/一个星期/一个月等
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was in Paris last week and in Rome the week before.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她上个星期在巴黎﹐前一个星期在罗马。

Sense.DEF: ahead of someone or something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: The king’s herald walked before.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 国王的传令官走在前面。

Sense.DEF: before something else happens or is done
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police need to be briefed beforehand on how to deal with this sort of situation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 需要事先告诉警察这种情况怎样处理。
Sense.EXAMPLE: When you give a speech, it’s natural to feel nervous beforehand.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你在演讲之前感到紧张是很自然的。

Sense.DEF: to behave in a friendly way towards someone, especially someone who is younger or needs help
Sense.TRAN: 以朋友态度对待〔尤指对较年轻或需要帮助的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: They befriended me when I first arrived in London as a student.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我初到伦敦求学时﹐他们待我如同朋友。

Sense.DEF: completely confused
Sense.TRAN: 迷惑不解的﹐极其糊涂的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Even in my befuddled state, I could find my key.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 即使迷迷糊糊的﹐我还是能找到钥匙。

Sense.DEF: to ask for something in an anxious or urgent way, because you want it very much
Sense.EXAMPLE: She begged and pleaded with them until they finally agreed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她一再恳求﹐后来他们终于同意了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She fought back the sudden urge to run to him and beg his forgiveness.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她突然很想冲上去请求他原谅﹐但是她忍住了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The children begged to come with us.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们央求着要和我们一起来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I begged Helen to stay, but she wouldn’t listen.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我恳求海伦留下来﹐可她就是不听。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She ran to the nearest house and begged for help.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她跑到最近的一户人家那里恳求帮助。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: We could hear the prisoners begging for mercy .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们听到囚犯在恳求宽恕。

GramExa.GLOSS: please
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Listen, I beg of you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 听我说﹐我求你了。

GramExa.GLOSS: ask permission to do something

Sense.DEF: to ask people to give you food, money etc, usually because you are very poor

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a ragged child begging from passing shoppers
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 向过路的购物者行乞的衣衫褴褛的孩子

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The old man went from door to door begging for food.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那老人挨家挨户地讨饭。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
a begging letter
a letter asking for money
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 〔讨钱的〕求助信

Sense.DEF: if a dog begs, it sits up with its front legs off the ground

Subsense.DEF: used to ask someone to repeat what they have just said
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘The meeting’s on Wednesday.’ ‘I beg your pardon?’ ‘I said the meeting’s on Wednesday.’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “会议星期三开。”“你说什么？”“我说会议星期三开。”

Subsense.DEF: used to say sorry when you have made a mistake, or said something wrong or embarrassing
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Oh, I beg your pardon. I thought you said 15 pence, not 50.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 噢﹐对不起﹐我以为你说的是15便士﹐不是50便士呢。

Subsense.DEF: used to show that you strongly disagree with something that someone has said, or think it is unacceptable
Subsense.TRAN: 你说什么〔表示强烈反对某人说的话﹐或认为其让人无法接受〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘Chicago’s an awful place.’ ‘I beg your pardon, that’s where I’m from!’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “芝加哥是个很糟糕的地方。”“你说什么﹐我就是芝加哥人！”

Sense.DEF: used to say firmly that you do not agree with something that has been said
Sense.EXAMPLE: I must beg to differ on this point.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在这点上﹐恕我不敢苟同。

Subsense.DEF: to make you want to ask a question that has not yet been answered

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This proposal begs the question of who is going to pay for the new building.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个提议让人不禁要问: 谁来出资兴建新的大楼？

Subsense.DEF: to treat an idea as though it were true or had been proved, when this may not be the case

Sense.DEF: if something is going begging, it is available for anyone who wants it
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s a beer going begging, if anyone’s interested.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果谁想要啤酒﹐这里有一瓶可以拿去。

Sense.DEF: to do whatever you must in order to get what you want – often used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 去讨去借去偷〔常为幽默用法﹐表示为了得到某物什么都肯做〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’d beg, borrow, or steal the money for those shoes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她哪怕是去讨去借去偷也要弄到钱买那双鞋子。

Sense.DEF:
the past tense of
begin
to become the father of a child
to cause something or make it happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hunger begets crime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 饥饿滋生犯罪。

Sense.DEF: someone who lives by asking people for food and money
Sense.EXAMPLE: the beggars on the streets
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 街头乞丐

Sense.DEF: used when speaking to or about someone you like
Sense.TRAN: 幸运/懒惰/无礼等的家伙〔用于称呼或谈及喜欢的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘How’s Dave?’ ‘The lucky beggar’s in the South of France!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “戴夫好吗？”“这个幸运的家伙正在法国南部呢！”

Sense.DEF: used to say that, when you have no money or no power to choose, you have to accept whatever you are given
Sense.TRAN: 要饭的哪能挑肥拣瘦﹐要饭就不能嫌馊

Sense.DEF: if something beggars description or belief, it is impossible to describe or believe it
Sense.EXAMPLE: They showed a lack of common sense that beggars belief.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们连常识都不懂﹐让人没法相信。

Sense.DEF: to make someone very poor
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why should he beggar himself for you?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他为什么要为你受穷呢？

Sense.DEF: poor
the state of being very poor
used to talk about a request for money made by an organization or country
Sense.TRAN: 〔机构或国家的〕求乞﹐求援﹐求助
Sense.EXAMPLE: Arts and theatre groups are constantly thrusting the begging bowl at the government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 艺术和戏剧团体经常伸手向政府要钱。

Sense.DEF: a container that a beggar holds out to people for money
to start doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: As everybody’s here, let’s begin.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大家都到齐了﹐我们就开始吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the third year students begin the study of classical Chinese.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学生在三年级开始学古代汉语。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The president begins talks with the prime minister tonight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总统将于今晚和首相展开会谈。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She began to feel a sense of panic.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她开始有一种恐慌的感觉。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I began teaching in 1984.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在1984年开始教书。

Sense.DEF: if something begins, or you begin something, it starts to happen or exist from a particular time
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was the coldest winter since records began.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那是有史以来最寒冷的冬天。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The meeting begins at 10.30 am.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 会议上午10点半开始。

Sense.DEF: if you begin with something or begin by doing something, this is the first thing you do

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Shall we begin with a prayer?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们先做个祷告好吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll begin by thanking you all for being here tonight.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 首先我要感谢大家今晚来到这里。

Sense.DEF: if a book, film, or word begins with something, it starts with a particular event or letter
Sense.TRAN: 〔书﹑电影或单词〕以…开始﹐以…开头

GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘Psychosis’ begins with a P.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 单词 psychosis的第一个字母是p。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually say start rather than begin
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐人们一般说start﹐而不说begin
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: The movie starts at 7.45.
Let’s start by introducing ourselves.
Not many English names start with X.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 以X开头的英语名字不多。

Sense.DEF: to start speaking
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Ladies and gentlemen,’ he began. ‘I am delighted to be here.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “女士们﹐先生们﹐”他开始发言说﹐“我很高兴来到这里。”

Subsense.DEF: used to introduce the first and most important point you want to make
Subsense.TRAN: 首先〔用于引出首先想说的﹑最重要的内容〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Well, to begin with, he shouldn’t even have been driving my car.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好吧﹐首先他本来就不应该开我的车。

Subsense.DEF: used to say that something was already in a particular condition before something else happened
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I didn’t break it! It was like that to begin with.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不是我弄坏的！它原来就是这样的。

Subsense.DEF: during the first part of a process or activity
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The kids helped me to begin with, but they soon got bored.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 开始时孩子们都来帮忙﹐但他们很快就厌烦了。

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize how difficult something is to understand etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t begin to imagine how awful it was.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我简直无法想象情况有多糟。

Sense.DEF: to be a particular thing at the start of your existence, working life etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔指生活﹑工作等〕从…开始﹐从…做起
Sense.EXAMPLE: Roger began his career as an office boy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗杰的事业是从办公室打杂开始的。

Tail.TailContent: This graph shows how common different grammar patterns of the verb begin are. 本图表所示为动词begin构成的不同语法模式的使用频率。

Sense.DEF: someone who has just started to do or learn something
Sense.EXAMPLE: an absolute beginner
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不折不扣的初学者

Sense.DEF: unusual success that you have when you start something new
the start or first part of an event, story, period of time etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔事件﹑故事﹑一段时间等的〕开始﹐开端﹐起点

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She’s been here since the beginning of the year.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她今年年初就来了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s a short poem at the beginning of every chapter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每一章的开头都有一首短诗。
Sense.EXAMPLE: From the beginning of my career as a journalist, I’ve been writing about gender issues.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 从我一开始干记者这一行﹐我就写性别议题的题材。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I thought he loved me; perhaps he did in the beginning .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我以为他爱我﹐也许开始时他确实是爱我的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: That chance meeting marked the beginning of a long and happy relationship.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那次邂逅展开了一段长久而幸福的关系。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This is just the beginning of a new and different life for you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这只是你新的别样生活的开始。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I said he would cause trouble, right from the beginning .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一开始就说过﹐他会惹事。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I opposed it from the very beginning .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一开始就反对。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole trip was a disaster from beginning to end .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅途从头到尾都在出乱子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I feel like I’ve been offered a new beginning .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我感觉好像有了一个重新开始的机会。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Could we start at the beginning ? Tell me where you first met him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们从头讲起好吗？告诉我﹐你是在哪里认识他的？

Sense.DEF: the early signs or stages of something that later develops into something bigger or more important

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I think I have the beginnings of a cold.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我感觉要感冒了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He rose from humble beginnings to great wealth.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他出身卑微﹐如今已腰缠万贯。

Sense.DEF: the time when something good starts to end
Sense.TRAN: 结束的先兆﹐结局的开始

Exponent.DEF: the first part of something such as a story, event, or period of time
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The beginning of the movie is very violent.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部影片的开头很暴力。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Let’s go back to the beginning.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 让我们回到开始的地方。

Exponent.DEF: the beginning of something, or the way something begins
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Tomorrow marks the start of the presidential election campaign.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 明天总统竞选活动正式开始。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It was not a good start to the day.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 对这一天而言﹐这不是个好的开始。

Exponent.DEF: the beginning of something – used especially in official contexts
Exponent.TRAN: 开端﹐开始 〔尤用于正式语境〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the commencement of the academic year
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 学年的开始

Exponent.DEF: the point from which something starts to exist
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He wrote a book about the origins of the universe.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他写了本有关宇宙起源的书。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The tradition has its origins in medieval times.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一传统起源于中世纪。

Exponent.DEF: the time when something bad begins, such as illness, old age, or cold weather
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the onset of winter
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 冬天的来临
Exponent.EXAMPLE: An active lifestyle can delay the onset of many diseases common to aging.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 积极的生活方式能够延缓许多老年常见疾病的发作。

Exponent.DEF: the beginning of an important period of time in history
Exponent.EXAMPLE: People have worshipped gods since the dawn of civilization.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 自有文明以来人们就敬奉神明。

Exponent.DEF: the beginning of something important that will change many people’s lives
Exponent.TRAN: 〔将改变许多人生活的重要事情的〕诞生﹐出现
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the birth of democracy in South Africa
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 南非民主的诞生
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the birth of the environmental movement
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 环境保护运动的起始

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to go away
a plant with yellow, pink, red, or white flowers

the past tense of
beget

the past participle of
beget
to feel angry or upset with someone because they have something that you think they do not deserve

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We shouldn’t begrudge her this success.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们不应该嫉妒她这次的成功。

Sense.DEF: to feel annoyed or unhappy that you have to pay something, give someone something etc
Sense.TRAN: 舍不得给﹐不乐意给﹐吝惜

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The farmer’s wife never begrudged him a meal at the end of the day.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那农夫的妻子从不计较每天晚上给他做一顿晚饭。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I begrudge spending so much money on train fares.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我舍不得花这么多钱买火车票。

Sense.DEF: to interest and attract someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was beguiled by his smooth talk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她被他的花言巧语吸引住了。

Sense.DEF: to persuade or trick someone into doing something
Sense.TRAN: 说服﹔欺骗﹐哄骗〔某人做某事〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was beguiled into buying another copy of her book.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他经劝诱又买了她的一本书。

Sense.DEF: to do something that makes the time pass in an enjoyable way
attractive and interesting
Sense.EXAMPLE: a beguiling smile
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迷人的微笑

Sense.DEF: a title of respect, used for married Muslim women, especially of high rank
Sense.TRAN: 夫人〔对穆斯林已婚女子的尊称﹐尤用于称呼地位高者〕

Sense.DEF:
the past participle of
begin

Subsense.DEF: instead of someone, or as their representative
Subsense.EXAMPLE: She asked the doctor to speak to her parents on her behalf.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她请医生代她同她父母谈谈。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: On behalf of everyone here, may I wish you a very happy retirement.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请允许我代表在座的各位祝你退休后生活愉快。

Subsense.DEF: because of or for someone
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Oh, don’t go to any trouble on my behalf.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 噢﹐不要为我费事。

Sense.DEF: to do things that are good, bad, sensible etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: She behaved in a very responsible way .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她表现得很有责任心。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I think he behaved disgracefully towards you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得他对你太不像话了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: grown men behaving like schoolboys
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 表现得像小学生一样的成年男子

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was a little boy, but he behaved as if he was an adult.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是个小男孩﹐可表现得跟大人一样。

Sense.DEF: to not do things that annoy or offend people
Sense.EXAMPLE: Will you children please behave!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们这些孩子能不能规矩一点！
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hope Nicholas behaved himself at the party.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我希望尼古拉斯在聚会上规矩一点。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a badly-behaved class
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不守规矩的班级

Sense.DEF: if something behaves in a particular way, it does those things
Sense.EXAMPLE: Quantum mechanics is the study of the way atoms behave.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 量子力学是研究原子运动的学科。

Sense.DEF: the things that a person or animal does
Sense.EXAMPLE: It is important to reward good behaviour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 表现好要给予奖励﹐这是很重要的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She complained of her boss’s inappropriate behavior towards her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她抱怨说老板对她有不规矩行为。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the effects of alcohol on human behaviour
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 酒精对人的行为产生的影响

Sense.DEF: to behave as well and politely as you can in order to please someone
Sense.TRAN: 尽可能好地表现﹐尽量行为检点
Sense.EXAMPLE: I want you both to be on your best behaviour at Grandad’s.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我希望你们俩在爷爷家里乖乖的。

Sense.DEF: the things that something in science normally does
Sense.TRAN: 〔科学上的〕表现方式﹐活动方式﹔特点

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the behaviour of human chromosomes
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人类染色体的特点

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The boys were suspended from school for bad behaviour.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这几个男孩子因行为不端被停学。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They thought their son’s behaviour was perfectly normal.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们认为自己的儿子行为完全正常。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 咄咄逼人的/粗暴的/威胁的
Collocate.EXAMPLE: His behavior became increasingly violent.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的行为变得越来越暴力了。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: antisocial behaviour such as spitting and swearing in public
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 随地吐痰和当众讲粗话这一类反社会行为

Collocate.EXAMPLE: This sort of behavior is completely unacceptable.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种行为是完全不能接受的。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: suitable/not suitable for that situation

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She teaches children with behaviour problems.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她教有行为问题的孩子。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: declining standards of behaviour among young people
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 年轻人中每况愈下的行为标准

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He has no reason to change his behaviour.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没有理由要改变自己的行为。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The genes we inherit influence our behaviour.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们继承的遗传基因影响着我们的行为方式。

Exponent.DEF: the way someone behaves
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Chemicals added to food may be responsible for children’s bad behaviour.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 食物中添加的化学物质可能就是导致儿童不良行为的罪魁祸首。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Tatsuya apologized for his behaviour towards me.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 达也为其行为向我道歉。

Exponent.DEF: the way someone behaves in public or in their job – used mainly in official or legal contexts
Exponent.TRAN: 〔公开场合或岗位上的〕行为〔主要用于官方或法律语境〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE:
Bates was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct
noisy and violent
.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 贝茨因有妨害治安行为被逮捕。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The committee found him guilty of unsatisfactory professional conduct .
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 委员会裁定他玩忽职守。

Exponent.DEF: the way someone behaves when they are talking to or dealing with other people, which is shown in their expression, their voice etc
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She had a pleasant friendly manner.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她态度亲切友好。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Suddenly his whole manner changed, and he started shouting.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 突然他态度大变﹐开始吼叫起来。

Exponent.DEF: the way someone looks and behaves, which shows you something about their character or feelings
Exponent.TRAN: 〔显示性格或情感的〕外表﹐举止
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She maintained a calm demeanour at all times.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她任何时候都镇定自若。

Exponent.DEF: someone’s behaviour – used when you think it is silly, funny, strange, or annoying
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The drunken antics of some English football fans has brought shame on the country.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 一些英国足球迷的酒后行为给国家带来了耻辱。

Sense.DEF: the belief that the scientific study of the mind should be based only on people’s behaviour, not on what they say about their thoughts and feelings
Sense.TRAN: 行为主义〔认为科学的心理研究应该以研究对象的行为为依据﹐而不应以他们对自己的思想感情所作的陈述为依据〕

Sense.DEF: to cut off someone’s head as a punishment
Sense.TRAN: 将…斩首﹐杀…的头〔作为刑罚〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Charles I was beheaded in 1649.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 查理一世于1649年被斩首。

Sense.DEF:
the past tense and past participle of
behold
something that is very large
Sense.EXAMPLE: a trade behemoth that shipped abroad $800 billion worth of goods
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 向国外运输了价值8,000亿美元货物的贸易巨头

Sense.DEF: because someone has asked for something or ordered something to happen
Sense.TRAN: 应某人的要求﹐在某人的吩咐之下
Sense.EXAMPLE: The committee was set up at the behest of the president.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个委员会是奉总统之命成立的。

Sense.DEF: at or towards the back of a thing or person
Sense.EXAMPLE: I turned to speak to the person standing behind me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我转身和站在我后面的那人说话。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Someone could easily creep up behind us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 很可能有人跟在我们后面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The car behind was hooting impatiently.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 后面那辆车不耐烦地按着喇叭。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jane shut the door behind her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 简随手关上身后的门。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The manager was sitting behind a large desk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经理坐在一张大办公桌的后面。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He set off down the road with the rest of us following close behind.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他带头上路﹐我们其他人紧随其后。

Sense.HINTTRAN: Do not say不要说‘behind of’: He hid behind a chair (NOT 不说 behind of a chair). 他躲在一把椅子的后面。

Sense.DEF: not as successful or not having made as much progress as someone or something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mark’s always behind the rest of his class in mathematics.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马克的数学成绩总是落在班上其他同学后面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This victory lifts Ferguson’s team into fifth place, nine points behind leaders Norwich.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场胜利使弗格森的球队升到了第五名﹐落后领先的诺里奇队九分。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Europe was falling behind in the important field of computer technology.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 欧洲在计算机技术这一重要领域落后了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone is late in doing what they have to do
Sense.TRAN: 〔必须做的事情在时间上〕落后
Sense.EXAMPLE: This work should have been finished yesterday. I’m getting terribly behind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项工作应该昨天完成的﹐我落后太多了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Victor had fallen behind with his mortgage payments after losing his job.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 维克托失业以后就拖欠抵押贷款了。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
an important research project that is already two years behind schedule
not ready at the time planned
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 进度已经落后了两年的一个重要研究项目

Sense.DEF: used for talking about the hidden reason for something
Sense.TRAN: 在…背后〔用于表示某事背后的原因〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I wonder what’s behind this change of plan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想知道这次计划改变背后的原因是什么。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Perhaps a bitter experience lay behind her anger.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在她愤怒的背后可能隐藏着一次痛苦的经历。

Sense.DEF: supporting a person, idea etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The workers are very much behind these proposals.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 工人们非常支持这些建议。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I suppose I’m lucky because my parents were behind me all the way.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我是幸运的﹐因为父母一直支持我。

Sense.DEF: responsible for a plan, idea etc or for organizing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was alleged that foreign agents were behind the recent violence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 据称最近的暴力事件是由国外特工策划的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Rotary Club is behind the fund-raising for the new hospital.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扶轮社负责新医院的筹款工作。

Sense.DEF: if an unpleasant experience or situation is behind you, it no longer upsets you or affects your life
Sense.TRAN: 置于…之后〔指不愉快的事情不再困扰你或影响你的生活〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Now you can put all these worries behind you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在你可以把这些烦恼全部撇在脑后了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a chance to start a new life and leave all your troubles behind
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 抛开所有烦恼﹑开始新生活的一个机会

Sense.DEF: if you have experience behind you, you have gained valuable skills or important qualities that can be used
Sense.EXAMPLE: Marjorie is one of the top designers in the business, with years of experience behind her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛乔里是这个行业里的顶级设计师之一﹐拥有多年的工作经验。

Sense.DEF: used when the real facts about a situation or someone’s character are hidden by the way things seem or by the way a person behaves
Sense.TRAN: 在…背后﹐在…表面下〔指现象背后的真实情况﹐或某人行为后面的真实性格〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We were determined to find the truth behind this mystery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们下决心查出这谜团背后的真相。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You could see the burning hatred behind Graham’s calm manner.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 格雷厄姆举止平静的表面下﹐可以看出他的内心其实燃烧着仇恨。

Sense.DEF: if a student stays behind after school or after a lesson, they stay after it has finished
the part of your body that you sit on
to see or to look at something – sometimes used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 见到﹐看﹐注视〔有时为幽默用法〕

GramExa.PROPFORM: be a sight/joy/pleasure etc to behold
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The beauty of the garden was a pleasure to behold.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 花园美景﹐赏心悦目。

Sense.DEF: to feel that you have a duty to someone because they have done something for you
Sense.TRAN: 觉得对某人有所亏欠/欠某人人情

Sense.LEXUNIT: it behoves sb to do sth
Sense.DEF: used to say that someone should do something because it is right or necessary, or it will help them
a pale brown colour

the present participle of
be
used to give the reason for something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Being a quiet sort of person, I didn’t want to get involved.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我是个喜欢清静的人﹐所以不想介入。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can’t expect them to sit still for that long, children being what they are.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不能指望他们安安静静地坐那么长时间﹐小孩子就是小孩子。

Sense.DEF: because
Sense.EXAMPLE: You might as well drink it, being as you’ve paid for it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 还是喝了吧﹐你钱都付过了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: come into being/be brought into being
Sense.DEF: to start to exist
Sense.EXAMPLE: a law that first came into being in 1912
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 于1912年制定的一条法律

Sense.DEF: a living thing, especially a person
Sense.EXAMPLE: a human being
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个人

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a story about alien beings who invade Earth
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 外星生物入侵地球的故事

Sense.DEF: the most important quality or nature of something, especially of a person

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The whole of her being had been taken over by a desire to return to her homeland.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的整个身心都被回乡的念头占据了。

Sense.DEF: wearing jewels, or decorated with jewels
Sense.EXAMPLE: bejewelled hands
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 戴着首饰的手

Sense.DEF: to keep emphasizing a fact or idea in a way that is annoying
to hit someone or something hard
happening or arriving late
Sense.EXAMPLE: a belated attempt to increase support
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个迟来的增加资助的举措

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The statement was a belated acknowledgement that the project had not been a success.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是一个迟来的声明﹐承认这个项目没有成功。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a belated birthday present
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迟来的生日礼物

Sense.DEF: to make someone who is climbing a mountain etc safe by attaching a rope to them and to a rock
to let air from your stomach come out loudly through your mouth
to send out a large amount of smoke, flames etc, or to come out of something in large amounts
Sense.EXAMPLE: a line of chimneys belching out smoke
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 喷吐着浓烟的一排烟囱
Sense.EXAMPLE: Flames belched from the wreckage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烈焰从残骸中蹿出来。

Sense.DEF: experiencing a lot of problems or criticism
Sense.TRAN: 困难重重的﹔饱受批评的
Sense.EXAMPLE: the country’s beleaguered steel industry
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国四面楚歌的钢铁行业

Sense.DEF: surrounded by an army
Sense.EXAMPLE: Supplies are being brought into the beleaguered city.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 补给品正在运往那个被围困的城市。

Sense.DEF: a tower for a bell, especially on a church
from or relating to Belgium or its people
someone from Belgium
to give someone a false idea about something
Sense.TRAN: 使人对…产生错觉﹔使人对…误解﹔掩饰
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her pleasant manner belied her true character.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她讨人喜欢的举止掩饰了她真实的个性。

Sense.DEF: to show that something cannot be true or real
Sense.TRAN: 显示…不真实﹔证明…是虚假的
Sense.EXAMPLE: His cheerful smile belied his words.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那开心的笑容证明他的话是假的。

Sense.DEF: the feeling that something is definitely true or definitely exists

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a strong belief in God
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 笃信上帝

GramExa.EXAMPLE: her sincere belief that her brother was not the murderer
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她真心相信哥哥不是凶手

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Thieves broke into the building in the mistaken belief that there was expensive computer equipment inside.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 窃贼们闯入大楼﹐误以为里面有昂贵的电脑设备。

Sense.DEF: the feeling that something is good and can be trusted

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you’re selling, you have to have genuine belief in the product.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你在销售某个产品﹐就必须对所售产品真正有信心。

Sense.EXAMPLE: When you get something wrong, it can shake your belief in yourself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果有什么事情没做好﹐就会动摇你对自己的信心。

Sense.DEF: an idea that you believe to be true, especially one that forms part of a system of ideas
Sense.EXAMPLE: religious beliefs
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宗教信仰
Sense.EXAMPLE: Several members hold very right-wing beliefs .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有几个成员持有很“右”的观点。

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that something is so extreme that it is difficult to believe
Sense.EXAMPLE: What she did was stupid beyond belief.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她所做的事情傻得叫人难以相信。

Crossrefto.REFLEX: to the best of your belief

Collocate.EXAMPLE: It is still my firm belief that we did the right thing.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我仍然坚信我们做的事是正确的。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: that you believe very much
Collocate.EXAMPLE: her strongly-held belief that things were much better in the past
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她坚信过去比现在好很多

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: that a lot of people believe
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There is a common belief that educational standards are declining.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 普遍的观点是教育水准在下降。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: the mistaken belief that cannabis is not an addictive drug
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 认为大麻不会致瘾的错误想法

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: based on what you really feel is true

Collocate.EXAMPLE: You must always have the belief that you can succeed.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 你必须始终相信自己能够成功。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He held this belief until the day he died.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他至死都坚守着这个信念。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: It is my belief that most teachers are doing a good job.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我认为大部分教师都干得不错。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: opposite to what most people think
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Contrary to popular belief, boys are not usually better at maths than girls.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 与普遍看法相反的是﹐男孩子在数学方面并非通常都优于女孩子。

Sense.DEF: something that is believable can be believed because it seems possible, likely, or real
Sense.EXAMPLE: a story with believable characters in it
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人物真实可信的故事
Sense.EXAMPLE: That scenario is entirely believable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那样的设想完全是可信的。

Sense.DEF: to be sure that something is true or that someone is telling the truth
Sense.EXAMPLE: You shouldn’t believe everything you read.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不应尽信书上看来的东西。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I believed him, even though his story sounded unlikely.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我相信了他﹐尽管他的话听上去难以置信。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I don’t believe he’s only 25.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不相信他只有25岁。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
I don’t believe a word of it
I think it is completely untrue
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一句话也不相信。

Sense.DEF: to think that something is true or possible, although you are not completely sure

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Detectives believe that the victim knew his killer.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 侦探认为被害人认识凶手。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It is believed that the house was built in 1735.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 据信这房子建于1735年。

GramExa.GLOSS: think that something is true
GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘Have they arrived yet?’ ‘Yes, I believe so.’
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “他们到了吗？”“嗯﹐我想到了。”

GramExa.EXAMPLE: At 115, Mrs Jackson is believed to be the oldest person in the country.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 115岁的杰克逊夫人被认为是国内最高寿的人。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
The four men are widely believed
believed by a lot of people
to have been killed by their captors.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们普遍认为﹐那四名男子已遭绑架者杀害。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Did you honestly believe that I’d be stupid enough to do that?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你真的认为我会傻到做那样的事情吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: I firmly believe that the business will be a success.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我坚信公司会成功的。

Sense.DEF: used when you are surprised that something is true
Sense.TRAN: 很难相信〔用于表示惊异〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sometimes, it’s hard to believe we’ve been married for 50 years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有时候﹐很难相信我们已经结婚50年了。

Sense.DEF: used when you are very surprised or shocked by something
Sense.TRAN: 不能/不敢相信某事〔用于表示惊异或震惊〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t believe he’s expecting us to work on Sunday!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我真不敢相信﹐他竟然要我们星期天上班！
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t believe it when he told me what had happened.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当他告诉我发生的这一切时﹐我简直没法相信。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I could scarcely believe my luck.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我几乎不敢相信自己的运气。

Sense.DEF: used when you are saying something that is true but surprising
Sense.EXAMPLE: He enjoys school, believe it or not.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 信不信由你﹐他喜欢上学。

Sense.DEF: used when you are surprised or angry about something
Sense.TRAN: 你会相信吗？ 我不能相信！〔表示惊讶或生气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: And then he just walked out. Would you believe it!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 然后他就走出去了。 你能相信吗！

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that something is definitely true
Sense.TRAN: 相信我〔用于强调某事绝对是真的〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’ll be trouble when they find out about this, believe you me!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 相信我﹐这件事如果给他们发现了会很麻烦的！

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that something is true
Sense.TRAN: 你最好相信！〔用于强调某事是真的〕

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that something is definitely not true
Sense.TRAN: 千万不要相信！〔用于强调某事绝对不是真的〕

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone is very surprised by something they see or hear
Sense.TRAN: 不敢相信自己的眼睛/耳朵

Sense.LEXUNIT: if you believe that, you’ll believe anything
Sense.DEF: used to say that something is definitely not true, and that anyone who believes it must be stupid
Sense.TRAN: 你要是连这都相信﹐还有什么不信的﹔谁相信谁就是傻瓜

Variant.LEXVAR: I’ll believe it when I see it

Sense.DEF: used to say that you will only believe that something happens or exists when you actually see it
to have a religious faith
Sense.EXAMPLE: She says those who believe will go to heaven.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她说信教的人可以进天堂。

Exponent.DEF: to be sure that something is true or that someone is telling the truth
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I believed her when she said that she loved me.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她说她爱我﹐我相信了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Don’t believe anything he tells you.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他告诉你的任何话都别信。

Exponent.DEF: to believe that something is true, especially because someone has persuaded you to believe it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: His wife accepted his explanation for why he was late.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他妻子接受了他对于迟到的解释。

Exponent.DEF: to believe what someone says is true, even though you have no proof or experience of it
Exponent.TRAN: 〔在没有证据或经验的情况下〕相信某人的话
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I don’t know anything about him, so I’ll just have to take your word for it.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我对他一点也不了解﹐所以只能相信你的话。

Exponent.EXP: give sb the benefit of the doubt
Exponent.DEF: to believe what someone says, even though you think it might not be true
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Unless you have proof, you should give him the benefit of the doubt.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 除非你有真凭实据﹐否则只能姑且相信他的话。

Section.SECHEADING: to believe something that is untrue

Exponent.DEF: to be tricked into believing something that is not true
Exponent.EXAMPLE: A lot of people were taken in by these claims.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多人都给这些说法蒙骗了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I can’t believe she fell for that old excuse!
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我简直不敢相信她竟会听信那种惯用的借口。

Exponent.DEF: to believe a story or explanation that is not true, especially when this makes you seem silly
Exponent.EXAMPLE: His aunt had swallowed his story unquestioningly.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他姑妈毫无疑心地相信了他的说法。

Sense.DEF: to be sure that someone or something exists
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you believe in God?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你相信有上帝吗？

Sense.DEF: to think that something is effective or right
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t believe in these diets.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不相信这些节食方法。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The school believes in letting children learn at their own pace.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学校认为要让孩子按着自己的进度学习。

Sense.DEF: to trust someone and be confident that they will be successful
Sense.TRAN: 信任﹐信赖﹐相信〔某人会成功〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The people want a president they can believe in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老百姓想要一个可以信赖的总统。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Believe in yourself, or you’ll never succeed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 相信自己﹐否则你永远不会成功。

Sense.DEF: to believe strongly that something is good and effective
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m a great believer in regular exercise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我深信经常锻炼有好处。

Sense.DEF: someone who believes in a particular god, religion, or system of beliefs
in Britain, one of two posts with a round flashing orange light on the top, marking a place that cars must stop at to allow people to cross a road
to make someone or something seem small or unimportant
Sense.EXAMPLE: He tends to belittle her efforts.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他往往轻视她的努力。

Sense.DEF: a piece of electrical equipment that makes a ringing sound, used as a signal or to get someone’s attention

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He rang the bell and waited for someone to answer the door.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他按了门铃﹐等着有人来开门。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: She walked up the path and rang the door bell .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她沿着小路走过去按响了门铃。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The bell went and everyone rushed out of the classroom.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 铃声一响﹐大家都冲出了教室。

Sense.DEF: a hollow metal object like a cup with a piece of metal hanging inside it, that makes a ringing noise when it moves or you shake it
Sense.EXAMPLE: church bells
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 教堂的钟

Sense.DEF: to telephone someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: I must give Vicky a bell later.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我过一会儿必须给维基打个电话。

Sense.DEF: something that is shaped like a bell
Sense.EXAMPLE: the bell of a flower
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 钟状的花萼

PIC.HEADING: BELLS 铃
PIC.PICCONTENT: bell 响铃; cowbell 牛颈铃; doorbell 门铃; bicycle bell 自行车铃

Sense.DEF: a poisonous plant
a substance from this plant, used as a drug
trousers with legs that get wider from the knee to the bottom
a young man who carries bags, takes messages etc in a hotel
Sense.TRAN: 〔宾馆的〕行李员﹐做杂役的男侍者

Sense.DEF: a beautiful girl or woman

GramExa.GLOSS: the most beautiful girl at a dance or party
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 舞会之花﹐舞会上最美的女子

Sense.DEF: a young man who carries bags, takes messages etc in a hotel
Sense.TRAN: 〔宾馆的〕行李员﹐做杂役的男侍者

Sense.DEF: behaving in a way that is likely to start an argument or fight
Sense.EXAMPLE: bellicose criticism
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 咄咄逼人的批评

Sense.DEF: very unfriendly and wanting to argue or fight
Sense.TRAN: 敌对的﹔好斗的﹔好寻衅的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a belligerent attitude
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 敌对的态度

Sense.DEF: a belligerent country is fighting a war against another country
to shout loudly in a deep voice
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘That’s your problem!’ bellowed Hurley.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “那是你的问题！”赫尔利吼道。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tony was bellowing orders.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 托尼正在吆喝着发号施令。

Sense.DEF:
to make the deep sound that a
bull
makes
a loud deep shout
Sense.EXAMPLE: His voice rose to a bellow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他提高声音﹐咆哮了起来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Alex gave another bellow of laughter.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 亚历克斯又发出一阵狂笑。

Sense.DEF:
the deep sound that a
bull
makes

Subsense.DEF: an object used for blowing air into a fire to make it burn better

part of a musical instrument that pushes air through pipes to produce a sound, for example in an
organ

Sense.DEF: a hollow red, green, or yellow vegetable
someone who rings church bells

Subsense.DEF: your stomach
Subsense.EXAMPLE: a full belly
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吃饱的肚子

Subsense.DEF: the front part of your body between your chest and your legs
Subsense.EXAMPLE: She was lying on her belly.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她趴着。

Sense.DEF: the middle part of an animal’s body, near its stomach
a curved or rounded part of an object
Sense.EXAMPLE: the belly of a plane
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机的机腹

Sense.DEF: having a black, fat, big etc stomach
Sense.TRAN: 黑色腹部的/腹部肥硕的/大腹便便的等

Sense.DEF: if a business or company goes belly up, it stops operating because it cannot pay its debts
to fill with air and become rounder in shape
a pain in your stomach
to complain a lot, especially about something unimportant

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She never stops bellyaching about money.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她一刻不停地抱怨没钱。

Sense.DEF: the small round mark in the middle of your stomach

a dance from the Middle East in which a woman moves her stomach and
hip s
around
Sense.TRAN: 肚皮舞〔一种源于中东的舞蹈﹐跳舞的女子扭动腹部和臀部〕

Sense.DEF: a way of jumping into water, in which the front of your body falls flat against the surface of the water
Sense.TRAN: 胸腹先着水的跳水动作

Sense.LEXUNIT: have had a bellyful of sb/sth
Sense.DEF: to be annoyed by someone or something because you have had to deal with them for too long
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d had a bellyful of his family by the end of the weekend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到周末过完的时候﹐我已经受够了他们一家人。

Sense.DEF: a deep loud laugh
if something belongs somewhere, that is the right place or situation for it
Sense.TRAN: 应在〔某处〕﹔适合〔某种情形〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Put the chair back where it belongs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把椅子放回原处。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an attitude that doesn’t belong in modern society
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不适合现代社会的处世态度

Sense.DEF: if you feel you belong in a place or situation, you feel happy and comfortable in it, because you have the same interests and ideas as other people
Sense.TRAN: 〔在某个地方或某种情形中〕能适应﹔感到自在
Sense.EXAMPLE: I worked there for five years but never really felt I belonged.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在那里工作了五年﹐但是从来没有真正觉得自己属于那里。

RunOn.EXAMPLE:
It’s important to have a sense of belonging
a feeling that you are happy and comfortable somewhere
.

Sense.DEF: if something belongs to someone, they own it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The book belongs to Dan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这本书是丹的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Who does this scarf belong to?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是谁的围巾？

Sense.DEF: to be a member of a group or organization
Sense.TRAN: 是…的成员﹐属于〔某团体或组织〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: He belongs to the golf club.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是高尔夫球俱乐部的成员。

Sense.DEF: to be related to something or form part of it
Sense.TRAN: 与〔某事物〕有关﹔是…的一部分
Sense.EXAMPLE: cars that belong to a different era
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 属于另一个时代的汽车

Sense.DEF: to be related to or produced by a particular person
Sense.EXAMPLE: She recognized the voice as belonging to the man who had attacked her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她听出那就是袭击她的那个人的声音。

Sense.DEF: if a competition or period of time belongs to someone, they are the most important or successful person in it
Sense.TRAN: 属于〔指某人是一场比赛或一段时间中最重要或最成功的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: All the acts were good, but the evening belonged to a dance group from Moscow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有的表演都很精彩﹐但是当晚最受欢迎的是一个来自莫斯科的舞蹈团。

Sense.DEF: the things you own, especially things that you can carry with you
Sense.EXAMPLE: an insurance policy that covers your personal belongings
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一张承保个人财物的保单

Sense.DEF: loved very much by someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: He never recovered from the death of his beloved daughter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一直没有走出失去爱女的阴影。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s always talking about his beloved computer!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他老是在谈论他的宝贝电脑！

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a book beloved of children everywhere
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 受各地儿童钟爱的一本书

Sense.DEF: someone who is loved very much
in a lower place or position, or on a lower level
Sense.EXAMPLE: an animal that lives below ground
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生活在地下的动物
Sense.EXAMPLE: Water was dripping onto the floor below.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 水滴到下面的地板上。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could hear voices in the courtyard below my window.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我能听到院子里有人在我的窗下说话。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They camped a few hundred feet below the summit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们在山峰下面几百英尺的地方扎了营。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Down below, people were talking and laughing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下面﹐人们谈笑风生。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Somewhere far below, a door slammed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下面远远的什么地方有一扇门砰地关上了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The kitchen is directly below her bedroom.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 厨房就在她卧室的正下方。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Captain Parker went below
to the lower level of the ship
, leaving Clooney in charge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 帕克船长下去了﹐让克卢尼掌舵。

Sense.DEF: of a lower rank or having a less important job than someone else
Sense.EXAMPLE: No one below the level of senior manager was present at the meeting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 高级经理职位以下没有人出席会议。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: officers of the rank of captain and below
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 上尉及上尉以下的军官

Sense.DEF: less than a particular number, amount, level etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Test scores below 50 were classed as ‘unsatisfactory’.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 50分以下的测验成绩归入“不理想”一类。
Sense.EXAMPLE: In June the rate of inflation fell below 3%.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 6月份﹐通货膨胀率降到了3%以下。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Tom’s spelling is well below average
much worse than the normal standard
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汤姆的拼写远低于平均水平。

GramExa.GLOSS: lower than the temperature at which water freezes
GramExa.EXAMPLE: In winter, temperatures dip to 40 degrees below freezing.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 冬天﹐气温会降到零下40度。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: free travel for children four years old and below
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 四岁及四岁以下儿童免费乘车

Sense.DEF: lower on the same page, or on a later page
Sense.EXAMPLE: Details of courses are listed below.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 课程的详细介绍列在下面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: For more information, see below.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 详情请看下面。

Sense.DEF: a band of leather, cloth etc that you wear around your waist to hold up your clothes or for decoration
Sense.EXAMPLE: He unbuckled his leather belt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他解开皮带。

Sense.DEF: a large area of land that has particular features or where particular people live
Sense.TRAN: 〔具有某种特色或某类人居住的〕地区﹐地带
Sense.EXAMPLE: America’s farming belt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 美国农业区
Sense.EXAMPLE:
the green
countryside
belt BrE
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 【英】绿化地带

Sense.DEF: a circular band of something such as rubber that connects or moves parts of a machine
unfair or cruel
Sense.EXAMPLE: That was a bit below the belt, Paul.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保罗﹐那样做有点不公平。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
The comments hit below the belt
they were unfair or cruel
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些话是恶意中伤。

Sense.DEF: to have achieved something useful or important
Sense.EXAMPLE: a secretary with several years’ experience under her belt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位拥有数年工作经验的秘书

Sense.DEF: a belt and braces way of doing something is one in which you do more than necessary in order to make sure that it succeeds
to hit someone or something hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dan belted the ball towards the goal.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 丹猛的一脚把球踢向球门。

Sense.DEF: to go somewhere very fast

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We were belting down the motorway at 95 miles per hour.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们以每小时95英里的速度在高速公路上疾驶。

Sense.DEF: to fasten something with a belt
Sense.EXAMPLE: Maria belted her raincoat firmly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽亚把雨衣系紧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a dress belted loosely at the waist
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 裙腰处松松地系着带子的连衣裙

Sense.DEF: to sing a song or play an instrument loudly
Sense.TRAN: 引吭高歌﹔高声演奏〔乐器〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was belting out old Broadway favourites.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在高唱百老汇的经典老歌。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone rudely to be quiet

to fasten your
seat belt
in a vehicle
fastened with a belt
Sense.EXAMPLE: a belted jacket
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有腰带的夹克衫

Sense.DEF: a fast main road that goes around a city, not through the centre
to complain or say that you are disappointed about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was bemoaning the fact that lawyers charge so much.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他抱怨律师收费太高。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an article bemoaning the lack of sports facilities in the area
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对本地区运动设施的缺乏表示不满的一篇文章

Sense.DEF: looking as if you are confused
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bemused expression
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 茫然的神情

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He looked slightly bemused by all the questions.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 面对所有这些问题﹐他看上去有点困惑。

Sense.DEF: a long seat for two or more people, especially outdoors
Sense.EXAMPLE: We sat on a park bench.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们坐在公园的长椅上。

Subsense.DEF:
the seat where a judge or
magistrate
sits in a court of law
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Would the prisoner please approach the bench?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请犯人走近法官席好吗？

Subsense.DEF:
the position of being a judge or
magistrate
in a court of law
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He was appointed to the bench last year.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他去年被任命为法官。

GramExa.GLOSS:
work as a judge or
magistrate

Sense.DEF: the seat where members of a sports team sit when they are not playing in the game
Sense.EXAMPLE: Batts and Dorigo are on the bench tonight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今晚巴茨和多利哥是替补队员。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Simpson came off the bench to play in midfield.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 辛普森离开替补席上场打中场。

Sense.DEF: the seats in the British parliament where members of a particular party sit
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was cheering from the Conservative benches.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保守党的议员席那边响起了欢呼声。

Sense.DEF: a long heavy table used for working on with tools or equipment
Sense.EXAMPLE: a carpenter’s bench
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 木工工作台

Sense.DEF: to not allow a sports player to play in a game, or to remove them from a game
Sense.EXAMPLE: Anderson has been benched until his injury has healed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 安德森伤势未愈﹐不能上场。

Sense.DEF: something that is used as a standard by which other things can be judged or measured
Sense.EXAMPLE: benchmark data
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 基准数据
Sense.EXAMPLE: The valuation becomes a benchmark against which to judge other prices.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个估价成了判断其他价格的依据。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: figures that are a useful benchmark for measuring the company’s performance
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 为衡量公司业绩提供实用标准的一些数据

GramExa.EXAMPLE: results that are used as a benchmark of success
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 作为成功判断标准的业绩

Sense.DEF: to use a company’s good performance as a standard by which to judge the performance of other companies of the same type
Sense.TRAN: 把〔指把某一公司的好业绩〕作为衡量标准

GramExa.EXAMPLE: British Steel is benchmarked against the best operations anywhere in the world.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国钢铁公司以世界各地最好的企业作为衡量标准。

Sense.DEF:
a player in a sports team who does not play in many matches, but is usually a
substitute
to move part of your body so that it is not straight or so that you are not upright
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lee bent and kissed her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 李俯下身来亲她。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She bent her head.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她低下头。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bend your knees, but keep your back straight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 膝盖弯曲﹐背部保持挺直。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Emma bent over to pick up the coins.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃玛弯腰去捡硬币。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I bent down to lift the box off the floor.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我弯腰把地上的箱子提起来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He bent towards me and whispered in my ear.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他俯过身来在我耳边低语。

Sense.DEF: to push or press something so that it is no longer flat or straight
Sense.EXAMPLE: You need a special tool to bend the steel.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你要用特殊的工具才能把这钢条弄弯。

Sense.DEF: to become curved and no longer flat or straight
Sense.EXAMPLE: Several branches started bending towards the ground.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 数根枝条开始向地面弯垂。

Sense.DEF: when a road bends, it changes direction to form a curve
Sense.EXAMPLE: The road bends sharply to the left.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 路向左急转。

Sense.DEF: to say something that is not completely true
to try very hard to be helpful
Sense.EXAMPLE: We bent over backwards to finish it on time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们拼命地干﹐要把它按时完成。

Sense.DEF: to talk to someone, especially for a long time, about something that is worrying you
Sense.TRAN: 和某人谈心〔尤指谈令人烦恼的事〕

Subsense.DEF: trying very hard to persuade someone to do something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He begged on bended knee for another chance.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他苦苦哀求再给他一次机会。

Subsense.DEF: in a kneeling position
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He went down on bended knee and asked her to marry him.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他跪下来向她求婚。

Sense.DEF: to give all your energy or attention to one activity, plan etc
Sense.TRAN: 集中全力于某事﹐专心致志于某事

Sense.DEF: to do what someone else wants, especially when you do not want to

PIC.HEADING: BEND 俯身
PIC.PICCONTENT: bow 鞠躬；bend 俯身

Sense.DEF: a curved part of something, especially a road or river
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指道路或河流的〕拐弯﹐弯道
Sense.EXAMPLE: The car came round the bend at a terrifying speed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那辆汽车以惊人的速度拐过弯道。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a sharp bend in the road
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 路上的一个急转弯

Sense.DEF: an action in which you bend a part of your body
Sense.EXAMPLE: We started the session with a few knee bends to warm up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在上课前先做了些曲膝动作来热身。

Sense.DEF: to annoy someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: His attitude drives me round the bend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的态度把我惹恼了。

Sense.DEF: to be or become crazy
Sense.EXAMPLE: I sometimes feel I’m going round the bend looking after young children all day.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 整天照看小孩子﹐我有时候觉得我都快疯了。

Sense.DEF:
a painful and serious condition that
diver s
get if they come up from deep water too quickly
Sense.TRAN: 屈肢症〔潜水员浮出水面过快造成的剧痛〕

Sense.DEF: a time when people drink a lot of alcohol or take a lot of drugs
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole team went on a bender and were arrested.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 整个球队聚众吸毒被抓。

Sense.DEF: a very offensive word for a man who is attracted to other men. Do not use this word.
easy to bend
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bendy rubber doll
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 容易弯折的橡皮娃娃

Sense.DEF: with many curves or angles
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bendy road
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一条弯弯曲曲的路

Sense.DEF: a long bus that can bend in the middle
in or to a lower position than something, or directly under something
Sense.TRAN: 在…之下﹐在…正下方﹔往…下面
Sense.EXAMPLE: The dolphins disappeared beneath the waves.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 海豚消失在波涛中。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jo enjoyed feeling the warm sand beneath her feet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔很喜欢脚下踩着温暖沙子的感觉。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was standing on the bridge looking at the river beneath.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他站在桥上﹐看着下面的河水。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Some roofs collapsed beneath the weight of
unable to support the weight of
so much snow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些房子的屋顶不堪积雪的重压塌陷了。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually use underneath (as an adverb or preposition) or under (as a preposition) when talking about position
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐谈到位置时人们通常用underneath（副词或介词）或under（介词）
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: They hid under the table.
a picture with a caption underneath
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 下面有说明文字的照片

Sense.DEF: covered by something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shiona shivered beneath the bedclothes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 希奥娜在被单下面瑟瑟发抖。

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone’s real character or feelings are not shown because their appearance or behaviour is different
Sense.TRAN: 在…的表面之下〔指真实性格或情感没有显现〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dave sensed that something more sinister lay beneath the woman’s cheerful exterior.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 戴夫感觉到﹐在那个女人开朗的外表下隐藏着一颗邪恶的心。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Beneath the surface she was angry.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她表面上没有显露出来﹐实际上很愤怒。

Sense.DEF: not good enough or suitable for someone
Sense.TRAN: 配不上〔某人〕﹐与〔某人〕不相称
Sense.EXAMPLE: She acts as if even speaking to us is beneath her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的样子好像和我们说句话都有失身份。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He felt it would be beneath his dignity to comment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他觉得发表意见会有失他的尊严。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
His mother felt he was marrying beneath him
marrying someone who was not good enough
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他母亲觉得他娶的妻子配不上他。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
I consider such behaviour to be beneath contempt
so bad that you have no respect for the person involved
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得这种行为为人所不齿。

Sense.DEF: in a lower, less important rank or job than someone else

a strong alcoholic drink that is a type of
liqueur
Sense.TRAN: 本尼迪克特甜酒〔一种烈酒〕

Sense.DEF:
a member of a Christian religious order of
monk s

PronCodes.PRON: ˌbenɪˈdɪkʃ ə n, ˌbenəˈdɪkʃ ə n

Sense.DEF: a Christian prayer that asks God to protect and help someone

PronCodes.PRON: ˌbenɪˈfækʃ ə n, ˌbenəˈfækʃ ə n

Sense.DEF: something, especially money, that someone gives a person or organization in order to help them do something good, or when someone gives money in this way
someone who gives money for a good purpose
Sense.EXAMPLE: An anonymous benefactor donated $2 million.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位没留姓名的捐助人捐款二百万美元。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a generous benefactor of the university
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 该大学一名慷慨的捐助人

Sense.DEF:
the pay and position of a Christian priest who is in charge of a
parish

PronCodes.PRON: bɪˈnefɪs ə nt, bɪˈnefəs ə nt

Sense.DEF: helping people, or resulting in something good
Sense.TRAN: 行善的﹔有帮助的﹐有助益的
Sense.EXAMPLE: the beneficent properties of natural remedies
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 自然疗法的益处

PronCodes.PRON: ˌbenɪˈfɪʃ ə l◂, ˌbenəˈfɪʃ ə l◂

Sense.DEF: having a good effect
Sense.TRAN: 有利的﹐有帮助的﹐有用的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a drug that has a beneficial effect on the immune system
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有益于免疫系统的一种药物

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Cycling is highly beneficial to health and the environment.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 骑自行车对于身体和环境都大有裨益。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
an arrangement that is mutually beneficial
it has advantages for everyone who is involved
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一项互惠互利的协定

Sense.DEF: someone who gets advantages from an action or change

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The rich were the main beneficiaries of the tax cuts.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 富人是这次减税的主要受益者。

Sense.DEF: someone who receives money or property from someone else who has died
Sense.TRAN: 遗产继承人﹐〔遗嘱的〕受益人

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was the chief beneficiary of his father’s will.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是他父亲遗嘱的主要受益人。

Sense.DEF: an advantage, improvement, or help that you get from something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the benefits of contact lenses
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 隐形眼镜的好处

Sense.EXAMPLE: I never had the benefit of a university education.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从未受过大学教育。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The new credit cards will be of great benefit to our customers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 新信用卡将大大方便我们的客户。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hope that the decision taken today will be to the benefit of the whole nation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我希望今天所作的决定将惠及我们整个国家。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Could you just explain again for Mark’s benefit?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你为马克再解释一遍好吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Most motorists manage without the benefit of four-wheel drive.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数汽车司机都不用四轮驱动。

Sense.DEF: money provided by the government to people who are sick, unemployed, or have little money
Sense.TRAN: 〔政府为病人﹑失业人士或穷人提供的〕补助金﹐救济金﹐津贴

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You might be entitled to housing benefit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你也许有资格申领住房津贴。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: families on benefit
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 领救济金的家庭

Sense.EXAMPLE: those people eligible to claim benefit
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那些可以申请补助的人

Sense.DEF: extra money or other advantages that you get as part of your job or from insurance that you have
Sense.TRAN: 〔工作单位提供的〕福利﹐补贴﹔保险金
Sense.EXAMPLE: We offer an excellent benefits package .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们提供非常好的综合福利。
Sense.EXAMPLE: medical benefits
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医疗福利

Sense.LEXUNIT: give sb the benefit of the doubt
Sense.DEF: to accept what someone tells you, even though you think they may be wrong or lying but you cannot be sure
Sense.TRAN: 虽有怀疑但还是相信某人﹐姑且相信某人
Sense.EXAMPLE: The referee gave him the benefit of the doubt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 裁判员虽有怀疑﹐但还是没有判他犯规。

Sense.DEF: used to say it is easier to know the right thing to do after something has happened or if you have a lot of experience
Sense.TRAN: 借助于事后的认识/经验
Sense.EXAMPLE: He admitted that with the benefit of hindsight the original launch had not been large enough.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他承认事后才明白最初的投放量不够大。

Sense.DEF:
a concert, performance etc arranged to make money for
charity
Sense.EXAMPLE: a benefit concert for famine relief
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为饥荒灾民筹款的慈善音乐会

Collocate.EXAMPLE: All the hotel rooms have the benefit of a balcony.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有的酒店客房都有一个阳台。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: In this way, students will gain maximum benefit from their classes.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样﹐学生就能从课上获得最大限度地受益。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: You’ll enjoy all the benefits of being a member.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 你将享用到所有的会员优惠。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: enjoy the advantages of something you have worked hard to get
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He was looking forward to reaping the benefits of all his hard work.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他期待着收获他所有艰苦努力的成果。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The new bridge has brought considerable benefits.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这座新桥带来了很大的便利。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: something is more important than the benefits
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Make sure that the risks don’t outweigh the benefits.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 确保风险不能大于收益。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The new system will be a great benefit to the company.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种新制度将为公司带来极大的益处。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: To get some real benefit from the exercise, you should continue for at least half an hour.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 你应该至少连续锻炼半小时﹐才能获得切实的效果。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They will have the full benefit of our facilities.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们将能充分享用我们的设施。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Tourism has brought considerable economic benefits to the island.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅游业给这个岛带来了巨额经济效益。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: something good for both people, companies etc involved

Sense.DEF: if you benefit from something, or it benefits you, it gives you an advantage, improves your life, or helps you in some way
Sense.TRAN: 受益﹐得益﹔有益于﹐有利于
Sense.EXAMPLE: They are working together to benefit the whole community.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们在为整个社区的利益共同努力。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Many thousands have benefited from the new treatment.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 千千万万的人已受益于这种新疗法。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: They would benefit by reducing their labour costs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们将得益于劳动力成本的降低。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m sure you’ll benefit greatly from the visit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我相信﹐这次访问将使你获益匪浅。

Sense.DEF: the countries of Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg considered as a group
Sense.TRAN: 比利时﹑荷兰﹑卢森堡三国﹔比荷卢联盟

Sense.DEF: kind and generous
Sense.TRAN: 仁慈的﹐仁爱的﹔乐善好施的
Sense.EXAMPLE: A benevolent uncle paid for her to have music lessons.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位叔叔慷慨解囊﹐出钱供她上音乐课。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a benevolent smile
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 慈祥的笑容

Sense.DEF:
a first university
degree
in
engineering
the language used in Bangladesh and West Bengal
someone from Bengal
having no knowledge or understanding
kind and gentle
Sense.EXAMPLE: He shook his head in benign amusement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被逗乐了，和蔼地摇了摇头。

Sense.DEF:
a benign
tumour
unnatural growth in the body
is not caused by
cancer

the past tense and past participle of
bend
no longer straight
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bent nail
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弯曲的钉子
Sense.EXAMPLE: Stand with your knees slightly bent.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 双膝微曲站立。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
He breathed in deeply, bent double in pain
with the top part of your body leaning forward towards your legs
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他深深地吸着气﹐痛得直不起腰来。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
a bent old man
not standing straight
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个驼背老汉

Sense.DEF: completely determined to do something, especially something bad
Sense.TRAN: 一心想做某事﹐执意要做某事 〔尤指坏事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a crowd of hooligans bent on violence
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 执意要施暴的一群流氓

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They seemed bent on destroying his career.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们好像决意要毁掉他的前程。

Sense.DEF: financially dishonest and willing to use your official position unfairly
Sense.TRAN: 〔经济上〕不诚实的﹐营私舞弊的﹔贪赃枉法的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bent policeman
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 贪赃枉法的警察

Sense.DEF:
an insulting word meaning
homosexual
very angry or upset
Sense.TRAN: 非常气愤的﹔相当不安的

Sense.DEF: special natural skill or interest in a particular area

GramExa.EXAMPLE: readers of a more literary bent
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 文学天赋较高的读者

Sense.DEF: a liquid obtained from coal, used for making plastics

a liquid obtained from
petroleum
, used to clean clothes
Sense.TRAN: 轻质汽油﹐轻油精﹐挥发油〔一种从石油提炼出的液体﹐用于清洁衣物〕

Sense.DEF: to officially arrange for someone to have something that you own after your death

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She bequeathed her collection of paintings to the National Gallery.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她把自己的藏画遗赠给国家美术馆。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: His father bequeathed him a fortune.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他父亲留给他一大笔财产。

Sense.DEF: to pass knowledge, customs etc to people who come after you or live after you
money or property that you arrange to give to someone after your death
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bequest of $5,000
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 五千美元的遗产

Sense.DEF: to speak angrily to someone because they have done something wrong
having lost a close friend or relative because they have recently died
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bereaved mother
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 痛失孩子的母亲

Sense.DEF: the person or people whose close friend or relative has just died
Sense.EXAMPLE: Our sympathies go to the bereaved.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们对死者的亲友表示慰问。

Sense.DEF: when someone loses a close friend or relative because they have died
Sense.TRAN: 丧亲（之痛）﹔丧友（之痛）﹔居丧
Sense.EXAMPLE: depression caused by bereavement or divorce
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 丧亲或离婚导致的抑郁消沉

Sense.DEF: completely without any hope etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The team now seems bereft of inspiration.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这支球队现在好像毫无斗志。

Sense.DEF: feeling very sad and lonely
Sense.EXAMPLE: His death in 1990 left her completely bereft.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他于1990年去世﹐令她深感孤寂。

Sense.DEF: a round cap with a tight band around the head and a soft loose top part
Sense.TRAN: 贝雷帽〔扁圆无檐柔软的小帽〕

Sense.DEF:
a disease of the nerves caused by lack of
vitamin B
a stupid person
short trousers that end at the knee
a small soft fruit with small seeds
to become very angry and violent
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dad went berserk when he found out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸知道以后勃然大怒。

Sense.DEF: a place where a ship can stop and be tied up
a place for someone to sleep on a ship or on a train
Sense.TRAN: 〔火车上的〕卧铺﹐铺位；〔船的〕舱位

Sense.DEF: to bring a ship into a berth, or arrive at a berth
a valuable stone that is usually green or yellow
to eagerly and anxiously ask someone for something
to make someone experience serious problems or dangers

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The business has been beset with financial problems.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 该企业为财务问题所困扰。

Sense.EXAMPLE: the injuries which have beset the team all season
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 困扰球队整个赛季的伤病问题

Sense.DEF: a particular bad feature or habit – often used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 坏习惯﹐恶习〔常为幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: next to or very close to the side of someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Wendy came up and sat beside me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 温迪走过来﹐坐在我身边。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the table beside the bed
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 床边的桌子
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was standing right beside her at the time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当时我就站在她的旁边。
Sense.HINTTRAN: Do not confuse beside (=next to) and besides (=in addition to). 不要混淆 beside（在…旁边）和 besides（除此之外）: He sat down beside Mary. 他在玛丽身边坐了下来。 | Who was there besides you? 那里除了你还有谁？

Sense.DEF: in comparison with something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: This year’s sales figures don’t look very good beside last year’s results.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今年的销售额和去年相比不是很好。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The children seemed tiny beside him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们在他身边显得只有一丁点大。

Sense.DEF: to be feeling so angry, excited etc that you find it difficult to control yourself
Sense.TRAN: 〔由于气愤﹑激动等而〕失去控制﹔忘形
Sense.EXAMPLE: The poor girl was almost beside herself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个可怜的女孩快要气疯了。

GramExa.PROPFORM: be beside yourself with anger/excitement/rage etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mom and Dad will be beside themselves with worry.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸和妈妈会担心死的。

Sense.DEF: to not be directly connected with the main subject or problem that you are talking about
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s very charming, but that’s beside the point.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他很有魅力﹐但那是题外话了。

Sense.DEF: used when adding another reason
Sense.EXAMPLE: I need the money. And besides, when I agree to do something, I do it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我需要这笔钱﹐而且﹐我一旦答应做什么事情就会做到。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In written English, people do not usually use besides as a sentence adverb. They start a sentence with the more formal moreover instead
F2NBox.TRAN: 在书面英语中﹐人们一般不用besides 作句子副词﹐而是用较为正式的moreover来引导句子
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Moreover , smoking is linked with heart disease and strokes.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 此外﹐吸烟还与心脏病和中风有关联。

Sense.DEF: in addition to someone or something else that you are mentioning
Sense.EXAMPLE: The area has stunning scenery, beautiful beaches, and much more besides.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个地方有迷人的景色﹑美丽的沙滩﹐除此之外还有很多很多。
Sense.EXAMPLE: People choose jobs for other reasons besides money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们择业除了钱之外还有别的考虑。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Besides myself, the only English people there were Keith and Doreen.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 除了我﹐那儿只有基思和多琳是英国人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Besides being heartbroken, she felt foolish.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 除了伤心之外﹐她还觉得自己很蠢。

Sense.DEF: to surround a city or castle with military force until the people inside let you take control
Sense.EXAMPLE: In April 655, Osman’s palace was besieged by rebels.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公元655年4月﹐奥斯曼的宫殿遭到叛军围攻。

Sense.DEF: if people, worries, thoughts etc besiege you, you are surrounded by them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Miller was besieged by press photographers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 米勒被摄影记者团团围住。

Sense.DEF: to receive a very large number of letters, requests etc
Sense.TRAN: 被大量的信件/要求/请求等所困扰

Sense.DEF: to spoil the good opinion that people have of someone
to love or want someone or something so much that you cannot think or behave sensibly
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s completely besotted with her.
