Sense.DEF: a high military rank in the British army, or the person who has this rank
a high army rank or someone holding this rank
a thief, especially one of a group that attacks people in mountains or forests
shining strongly, or with plenty of light
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her eyes were hurting from the bright lights.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 明亮的光线刺痛了她的眼睛。
Sense.EXAMPLE: bright sunshine
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 灿烂的阳光
Sense.EXAMPLE: a large bright room
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 明亮的大房间

Sense.DEF: if the weather is bright, the sun is shining and there is a lot of light
Sense.EXAMPLE: The weather was bright and sunny.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 天气晴朗﹐阳光明媚。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bright autumn day
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个阳光明媚的秋日

Sense.DEF: intelligent and able to learn things quickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was an exceptionally bright child.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是个特别聪明的孩子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bright ambitious young man
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个聪明﹑有抱负的年轻人

Sense.TRAN: 聪明点子〔有时作讽刺用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Whose bright idea was this?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是谁出的好点子？
Sense.EXAMPLE: He is constantly coming up with bright ideas for making money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他老是会想出些赚钱的好法子。

Sense.DEF: bright colours are strong and easy to see
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bright red jumper
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一件鲜红色的套头毛衣
Sense.EXAMPLE: I never wear bright colours.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从来不穿鲜艳的颜色。

Sense.DEF: happy and full of energy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her voice was bright and cheerful.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的声音很欢快。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She gave him a bright smile.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她给了他一个灿烂的微笑。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He looked up at me with bright eyes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他抬起头来，用明亮的眼睛看着我。

Sense.DEF: if the future looks bright, you think that something will be successful
Sense.EXAMPLE: The school’s future now looks very bright.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在﹐这所学校的前途看起来非常光明。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m sure the company has a bright future now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我确信公司现在前途光明。

Sense.DEF: very intelligent and full of energy
to see the good points in a situation that seems to be bad
Sense.TRAN: 看到光明的一面﹐抱乐观态度
Sense.EXAMPLE: Come on, try to look on the bright side.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好啦﹐多往好处想想吧。

Sense.DEF: very early in the morning
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was up bright and early, keen to get started.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一大早就起来了﹐急着开始工作。

Sense.DEF: someone who says or does something that they think is intelligent but is really wrong or stupid
Sense.EXAMPLE: Some bright spark thought the building was on fire and called the fire brigade.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不知道哪个聪明人以为大楼着火了﹐就叫来了消防队。

Sense.DEF: happy and confident
happy and full of energy
the interesting exciting life in a big city
Sense.TRAN: 大城市五光十色的生活
Sense.EXAMPLE: She missed the bright lights of London.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她怀念伦敦丰富多彩的生活。

Sense.DEF: an event or a period of time that is more pleasant when everything else is unpleasant
Sense.TRAN: 亮点〔指在其他事情都很糟糕时的一件令人高兴的事或一段快乐的时光〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The only bright spot of the weekend was our trip to the theatre.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个周末唯一高兴的事就是我们去看了场戏。

Exponent.DEF: shining strongly
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The sunshine was very bright.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 阳光非常灿烂。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the bright light of the torch
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 手电筒明亮的光

Exponent.DEF: very bright
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Photographs fade if they are exposed to strong sunlight.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 照片如果暴露在强烈的阳光下就会褪色。

Exponent.DEF: extremely bright, especially in a way that seems good
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The garden was full of brilliant autumn sunshine.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 花园里洒满明媚的秋日阳光。

Exponent.DEF: a dazzling light is so bright that it hurts your eyes and you cannot look at it
Exponent.TRAN: 使人目眩的﹐令人眼花的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: dazzling headlights
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 晃眼的车头灯

Exponent.DEF: a blinding light is very bright and makes you unable to see for a short time after you have looked at it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: There was a sudden blinding light, followed by the sound of a huge explosion.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 突然出现一道刺眼的光﹐紧接着是一声爆炸的巨响。

Exponent.DEF: a harsh light is bright and unpleasant
Exponent.EXAMPLE: In the harsh light of the kitchen, she looked older than she was.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 厨房刺眼的灯光让她显老。

Exponent.DEF: if the light is good in a place where you are working, it is bright enough for you to see what you are doing
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The light wasn’t good enough to read.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这光线看书不够亮。

Exponent.DEF: full of light
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I wish the room was a bit brighter.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我希望这房间的光线再亮一些。

Exponent.DEF: bright because there are big windows
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The dining room was light and airy.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 饭厅明亮又通风。

Exponent.DEF: bright because there are plenty of electric lights
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Try to park in a well-lit place.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 最好把车停在灯光明亮的地方。

Sense.DEF: to make something lighter or brighter
Sense.EXAMPLE: Use blonde highlights to brighten your hair.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用点金色的挑染﹐让你的发色明亮起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The morning sunshine brightened up the room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 清晨的阳光照亮了房间。

Sense.DEF: to make something more colourful or attractive
Sense.EXAMPLE: She bought some flowers to brighten the room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她买了一些花﹐把房间装点得亮丽生色。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I want to brighten the place up a bit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想把这个地方装饰一下。

Sense.DEF: to make something more enjoyable, exciting, or interesting
Sense.EXAMPLE: His letter brightened my day.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的来信让我开心了一天。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I felt I needed something to brighten up my life.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我感到我需要什么东西来刺激一下我的生活。

Sense.DEF: to shine more strongly, or become brighter in colour
Sense.EXAMPLE: The stage lights brightened to reveal a street scene.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 舞台灯光亮起﹐现出一道街景。

Sense.DEF: if the weather brightens, the sun begins to shine and it becomes lighter
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sky brightened after lunch.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 午饭后﹐天空放晴了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s hope the weather brightens up later.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 希望过会儿天气会转晴。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It brightened up a bit in the afternoon.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到了下午﹐天色亮了一点。

Sense.DEF: to become happier or more excited
Sense.EXAMPLE: His eyes brightened when we started talking about money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一谈到钱﹐他的眼睛就亮了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She brightened up a bit when she saw us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她看到我们便开心了一点。

Sense.DEF:
car
headlight s
when they are shining as brightly as possible
Sense.EXAMPLE: driving with your brights on
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 打开车头灯行驶

Sense.DEF: very good
Sense.EXAMPLE: It sounds really brill!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 听上去非常不错！

Sense.DEF: a very high level of intelligence or skill
Sense.EXAMPLE: He is also respected for his brilliance as an artist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的艺术才华同样被人尊敬。

Sense.DEF: very great brightness
Sense.EXAMPLE: The stars glittered with the brilliance of jewels.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 群星闪耀﹐犹如一颗颗璀璨的宝石。

Sense.DEF: brilliant light or colour is very bright and strong
Sense.TRAN: 明亮的﹐光辉夺目的﹐灿烂的
Sense.EXAMPLE: She closed her eyes against the brilliant light .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 强烈的光线下﹐她闭起了眼睛。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We sat outside in the brilliant sunshine .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们坐在外面﹐沐浴在灿烂的阳光下。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was dressed in brilliant white.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她穿着一身耀眼的白色。

Sense.DEF: extremely clever or skilful
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think that’s a brilliant idea .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得那是个绝妙的主意。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a brilliant performance
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 精湛的演出
Sense.EXAMPLE: a brilliant young musician
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位才华横溢的年轻音乐家

Sense.DEF: excellent
Sense.EXAMPLE: The film was absolutely brilliant .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部电影极为出色。

Sense.DEF: very successful
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had a long and brilliant career .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的事业长久而辉煌。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The project was a brilliant success .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个项目非常成功。

Sense.DEF: an oily substance that was used in the past on men’s hair
a ball of wire filled with soap, which is used for cleaning pans
Sense.TRAN: 〔内有肥皂的〕布瑞罗洁锅球[钢丝球]

Sense.DEF: the bottom part of a hat that sticks out to protect you from sun and rain
Sense.EXAMPLE: an old straw hat with a broad brim
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一顶旧的宽边草帽

Sense.DEF: the top edge of a container
Sense.EXAMPLE: She filled each glass to the brim.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她把每个杯子都斟得满满的。

GramExa.GLOSS: completely full
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The cup was filled to the brim with coffee.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 杯子里倒了满满的一杯咖啡。

Sense.DEF: if your eyes brim with tears, or if tears brim from your eyes, you start to cry

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her eyes brimmed with tears.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她双眼噙满泪水。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Her tears brimmed over again as she started to speak.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她一张口说话﹐泪水再次夺眶而出。

Sense.DEF: to have a lot of a particular thing, quality, or emotion
Sense.TRAN: 充满〔某种事物﹑品质或情感〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The flowerbeds were brimming over with flowers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 花坛里开满了鲜花。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He seemed to be brimming with confidence .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他好像充满信心。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rob was just brimming with enthusiasm.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗布满腔热情。

Sense.DEF: very full of something
Sense.TRAN: 满到边的﹔溢出的﹔充满的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The team is brimful of confidence after their win last week.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 上个星期获胜以后﹐这支球队充满了信心。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a glass brimful of red wine
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 斟满红葡萄酒的杯子

Sense.DEF: a brindled animal is brown and has marks or bands of another colour
water that contains a lot of salt and is used for preserving food
Sense.EXAMPLE: fish pickled in brine
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用盐水腌制的鱼

Sense.DEF: sea water

Subsense.DEF: to take something or someone with you to the place where you are now, or to the place you are talking about
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Did you bring an umbrella?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你带伞了吗？
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It was the first time Joey had ever brought a girl home .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那是乔伊第一次带女孩子回家。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: They brought news of further fighting along the border.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们带来消息﹐说边境再次发生了冲突。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Is it OK if I bring some friends to the party?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我带几个朋友来参加聚会行吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: For some reason, Jesse had brought a tape recorder with him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不知为什么﹐杰西带了一台盒式录音机来。

Subsense.DEF: to get something for someone and take it to them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can you bring me another beer?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你再给我拿一杯啤酒好吗？
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Robert asked the waiter to bring him the check.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗伯特叫服务生给他拿账单来。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: While she was in prison, friends used to bring her books.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在狱中时经常有朋友给她带书去。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He expects me to bring everything to him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他指望我什么东西都给他带去。

Subsense.DEF: to make a particular situation exist, or cause a particular feeling
Subsense.TRAN: 引起〔某种情况或情感〕﹐造成﹐导致
Subsense.EXAMPLE: efforts to bring peace to the region
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 给这个地区带来和平的种种努力
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The strikes are expected to bring chaos.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 预计罢工会造成混乱。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The senator’s speech brought an angry response from Civil Rights groups.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那名参议员的话引起了一些民权组织的愤怒。

Subsense.DEF: to cause someone or something to reach a particular state or condition

GramExa.PROPFORM: bring sth to an end/a close/a halt/a conclusion
GramExa.GLOSS: make something stop
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The trial was swiftly brought to an end.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 庭审匆匆就结束了。

Subsense.EXAMPLE:
It was the war that first brought him to power
make him have power over a country
.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 是战争首次将他推上权力宝座。
Subsense.EXAMPLE:
So far the US has been unable to bring him to justice
make him be punished for his actions
.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 至今美国还是未能将他绳之以法。
Subsense.EXAMPLE:
Bring the sauce to the boil
heat it until it boils
.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把调味汁煮沸。
Subsense.EXAMPLE:
The country had been brought to its knees
caused to be in such a bad condition that it is almost impossible to continue
.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个国家已经陷入瘫痪。

Sense.DEF: to make something move in a particular direction

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Bring your arm up slowly until it’s level with your shoulder.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 慢慢举起手臂到齐肩的高度。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The storm brought the old oak tree crashing down.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 暴风雨把这棵老橡树刮倒了。

Sense.DEF: if something brings people to a place, it makes them go there
Sense.EXAMPLE: The discovery of gold brought thousands of people to the Transvaal.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 黄金的发现把成千上万的人引到了德兰士瓦。

GramExa.GLOSS: used to ask why someone is in a particular place
GramExa.EXAMPLE: What brings you here on a night like this?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样的晚上﹐是什么风把你吹来的？

Sense.DEF: to make something available for people to use, have, enjoy etc
Sense.TRAN: 带来〔可供人们使用﹑拥有或享受的东西〕﹔使得到﹔创造
Sense.EXAMPLE: The expansion of state education brought new and wider opportunities for working class children.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公立教育的普及为工人阶层出身的儿童带来了更多新的机会。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The government is launching a new initiative to bring jobs to deprived areas.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府正在出台一个新的方案﹐为贫困地区创造就业机会。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s a good sign – let’s hope it will bring us some luck.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是一个好征兆——但愿会给我们带来好运。

Sense.DEF: if a period of time brings a particular event or situation, the event or situation happens during that time
Sense.EXAMPLE: The 1930s brought unemployment and economic recession.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 20世纪30年代带来了失业和经济衰退。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Who knows what the future will bring?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 谁知道未来会发生什么？

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring charges/a lawsuit/a court case/a prosecution/a claim (against sb)
Sense.DEF: to begin a court case in order to try to prove that someone has done something wrong or is legally responsible for something wrong
Sense.TRAN: 起诉（某人）﹐对（某人）提起诉讼
Sense.EXAMPLE: Survivors of the fire later brought a billion-dollar lawsuit against the company.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 火灾的幸存者后来对该公司提起诉讼﹐索赔十亿美元。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police say they are planning to bring charges against him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方说他们准备起诉他。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring a smile to sb’s lips/face
Sense.DEF: to make someone smile
Sense.TRAN: 使某人唇边/脸上现出笑意
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her words brought a sudden smile to his lips.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的话使他唇角突然上扬露出笑意。

Sense.DEF: to make someone start to cry
Sense.EXAMPLE: The pain brought tears to his eyes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他痛得眼泪都出来了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring the total/number/score etc to sth
Sense.DEF: used when saying what the new total etc is
Sense.TRAN: 使总数/数字/得分等变成…
Sense.EXAMPLE: This brings the total to 46.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样一来，总数就变成46了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: cannot/could not bring yourself to do sth
Sense.DEF: to feel unable to do something because it would upset you or someone else too much
Sense.TRAN: 〔因为会让自己或某人非常难过而〕无法使自己做某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: She still can’t bring herself to talk about it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她还是难以开口说这件事。

Sense.DEF: used when saying that something is the next thing that you want to talk about
Sense.TRAN: 把…带入新话题﹐使…接下去谈到

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This brings me to the main point of today’s meeting.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 由此﹐我要谈到今天会议的重点。

Sense.DEF: if a programme is brought to you by a particular television or radio company, they broadcast it or make it
Sense.TRAN: 向…播出﹔为…制作〔电视或广播节目〕

GramExa.PROPFORM: sth is brought to you by sb
GramExa.EXAMPLE: This programme is brought to you by the BBC.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 本节目由英国广播公司为您播出。

Sense.DEF: to use something, for example your power, authority, or your knowledge, in a way that will have a big effect on something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The full force of the law was brought to bear on anyone who criticized the government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 凡是批评政府的﹐都要受到法律最严厉的惩罚。

Sense.DEF: to earn the money that your family needs to live

Exponent.DEF: to take something or someone to the place where you are now, or the place where you are going
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Have you brought your ticket with you?
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 你带了票吗？
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He asked his father if he could bring a friend to stay.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他问他父亲是否可以带个朋友来住。

Exponent.DEF: to move something to another place, or help someone go to another place
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I took a book with me to read on the train.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我带了本书在火车上看。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He was taken to hospital by ambulance.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被救护车送往医院。

Exponent.DEF: to go to another place and come back with something or someone
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I went upstairs to get my jacket.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我上楼去拿外套。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Joseph told me to fetch the doctor, so I ran to the village.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 约瑟夫叫我去找医生﹐于是我向村子跑去。

Sense.DEF: to make something happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: How can we bring about a change in attitudes?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们如何才能改变态度？
Sense.EXAMPLE: A huge amount of environmental damage has been brought about by the destruction of the rain forests.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毁掉热带雨林给环境造成了巨大的破坏。

Sense.DEF: to take someone or something with you when you go somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’re welcome to bring along a friend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 欢迎你带一个朋友来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve brought some pictures along to show you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我带来一些照片给你看。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring the conversation around/round to sth
Sense.DEF: to deliberately and gradually introduce a new subject into a conversation
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll try to bring the conversation around to the subject of money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我会设法把话题转到钱上来。

Sense.DEF: to make someone become conscious again
Sense.EXAMPLE: I slapped his face a couple of times to try to bring him round.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在他脸上拍了几下﹐想让他苏醒过来。

Sense.DEF: to manage to persuade someone to do something or to agree with you
Sense.EXAMPLE: She won’t listen to me. Let’s see if Sue can bring her round.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不听我劝﹐我们看看休能不能说服她。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m sure I can bring him around to our point of view.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我相信我可以说服他同意我们的观点。

Sense.DEF: to bring someone or something to someone’s house
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll bring the books around tomorrow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我明天把书带过来。

Sense.DEF: to start to use something again that was used in the past
Sense.EXAMPLE: The city council has decided to bring back the old electric trams.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 市政会决定恢复运营老式电车。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bringing back the death penalty has done absolutely nothing to reduce crime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 恢复死刑对减少犯罪根本无济于事。

Sense.DEF: to make you remember something
Sense.TRAN: 使想起某事﹐使回忆起某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: The trip brought back a lot of happy memories .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次旅行唤起了许多美好的回忆。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Seeing those pictures on TV brought it all back to me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看到电视上的那些画面﹐我想起了过去的一切。

Sense.DEF: to take something or someone with you when you come back from somewhere

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t forget to bring something back for the kids.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 别忘了给孩子们带点东西回来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you’re going to the store, could you bring me back a six-pack?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你如果去商店﹐帮我带一提六罐装的啤酒回来好吗？

Sense.DEF: to return someone to their previous job or position of authority
Sense.TRAN: 使重返岗位﹐使恢复原职
Sense.EXAMPLE: Following their latest defeat, soccer fans are urging the club to bring back the former manager.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 球队最近一次比赛失利以后﹐球迷们就敦促俱乐部把前任主教练请回来。

Sense.DEF: if something that is said brings you back to a particular subject, it is connected with that subject, so you will start talking about it again
Sense.EXAMPLE: This brings us back to the question of funding.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这又使我们回到了资金的问题上。

Sense.DEF: to reduce something to a lower level
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government hopes these measures will help to bring down inflation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府希望这些措施有助于减轻通货膨胀。

Sense.DEF: to fly a plane down to the ground
Sense.EXAMPLE: The pilot managed to bring the plane down safely.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞行员终于成功地使飞机安全降落。

Sense.DEF: to make a plane, bird, or animal fall to the ground by shooting at it
Sense.TRAN: 击落〔飞机或鸟〕﹔击倒〔动物〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: A bomber had been brought down by anti-aircraft fire.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一架轰炸机被防空炮火击落了。

Sense.DEF: to force a government or ruler to stop ruling a country
Sense.EXAMPLE: a crisis that could bring down the government
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 可使政府下台的一场危机

Sense.DEF: to make someone fall over
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was brought down by the goalkeeper and awarded a penalty.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被守门员绊倒﹐获得一个罚点球的机会。

Sense.DEF: to make something bad happen to someone, especially to yourself or to people connected with you
Sense.TRAN: 使〔坏事〕发生在…﹐使…落在〔某人自己或亲属〕身上
Sense.EXAMPLE: His recklessness brought down disaster on the whole family.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的鲁莽给全家带来了灾难。

Sense.DEF: to produce something or make it appear
Sense.EXAMPLE: a tragic love affair that brought forth only pain
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只带来痛苦的一场情爱悲剧

Sense.DEF: to change an arrangement so that something happens sooner

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The meeting’s been brought forward to Thursday.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 会议已被提前到星期四举行。

Sense.DEF: to officially introduce plans etc for people to discuss
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government has brought forward new proposals to tackle the problem of increasing crime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府提出了解决犯罪率上升问题的新计划。

Sense.DEF: to record the result of a calculation so that it can be used in a further calculation
Sense.EXAMPLE: The balance brought forward is £21,765.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 结转余额是21,765 英镑。

Sense.DEF: to introduce a new law
Sense.TRAN: 推行﹐引入﹐提出〔新的法律〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Harsh anti-Trade Union laws were brought in in the early 1980s.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 20世纪80年代初期推行了严厉的反工会法。

Sense.DEF: to ask someone to become involved in a discussion or situation
Sense.TRAN: 请…参与〔讨论或某件事情〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d like to bring in Doctor Hall here and ask him his views.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想请霍尔博士上来﹐征求一下他的看法。

GramExa.PROPFORM: bring sb in to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The police were brought in to investigate the matter.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方已介入调查此案。

Sense.DEF: to earn a particular amount or produce a particular amount of profit
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sale of the house only brought in about £45,000.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卖房子只赚了45,000英镑左右。

Sense.DEF: to attract customers to a shop or business
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve got to bring in more business if we want the restaurant to survive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 餐馆若要生存下去﹐我们必须吸引更多的生意。

Sense.DEF: to say officially in a law court whether someone is guilty or not guilty of a crime
Sense.EXAMPLE: The jury brought in a verdict of not guilty.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 陪审团作出无罪裁决。

Sense.DEF: to cause someone or something to be in a particular situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most of the land has now been brought into cultivation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大部分土地现在都被用于耕种。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The work brought me into contact with a lot of very interesting people.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个工作使我能接触到许多非常有趣的人。

Sense.DEF: to make someone become involved in a discussion or situation
Sense.TRAN: 使参与〔讨论或某件事情〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government is trying to bring teachers into the debate on education.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府设法让教师参与讨论教育议题。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There is a danger that this could bring other countries into the war.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样有可能会把其他国家卷进这场战争。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in doing something difficult
Sense.TRAN: 使成功﹔圆满完成〔困难的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: They managed to bring off the most daring jewellery robbery in history.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们精心实施了史上最大胆的珠宝抢劫案。

Sense.DEF: to make something bad or unpleasant happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: Stress can bring on an asthma attack.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 精神压力会引起哮喘发作。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What’s brought this on? Have I upset you somehow?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 怎么啦？是不是我有什么事惹你生气了？

Sense.DEF: to help someone to improve or make progress
Sense.EXAMPLE: Teachers have to bring on the bright children and at the same time give extra help to those who need it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 教师需要培养聪明的孩子﹐同时给予有需要的学生更多的帮助。

Sense.DEF: to make plants or crops grow faster
Sense.TRAN: 促进〔植物或农作物〕生长
Sense.EXAMPLE: Keeping the young plants in a greenhouse will help bring them on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在温室培养幼苗可以促进它们生长。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you are prepared and willing to deal with something bad that is likely to happen
Sense.TRAN: 就让它来吧〔表示已经准备好面对坏事〕

Sense.DEF: to make something unpleasant happen to someone
Sense.TRAN: 引起﹐招来﹐惹来〔不愉快的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: You have brought disaster on the whole village!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你给整个村子招来了灾祸！

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ve got no sympathy for him – he’s brought this all on himself!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一点也不同情他——他这是自作自受！

Sense.DEF: if something brings you onto a particular subject, it is a good time for you to start talking about it
Sense.EXAMPLE: This brings me onto the question of pay rises.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 借此机会﹐我再谈谈加薪的问题。

Sense.DEF: to make something easier to see, taste, notice etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The spices really bring out the flavour of the meat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些香料果然能把肉的味道全带出来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Fatherhood seems to have brought out the caring side of him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当了父亲以后﹐他关心体贴的一面似乎都表现了出来。

Sense.DEF: to produce something that will be sold to the public
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s bringing out a new album next month.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下个月他将推出一张新专辑。

Sense.DEF: to take something out of a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jenny opened the cupboard and brought out a couple of bottles.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 珍妮打开碗橱﹐拿出了几个瓶子。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring out the best/worst in sb
Sense.DEF: to make someone behave in the best or worst way that they can
Sense.TRAN: 把某人最好的一面显露出来/把某人最坏的一面暴露出来
Sense.EXAMPLE: Alcohol just brings out the worst in her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 喝酒把她最坏的一面暴露了出来。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel more confident and able to talk to people
Sense.EXAMPLE: Changing schools has really brought her out of herself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 转学后﹐她变得活泼自信多了。

Sense.DEF: if something brings you out in spots, it makes them appear on your skin
Sense.EXAMPLE: Any foods containing wheat bring him out in a rash.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他吃了任何含小麦的食物都会出疹子。

Sense.DEF: to help someone to successfully deal with a very difficult event or period of time
Sense.TRAN: 使脱离（险境）﹔使渡过（难关）
Sense.EXAMPLE: Both my children have brought me through extremely difficult times since my husband died.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 丈夫过世以后﹐我的两个孩子帮助我度过了特别艰难的时期。

Sense.DEF: to arrange for people to meet and do something together
Sense.EXAMPLE: We brought together researchers from three different universities to work on the project.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们联合了三所大学的研究人员从事这个项目。

Sense.DEF: to make people have a better relationship or feel closer to each other
Sense.TRAN: 使联合起来﹐使团结起来
Sense.EXAMPLE: Any attack by a foreign power will inevitably bring the people of a country together.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 任何外来侵略都必定会使全国人民团结起来。

Sense.DEF: to mention a subject or start to talk about it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why did you have to bring up the subject of money?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你为什么一定要提钱这个话题？

Sense.DEF: to look after and influence a child until he or she is grown up
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was brought up by his grandparents.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是由祖父母抚养长大的。

GramExa.PROPFORM: bring sb up to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: In my day, children were brought up to respect the law.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 在我那个时代，孩子们从小就被教导要守法。

GramExa.PROPFORM: be brought up (as) a Catholic/Muslim etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I was brought up a Catholic.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从小受天主教的教育。

Sense.DEF: to make something appear on a computer screen
Sense.TRAN: 把…调出来〔使显示在计算机屏幕上〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can you bring up the list of candidates again?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你把候选人名单再调出来好吗？

Sense.DEF: if you bring food up, it comes back up from your stomach and out of your mouth
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had a sandwich for lunch and promptly brought it up again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我午饭吃了个三明治﹐可马上就吐了。

Sense.DEF: to charge someone with a particular crime and make them go to a court to be judged

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was brought up before a magistrate, charged with dangerous driving.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因为危险驾驶遭起诉﹐受到治安法官的传讯。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bring sb up short/with a start
Sense.DEF: to surprise someone and make them suddenly stop talking or doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her question brought me up short.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的问题让我一下子顿住了。

Sense.DEF: a situation when you are almost in a new situation, usually a bad one
Sense.TRAN: （某事物的）边缘〔一般指坏情况〕

GramExa.PROPFORM: on the brink of death/disaster/war etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: In October 1962 the world seemed on the brink of nuclear war.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1962年10月﹐世界似乎处于核战争的边缘。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company had huge debts and was on the brink of collapse.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司背负巨额债务﹐已濒临破产。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: managers who have taken their companies to the brink of disaster
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 使公司面临灾难的经理们

GramExa.EXAMPLE:
He will go down in history as the leader who pulled us back from the brink
saved us from disaster
.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他作为救我们于危难之中的领导人将名垂青史。

Sense.DEF: to make someone start doing crazy or extreme things
the edge of a very high place such as a cliff
a method of gaining political advantage by pretending that you are willing to do something very dangerous
briny water is water that contains a lot of salt
the sea
energy and confidence
a type of sweet bread made with flour, eggs, and butter

a block of pressed coal dust, to burn in a fire or
barbecue
quick and full of energy
Sense.TRAN: 轻快的﹔活泼的﹔精力充沛的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a brisk walk
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 轻快的行走
Sense.EXAMPLE: They set off at a brisk pace .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们踏着轻快的步伐上路了。

Sense.DEF: quick, practical, and showing that you want to get things done quickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her tone of voice is brisk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的语气干脆利落。

Sense.DEF: trade or business that is brisk is very busy, with a lot of products being sold
Sense.EXAMPLE: The public bar was already doing a brisk trade .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公众酒吧区生意已经很红火了。

Sense.DEF: weather that is brisk is cold and clear
meat from the chest of an animal, especially a cow
a short stiff hair that feels rough
Sense.EXAMPLE: His chin was covered with bristles.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他满下巴都是胡茬。

Sense.DEF: a short stiff hair, wire etc that forms part of a brush
to behave in a way that shows you are very angry or annoyed

GramExa.EXAMPLE: John pushed back his chair, bristling with rage.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰把椅子往后一推﹐暴跳起来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He bristled at her rudeness.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的无礼使他火冒三丈。

Sense.DEF: if an animal’s hair bristles, it stands up stiffly because the animal is afraid or angry
Sense.TRAN: 〔动物因惊慌或愤怒而毛发〕竖起﹐耸起

Sense.DEF: to have a lot of something, or be full of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a battleship bristling with guns
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 布满大炮的战舰

Sense.DEF: bristly hair is short and stiff
a bristly part of your body has short stiff hairs on it
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bristly chin
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 胡子拉碴的下巴

Sense.DEF: someone from Britain
a set of prizes given every year at a public ceremony to the best British pop and rock musicians
Sense.TRAN: 〔每年颁给英国最佳流行和摇滚音乐家的〕全英音乐奖

Sense.DEF: trousers
relating to Britain or its people
Sense.EXAMPLE: the British government
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国政府
Sense.EXAMPLE: a British-born scientist
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一名英国出生的科学家

Sense.DEF: people from Britain
someone from Britain
the time one hour ahead of Greenwich Mean Time that is used in Britain from late March to late October
Sense.TRAN: 英国夏令时间〔每年3月底至10月底使用﹐比格林尼治平均时间早一小时〕

Sense.DEF: someone from Britain
Sense.EXAMPLE: the ancient Britons
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古英国人
Sense.EXAMPLE: the first Briton to win a medal
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 第一位获奖章的英国人

Sense.DEF: hard but easily broken
Sense.EXAMPLE: The branches were dry and brittle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那些树枝又干又脆。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Joanna was diagnosed as having brittle bones.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔安娜被诊断为骨质疏松。

Sense.DEF: a situation, relationship, or feeling that is brittle is easily damaged or destroyed
Sense.EXAMPLE: He spoke with the brittle confidence of someone who, underneath, was very worried.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他说话的时候带着一种一戳击破的自信，因为他内心非常焦虑。

Sense.DEF: showing no warm feelings
Sense.EXAMPLE: a brittle laugh
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 冷淡的笑

Sense.DEF: your brother
a way of greeting a friend
to mention a subject that may be embarrassing or unpleasant or cause an argument
Sense.TRAN: 提及〔可能令人尴尬﹑不快或引起争论的〕话题/问题/事情等
Sense.EXAMPLE: I broached the subject of his past.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我提起了他的过去。

Sense.DEF:
to open a bottle or
barrel
containing wine, beer etc
Sense.TRAN: 开启〔装葡萄酒﹑啤酒等的瓶或桶〕

Sense.DEF: a road, river, or part of someone’s body etc that is broad is wide
Sense.EXAMPLE: We went along a broad passage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们走在一条宽阔的走廊上。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was six feet tall, with broad shoulders.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他身高六英尺﹐肩膀宽阔。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The room is three metres long and two metres broad.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个房间长三米﹐宽两米。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually say wide rather than broad
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐人们一般说wide﹐而不说 broad
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: a wide river/street/corridor
They sell a wide range of bikes.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们销售各式各样的自行车。
F2NBox.EXPL: Broad , however, is always used when describing someone's shoulders or back.
F2NBox.TRAN: 但形容某人的肩膀或背部时﹐总是用broad。

Sense.DEF: including many different kinds of things or people
Sense.EXAMPLE: The show aims to reach the broadest possible audience.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个节目力图覆盖尽可能广泛的观众群。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Students here study a broad range of subjects.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这里的学生所学的科目范围很广。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Private pension schemes fall into two broad categories.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 个人养老金计划分两大类。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a party which lacks a broad base of political support
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 缺乏广泛政治基础的党派
Sense.EXAMPLE: The play is a comedy, in the broadest sense of the word .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部剧从广义上说是喜剧。

Sense.DEF: concerning the main ideas or parts of something rather than all the details
Sense.EXAMPLE: The client should understand, in broad terms , the likely cost of the case.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当事人对这一诉讼可能需要的费用应该有个大致了解。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The members were in broad agreement.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 成员的意见大致相同。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll give you a broad outline of the plan.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我来给你讲讲大体的计划。

Sense.DEF: covering a large area
Sense.EXAMPLE: a broad expanse of water
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一片辽阔的水域

Sense.DEF:
a broad
accent
clearly shows where you come from
Sense.EXAMPLE: a broad Scottish accent
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 浓重的苏格兰口音

Sense.DEF: a big smile
Sense.EXAMPLE: Abby came in with a broad smile on her face.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 阿比满面笑容地走了进来。

Sense.DEF: if something, especially a crime, happens in broad daylight, it happens in the daytime and in public
Sense.TRAN: 在大白天﹔在光天化日之下
Sense.EXAMPLE: The attack happened in broad daylight, in one of the busiest parts of town.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 袭击事件就发生在光天化日之下﹐还在镇上最繁华的地段之一。

Sense.DEF:
a
hint
suggestion
that is very clear and easy to understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: In June he gave a broad hint that he might retire.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 六月份他曾明确暗示过他可能会退休。

Sense.DEF: an organization that contains a wide range of opinions
Sense.TRAN: 容纳多种观点的组织﹐广纳众议的机构
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Labour Party has to be a broad church.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 工党必须是一个广纳众议的政党。

Sense.DEF: broad humour is rather rude or concerned with sex

having large or fat
hip s
an offensive word for a woman
Sense.TRAN: 婆娘﹐娘儿们〔对成年女子的蔑称〕

Sense.DEF:
a type of road in Britain that is smaller than an
A-road
Sense.TRAN: B级公路〔英国的一种公路﹐小于A级公路〕

Sense.DEF: a system of sending radio signals, that allows several messages to be sent at the same time
a system of connecting computers to the Internet and moving information, such as messages or pictures, at a very high speed
Sense.TRAN: 宽带〔连接计算机和因特网﹐用于高速传输信息的系统〕

Sense.DEF: a round pale green bean
dealing only with the main parts of something, and not with the details
Sense.TRAN: 粗线条的﹐粗略的﹐概括的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a broadbrush strategy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 粗略的策略

Sense.DEF: a programme on the radio or on television
Sense.EXAMPLE: a news broadcast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一档新闻节目
Sense.EXAMPLE:
CNN’s live broadcast of the trial
sent out at the same time as the events are happening
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 美国有线电视新闻网对这场庭审的现场直播

Sense.DEF: to send out radio or television programmes
Sense.EXAMPLE: The interview was broadcast live across Europe.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次采访向整个欧洲进行了现场直播。

Sense.DEF: to tell something to a lot of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t broadcast the fact that he lost his job.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要到处去散布他丢了工作的事。

Sense.DEF: someone who speaks on radio or television programmes
Sense.EXAMPLE: a well-known broadcaster
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位著名的播音员

Sense.DEF: a company that sends out television or radio programmes
Sense.EXAMPLE: the British broadcaster Channel 4
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国第四频道电视台

Sense.DEF: the business of making television and radio programmes
Sense.TRAN: 〔电视或电台的〕广播工作﹔广播业
Sense.EXAMPLE: a career in broadcasting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 广播事业

Sense.DEF: to increase something such as your knowledge, experience, or range of activities
Sense.TRAN: 增长〔知识或经验〕﹔扩大〔活动范围〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The course helps school-leavers broaden their knowledge of the world of work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这门课程有助于毕业生增加对职场的了解。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
I’d like to work abroad to broaden my horizons
learn, experience, or attempt new things
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想去国外工作﹐开阔眼界。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Travel broadens the mind
helps you to understand and accept other people’s beliefs, customs etc
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅行使人胸襟开阔。

Sense.DEF: to affect or include more people or things, or to make something affect or include more people or things
Sense.TRAN: （使）扩大〔影响或所包含的范围〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Mates said the party must broaden its appeal to younger voters.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 梅茨先生说该党必须扩大在年轻选民中的影响。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Flynn’s appeal broadened as the campaign continued into the summer months.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 随着这场运动持续到夏季﹐弗林的号召力也扩大了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I want to broaden the discussion to other aspects of the problem.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想将讨论范围扩展到这个问题的其他方面。

Sense.DEF: to make something wider, or to become wider
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mark’s smile broadened.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马克笑得更加灿烂了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The council decided to broaden the pavement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地方议会决定拓宽人行道。

Sense.DEF: if something, especially a river or road, broadens out, it becomes wider
Sense.EXAMPLE: The river broadens out at this point.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 河道在这里开始变宽。

Sense.DEF:
the
long jump
a broadleaved tree or plant has wide leaves rather than leaves shaped like needles

carpet
that is woven in a single wide piece
in a general way, relating to the main facts rather than details
Sense.EXAMPLE: She knows broadly what to expect.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她大致知道会有什么结果。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We reached broadly similar conclusions.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们得出了大致相同的结论。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Broadly speaking , there are four types of champagne.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 香槟大体上分为四种。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Independent films are, broadly defined , movies that appeal to sophisticated audiences.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宽泛地说﹐独立电影是吸引有鉴赏力的观众的电影。

Sense.DEF: to have a big smile on your face that clearly shows that you are happy or amused
including a range of different things or subjects
Sense.EXAMPLE: a broadly based school curriculum
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 全面的学校课程
Sense.EXAMPLE: We invest broadly to lessen the risk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们多方投资﹐以降低风险。

Sense.DEF: willing to respect opinions or behaviour that are very different from your own
Sense.TRAN: 气量大的﹐心胸开阔的﹐能容异己的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her parents were broadminded, tolerant, and liberal.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的父母心胸开阔﹐宽容而开明。

Sense.DEF: a newspaper printed on large sheets of paper, especially a serious newspaper
a strong criticism of someone or something

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府能否顶住其支持者最近的猛烈抨击？

Sense.DEF: an attack in which all the guns on one side of a ship are fired at the same time
with the longest side facing something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I brought the boat in broadside to the beach.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把船侧着拉上海滩。

Sense.DEF: to crash into the side of another vehicle
Sense.TRAN: 撞上〔另一辆车〕的侧面﹐拦腰撞上

Sense.DEF: a heavy sword with a broad flat blade
thick heavy decorative cloth that has a pattern of gold and silver threads

Sense.EXAMPLE: deluxe brocades and satins

Sense.DEF: a green vegetable that has short branch-like stems
a thin book giving information or advertising something

Sense.DEF: a thick strong leather shoe with a pattern in the leather

Sense.EXAMPLE: a new pair of brogues
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一双新拷花皮鞋

Sense.DEF:
an
accent
, especially an Irish or Scottish accent
Sense.TRAN: 口音﹔〔尤指爱尔兰人或苏格兰人说英语时的〕土腔

Sense.DEF:
to cook something under direct heat, or over a flame on a
barbecue

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤鸡

Sense.DEF: to become very hot
Sense.EXAMPLE: We lay broiling in the sun.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们躺在太阳底下都快烤熟了。

Sense.DEF:
a special area of a
stove
, used for cooking food under direct heat
a broiler chicken
a chicken that is suitable to be cooked by broiling
broiling weather, sun etc makes you feel extremely hot
Sense.EXAMPLE: a broiling day
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 酷热的一天

Sense.DEF:
the past tense of
break
having no money
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m fed up with being broke all the time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我受够了老是身无分文。

GramExa.GLOSS: completely broke

Sense.DEF: if a company or business goes broke, it can no longer operate because it has no money
Sense.EXAMPLE: A lot of small businesses went broke in the recession.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济衰退的时候许多小企业都破产了。

Sense.DEF: to take big risks when you try to achieve something
Sense.EXAMPLE: At 2–0 down with ten minutes left, you have to go for broke.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 比赛只剩十分钟的时候还是零比二落后﹐就得豁出去了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: if it ain't broke, don't fix it
Sense.DEF: used to say that you should not try to improve a system, situation etc that is satisfactory
Sense.TRAN: 如果还没坏就不要去修〔指某一制度﹑情况等还过得去﹐就不要设法改进它〕

Sense.DEF:
the past participle of
break
not working properly

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 激光唱机又坏了。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Do you know how the phone got broken
became broken
?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你知道电话是怎么坏掉的吗？

Sense.DEF: in small pieces because it has been hit, dropped etc
Sense.TRAN: 破的﹔破碎的﹔损坏的﹔断裂的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mind the broken glass.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当心碎玻璃。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Wrap it up well so it doesn’t get broken
become broken
in the mail.

Sense.DEF: cracked because you have had an accident

Sense.EXAMPLE: Gibbs had an X-ray, which revealed no broken bones.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉布斯拍了X光片﹐显示没有骨折。

Sense.DEF: interrupted and not continuous

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一条断断续续的白线
Sense.EXAMPLE: a long noisy night of broken sleep

Sense.DEF: extremely weak mentally or physically because you have suffered a lot

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他从战场上回来﹐整个人都垮了。

Sense.DEF: if you speak in broken English, French etc, you speak slowly and make a lot of mistakes because you know only a little of the language
Sense.TRAN: 蹩脚[不流利]的英语/法语等

Sense.DEF:
a family that no longer lives together because the parents have
divorce d
Sense.EXAMPLE: The majority of offenders do not come from broken homes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数犯罪者并非来自破裂家庭。

Sense.DEF: a marriage that has ended because the husband and wife do not live together anymore

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我估计她是伤心过度而死的。

Exponent.DEF: something that is broken has become separated into pieces, for example by being hit or dropped
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The floor was covered in broken glass.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 地板上满是碎玻璃。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: This suitcase is no good – the handle’s broken.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个手提箱没用了﹐提手断了。

Exponent.DEF: if a machine, especially one used by the public, is out of order, it is not working for a temporary period
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤指公共设备﹑机器等〕出故障﹐失灵
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Every phone I tried was out of order.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我试的每个电话都出了故障。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The toilets were all out of order.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有的抽水马桶都坏了。

Exponent.DEF: if a computer system is down, it is not working
Exponent.TRAN: 〔计算机系统〕不能运行的﹐有故障的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The computer system was down all afternoon, so we went home.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 电脑系统整个下午都无法运行﹐所以我们回家去了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The network went down at 11:00 and we lost the whole morning’s work.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 网络11点钟出了故障﹐我们一上午的工作全没了。

Exponent.DEF: used when saying that a car, machine etc does not work properly and you do not know why
Exponent.TRAN: 〔汽车﹑机器等〕出了什么故障[问题]
Exponent.EXAMPLE: There’s something wrong with my car; I think it might be the battery.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的汽车出问题了﹐我觉得可能是电池故障。

Exponent.DEF: used when saying that a car, machine etc is completely broken and cannot be repaired
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’m afraid the bike’s had it.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 恐怕这辆自行车是完蛋了。

Sense.DEF: not working, or in very bad condition

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一辆破卡车

Sense.DEF: extremely sad, especially because someone you love has died or left you

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她离他而去﹐他心都碎了。

Sense.DEF: if you say something brokenly, you speak in short phrases with a lot of pauses, because you are feeling a strong emotion

Sense.DEF:
someone who buys and sells things such as
share s
in companies or foreign money for other people

Sense.DEF: a company of brokers, or the place where they work

an
umbrella
a chemical that is sometimes used in medicine to make people feel calm
a statement that is intended to make someone less angry but which is not effective

Sense.DEF:
a
bronco
affecting the bronchial tubes

Sense.DEF:
a large
dinosaur

a hard metal that is a mixture of

and

a work of art such as a

model of a person
, made of bronze

Sense.DEF:
a

Sense.DEF: made of bronze

Sense.DEF: having the dark reddish brown colour of bronze
the time, between about 6,000 and 4,000 years ago, when bronze was used for making tools, weapons etc

a
medal
made of bronze given to the person who comes third in a race or competition
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bronze medal went to Nool of Estonia.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 铜牌得主是爱沙尼亚的努尔。

Sense.DEF: a piece of jewellery that you fasten to your clothes, usually worn by women
to keep thinking about something that you are worried or upset about
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t sit at home brooding all day.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别整天坐在家里闷闷不乐的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There’s no point brooding over it – she’s gone.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 老是想这件事也没用﹐她都已经走了。

Sense.DEF: if a bird broods, it sits on its eggs to make the young birds break out
a family of young birds all born at the same time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mary has a whole brood of grandchildren.

Sense.DEF: mysterious and threatening

Sense.DEF: looking thoughtful and sad

Sense.DEF:
a
mare

that is kept for breeding

Sense.DEF: silent because you are thinking or worrying about something

a small stream

a bridge in New York that connects Brooklyn with Manhattan. It is a famous

on the New York

shape made by buildings against the sky
. If something is difficult to believe, people sometimes talk about ‘selling the Brooklyn Bridge’, because this is something that is very unlikely to happen.

Sense.DEF: a large brush with a long handle, used for sweeping floors
a large bush with small yellow flowers

a broom with a long handle and thin sticks tied at one end that a

the written abbreviation of 书面缩写= Brothers , used in the names of companies 兄弟公司〔用于公司名称〕

Sense.DEF: soup with meat, rice, or vegetables

Sense.DEF:
a house where men pay to have sex with

GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我得送我弟弟去上学。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
My big brother

has always looked after me.

Sense.DEF: a word meaning a black man, used especially by other black men

Sense.DEF: a male member of a group with the same interests, religion, profession etc as you

Sense.DEF:

Sense.DEF:
a member of a
fraternity

Sense.DEF: soldiers who have fought together in a war
used to show you are annoyed or surprised

Sense.DEF: a feeling of friendship between people

the relationship between brothers

the husband of your sister
the husband of your husband or wife’s sister

Sense.DEF: a carriage used in the past, that had four wheels and a roof and was pulled by a horse

Sense.DEF:
the past tense and past participle of
bring
unnecessary excitement, criticism, or activity – used especially in news reports to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 喧闹﹐嘈杂﹔骚乱〔尤用于新闻报道﹐含贬义〕

Sense.DEF: the part of your face above your eyes and below your hair

GramExa.GLOSS: dry your brow with your hand or a cloth because you are hot or nervous
lines appear on your brow because you are thinking or are worried
GramExa.EXAMPLE: His brow furrowed. ‘I don’t understand,’ he said.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他蹙起了眉头。“我不明白。”他说。

Sense.DEF:
an

a large amount of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: They were drinking beer by the bucket.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们狂饮啤酒。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They made buckets of cash on the deal.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这笔生意他们赚大发了。

Sense.DEF: to cry a lot
if rain comes down in buckets, it is raining very hard
to rain very hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s been bucketing down all day.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 倾盆大雨已下了一整天。

Sense.DEF: a car seat with a high curved back, for one person
a place that sells cheap plane tickets

the official home of the British royal family in London. Since 1995, some parts of the building have been open to tourists. The name of the Palace is sometimes used to mean the officials who are in charge of organizing the Queen's public life
Sense.TRAN: 白金汉宫〔位于伦敦的英国王室宫殿﹐1995年起部分建筑对游客开放﹔亦指负责安排女王公开活动的官员〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Buckingham Palace announced today that Her Majesty will be visiting Japan next year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 白金汉宫今天宣布女王陛下将于明年出访日本。

Sense.DEF: to become bent or curved because of heat or pressure, or to make something bend or curve in this way
Sense.TRAN: 〔因高温或压力〕（使）弯曲﹔扭曲﹔（使）变形
Sense.EXAMPLE: The steel pillars began to buckle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些钢柱开始变形了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The rails buckled under the intense heat of the fire.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 铁轨在烈火的高温下变了形。

Sense.DEF: if your knees or legs buckle, they become weak and bend
Sense.EXAMPLE: John felt his knees start to buckle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰觉得膝盖开始发软了。

Sense.SIGNPOST: do sth you do not want
Sense.DEF: to do something that you do not want to do because a difficult situation forces you to do it
Sense.EXAMPLE: He refused to buckle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他拒绝屈服。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A weaker person would have buckled under the weight of criticism.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 意志薄弱的人在这样的批评下也许已经垮了。

Sense.DEF: to fasten a buckle, or be fastened with a buckle
Sense.EXAMPLE: Amy buckled the belt around her waist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃米把腰带扣在腰上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Lou was buckling on his revolver.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 卢在把左轮手枪扣挂在身上。

Sense.DEF: to start working very hard

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You’d better buckle down to some revision now.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你现在最好坐下来好好复习。

Sense.DEF:
to fasten your
seat belt
in a car, aircraft etc
a piece of metal used for fastening the two ends of a belt, for fastening a shoe, bag etc, or for decoration
Sense.TRAN: 〔皮带等的〕金属扣环﹐扣子﹔带扣

Sense.DEF: stiff cloth, used in the past for covering books and making the stiff parts of clothes
Sense.TRAN: 〔旧时用来做书的封面或使衣服挺直的〕硬粗布﹐硬衬布

Sense.DEF:
a mixture of
champagne
and orange juice, or a glass of this
Sense.TRAN: （一杯）巴克鸡尾酒〔用香槟和橙汁调成的饮品〕

Sense.DEF: a lot of small metal balls that are fired together from a gun

strong soft leather made from the skin of a
deer
or goat
teeth that stick forward out of your mouth
a type of small grain used as food for chickens, and for making flour
relating to the countryside
a young tightly rolled-up flower or leaf before it opens
Sense.EXAMPLE: rose buds
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玫瑰花苞

GramExa.GLOSS: having buds but no flowers yet
start to produce buds

Sense.EXAMPLE: Hey, bud, how’s it going?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 嘿﹐老兄﹐最近怎么样？

Sense.DEF: to produce buds
a religion of east and central Asia, based on the teaching of Gautama Buddha
someone who is just starting to paint, act etc and will probably be successful at it
Sense.TRAN: 崭露头角的艺术家/演员/作家等

Sense.DEF: beginning to develop
Sense.EXAMPLE: a budding romance
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 刚刚开始的恋情

Sense.DEF: a friend
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re good buddies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们是好朋友。

Sense.DEF: used to talk to a man or boy, especially one you do not know
Sense.TRAN: 老兄〔尤用于称呼不认识的男子〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hey, buddy! This your car?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 喂﹐老兄！ 这是你的车吗？

Sense.DEF: to be very friendly with someone

a place on a computer where you keep a list of the names of people that you regularly send
instant message s
to
Sense.TRAN: 好友名单〔保存计算机中的即时通讯联系人名单〕

Sense.DEF: a system in which two people in a group are put together to help each other or keep each other safe
to move, or to make someone or something move
Sense.EXAMPLE: She leaned on the door, but it wouldn’t budge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她靠在门上﹐但是门纹丝不动。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Will hasn’t budged from his room all day.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 威尔一整天没出房门了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The horse refused to budge an inch .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那匹马寸步都不肯走。

Sense.DEF: to change your opinion, or to make someone change their opinion
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government has refused to budge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府不肯作出让步。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He won’t budge on the issue.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这件事上他不肯妥协。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Treacy refuses to budge from his principles.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 特里西坚持自己的原则﹐不肯让步。

Sense.DEF:
a
budgie
the money that is available to an organization or person, or a plan of how it will be spent

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a welfare program with a budget of $2 million
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 预算为200万美元的福利计划

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The budget for photography has been cut.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 摄影方面的预算被削减了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: We had a really tight budget .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的预算很紧。

GramExa.GLOSS: not using more money than planned
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The project was completed within budget.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一项目在预算内完成。

GramExa.GLOSS: using less money than planned
GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you come in under budget, everyone will be very impressed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果没有超出预算﹐大家都会很佩服你。

GramExa.GLOSS: using more money than planned
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Feature movies always run over budget.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 拍故事片总是超支。

Sense.DEF: if you are on a budget, you do not have much money to spend
Sense.EXAMPLE: Travellers on a budget might prefer to camp.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 钱不多的旅游者可能更喜欢野营。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a book which offers great ideas for decorating on a budget
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为经济型装修支妙招的一本书
Sense.EXAMPLE: families on a tight budget
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济拮据的家庭

Sense.DEF: an official statement that a government makes about how much it intends to spend and what taxes will be necessary

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The organization has an annual budget of $24 million.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 该机构的年度预算为2,400万美元。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He has a plan to balance the federal budget.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有一个平衡联邦预算的计划。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We had to make cuts in the defence budget.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须削减国防预算。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Often the husband and wife contribute equally to the family budget.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 通常夫妇俩会平均分担家庭预算。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The club does not have a large budget for new players.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家俱乐部没有大笔预算来引进新球员。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 小额的/低的/有限的预算
Collocate.EXAMPLE: It was a project with a low budget.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一项目的预算很少。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: small and limited

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Hospital caterers have a budget of about £20 per person per week.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 医院饮食供应商的预算是每人每周20英镑。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The Metropolitan Police has overspent its budget by £70 million.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 伦敦警察厅超出预算达7,000万英镑。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: spend only the money that is available
spend only the money that is available
when a government has spent more money than it has
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The country has a budget deficit of over $4 billion.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国预算赤字逾40亿美元。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: when a government has more money than it spends
Collocate.EXAMPLE: A huge budget surplus of over £16 billion was recorded.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 记录中有逾160亿英镑的巨额预算盈余。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: reductions in the amount of money that is available

Sense.DEF: to carefully plan and control how much money you spend and what you will buy with it
Sense.TRAN: 编制预算﹔把…编入预算﹔按计划花钱
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll have to budget more carefully.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须更仔细地安排开支。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This scheme enables you to budget the cost through fixed monthly payments.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个计划可以让你把费用分摊在每个月里等额偿还。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’ve budgeted for a new car next year.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们已经把明年要买新车纳入预算。

Sense.DEF: if you budget something such as time, you decide how much of it you will need
very low in price – often used in advertisements
Sense.TRAN: 经济的﹐特价的﹐便宜的〔常用于广告中〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: budget flights
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 低价航班

Sense.DEF: used for saying how much money has been spent on doing something, especially making a film
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指拍摄电影〕低预算/高预算的
Sense.EXAMPLE: low-budget movies
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 低预算电影

PronCodes.PRON: ˈbʌdʒɪt ə ri, ˈbʌdʒət ə ri

Sense.DEF: relating to the way money is spent in a budget
a small brightly coloured bird that people keep as a pet
someone who is interested in wine, films etc and knows a lot about them
Sense.TRAN: 葡萄酒专家/影迷/歌剧爱好者等

Sense.DEF: a pale yellow-brown colour
not wearing any clothes
Sense.TRAN: 赤身裸体的﹐一丝不挂的

Sense.DEF: to polish something with a cloth
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sandra was buffing her nails.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 桑德拉正在擦指甲。

Sense.DEF: to exercise in order to make your muscles bigger
Sense.EXAMPLE: Smith buffed up for his role as Muhammad Ali.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 史密斯为了扮演穆罕默德·阿里而锻炼肌肉。

Sense.DEF: having a pale yellow-brown colour
Sense.EXAMPLE: buff envelopes
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 米色信封

Sense.DEF: attractive and looking as if you do a lot of exercise – used especially by young people
Sense.TRAN: 健美的〔尤为年轻人使用〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s so buff!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那身肌肉真棒！

Sense.DEF: an African animal similar to a large cow with long curved horns

a
bison
someone or something that protects one thing or person from being harmed by another

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Eastern Europe was important to Russia as a buffer against the West.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 东欧是俄罗斯与西方抗衡的重要缓冲。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She often had to act as a buffer between father and son.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她经常要充当父子之间的调解人。

Sense.DEF: one of the two special metal springs on the front or back of a train or at the end of a railway track, to take the shock if the train hits something
Sense.TRAN: 〔火车或铁轨末端的〕缓冲器﹐减震器

Sense.DEF: an area between two armies, that is intended to separate them so that they do not fight
a smaller country between two larger countries, that makes war between them less likely
a place in a computer’s memory for storing information temporarily
an old man who is not good at managing things
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s a nice old buffer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是个不错的老家伙。

Sense.DEF: something used to polish a surface
an activity or plan that hits the buffers is stopped and does not succeed
to reduce the bad effects of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Consumer spending is buffering the effects of the recession.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 消费支出正在缓解经济衰退造成的影响。

Sense.DEF: if a computer buffers information, it holds it for a short while before using it
a meal at a party or other occasion, in which people serve themselves at a table and then move away to eat
Sense.EXAMPLE: a cold buffet
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 冷餐会

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The price includes morning coffee, buffet lunch, and afternoon tea.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一价格包含早晨的咖啡﹑自助午餐和下午茶。

Sense.DEF: a place in a railway station, bus station etc where you can buy and eat food or drink
a piece of furniture in which you keep the things you use to serve and eat a meal
if something, especially wind, rain, or the sea, buffets something, it hits it with a lot of force
Sense.EXAMPLE: London was buffeted by storms last night.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伦敦昨晚遭到暴风雨的袭击。

Sense.DEF: to treat someone unkindly
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was weary of being buffeted by life.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我厌倦了生活的艰难坎坷。

Sense.DEF: to move something in one direction and then another, again and again, with force
Sense.TRAN: 把…推来搡去﹐把…抛来抛去
Sense.EXAMPLE: The body was buffeted about in the waves.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尸体在海浪中漂来荡去。

Sense.DEF: a part of a train where you can buy food and drink
someone who does silly amusing things
an illness that people catch very easily from each other but is not very serious

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I picked up a bug last weekend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 上个周末我生了一场小病。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
There’s a nasty bug going round
that a lot of people have caught
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在流行着一种很烦人的传染病。

GramExa.GLOSS: illness affecting your stomach
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s off work with a stomach bug.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他胃不舒服没有上班。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a 24-hour flu bug
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一天即愈的流感

Sense.DEF: a small insect
a fault in the system of instructions that operates a computer
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bug in the software
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 软件上的一个问题

Sense.DEF: a small piece of electronic equipment for listening secretly to other people’s conversations
a sudden strong interest in doing something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She’s got the travel bug.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她突然迷上了旅游。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
I had one flying lesson and immediately caught the bug
became very interested in flying
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我上了一节飞行课﹐马上就着了迷。

Sense.DEF: to annoy someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: It just bugs me that I have to work so many extra hours for no extra money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我得加班那么长时间﹐却拿不到分文加班工资﹐这使我很恼火。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The baby’s crying is really bugging him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 婴儿的哭闹实在让他心烦。

Sense.DEF:
to put a
bug
small piece of electronic equipment
somewhere secretly in order to listen to conversations
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you think the room is bugged?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你认为这房间装了窃听器吗？

Sense.DEF: something that makes people anxious or afraid
something that makes people feel annoyed or worried
Sense.EXAMPLE: Paperwork is our worst bugbear.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 文书工作是我们最头痛的事。

Sense.DEF: having eyes that stick out
an offensive word for someone who is very annoying or unpleasant
someone that you pretend to be annoyed with, although you actually like or love them
Sense.TRAN: 坏蛋〔对喜欢的人假装讨厌的称呼〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The poor little bugger got an awful shock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这可怜的小坏蛋受到很大的惊吓。

Sense.DEF: a job or activity that is very difficult
Sense.EXAMPLE: The exam was a bit of a bugger.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 考试有点难。

Sense.DEF: nothing
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s bugger all wrong with this machine.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这机器屁问题都没有。

Sense.DEF: said when you are annoyed or angry
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bugger it! I don’t see why I should pay for everything.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该死的！我不明白干吗什么都要我来出钱。

Sense.DEF: said when you are surprised about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Well I’m buggered! I never thought you’d do that.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 噢﹐该死！我从没想到你会做那样的事。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you do not care about the person or thing you are talking about
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bugger the expense – I’m going to buy it!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 管它多少钱——我一定要买！

Sense.DEF:
to have
anal
sex with someone
to behave in a stupid way or waste time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s stop buggering about and go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们别闹了﹐走吧。

Sense.DEF: to cause unnecessary problems for someone
Sense.TRAN: 给某人添麻烦﹐烦扰某人
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t let Peter bugger you about.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别让彼得来烦你了。

Sense.DEF: to go away or leave a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tim buggered off to Australia years ago.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蒂姆几年前就去了澳大利亚。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Bugger off!’ she screamed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “滚开！”她大声叫道。

Sense.DEF: to ruin something or do something very badly
Sense.EXAMPLE: It really buggered up our plans when the train was cancelled.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那班火车取消了﹐我们的计划全打乱了。

Sense.DEF: extremely tired
completely ruined or broken
Sense.EXAMPLE: The washing machine’s buggered.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 洗衣机坏了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you do not know something, will not do something, or are not able to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m buggered if I can remember.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我要能记得起来才怪呢。

Sense.DEF:
anal
sex
a light folding chair on wheels that you push small children in
a light carriage pulled by a horse
a small bed on wheels, that a baby lies in

a musical instrument like a
trumpet
, that is used in the army to call soldiers
to make something, especially a building or something large
Sense.EXAMPLE: The purpose is to build new houses for local people.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 目的是要为当地居民建造新的住宅。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The road took many years to build.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条路修了好几年。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They needed $3 million to build the bridge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们需要300万美元来修建这座桥。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It is the female birds that build the nests.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 筑巢的是雌鸟。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Developers want to build on the site of the old gasworks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 开发商想在煤气厂的旧址上造房子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a row of recently built houses
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一排新建的房子

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s going to build the children a doll’s house.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他打算给孩子们搭一个玩偶屋。

Sense.DEF: to make something develop or form
Sense.TRAN: 使发展﹔使构成﹔创建﹐建立﹔树立﹔培养
Sense.EXAMPLE: She had built a reputation as a criminal lawyer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她已经树立起了刑事诉讼律师的声望。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s been busy building her career.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她忙于创建自己的事业。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ross took 20 years to build up his business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗斯花了20年的时间创业。

GramExa.GLOSS: form a clear idea about someone or something
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 对某人/某物有清楚的认识
GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re trying to build up a picture of what happened.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们试图弄清楚事情发生的经过。

Sense.DEF: to be made using particular materials
Sense.EXAMPLE: The church was built of brick.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这座教堂是用砖建造的。

Sense.DEF: if a feeling builds, or if you build it, it increases gradually over a period of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tension began to build as they argued more frequently.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们争吵越来越频繁﹐关系也随之紧张起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: In order to build your self-esteem, set yourself targets you can reach.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为了增强自尊心﹐要为自己设定一些可以达到的目标。

Sense.DEF: to try to establish a better relationship between people who do not like each other
Sense.TRAN: 沟通﹔建立良好关系〔尤指在对立的人之间〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Peter needs to try and build bridges with Lizzie.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 彼得要设法和莉齐好好沟通。

Sense.DEF: to base something on an idea or thing and develop it from there
Sense.EXAMPLE: Successful businesses are built around good personal relationships.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 成功的企业是建立在良好的人际关系上。

Sense.DEF: to make something so that it is a permanent part of a wall, room etc
Sense.TRAN: 把…建造在〔墙﹑房间等〕里面
Sense.EXAMPLE: You could build in a wardrobe with mirrored doors.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以嵌入一个带镜门的衣橱。

Sense.DEF: to make something so that it is a permanent part of a wall, room etc
Sense.TRAN: 把…建造在〔墙﹑房间等〕里面
Sense.EXAMPLE: There are three cash machines built into the wall .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有三台自动取款机嵌在墙里面。

Sense.DEF: to make something a permanent part of a system, agreement etc
Sense.TRAN: 使…永久成为〔体制﹑协议等〕的部分
Sense.EXAMPLE: Opportunities for reviewing the timings should be built into the plan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 计划中应留有机会重新考虑时间安排。

Sense.DEF: to base something on an idea or thing
Sense.TRAN: 把某事物建立在某事物之上
Sense.EXAMPLE: Our relationship is built on trust.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的关系建立在信任之上。

Sense.DEF: to use your achievements as a base for further development
Sense.EXAMPLE: The new plan will build on the success of the previous programme.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个新计划将以先前那个方案所取得的成功作为基础。

Sense.DEF: to add another room to a building in order to have more space

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re planning to build on a conservatory.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们打算增建一个玻璃暖房。

Sense.DEF: if something builds up somewhere, or if you build it up, it gradually becomes bigger or greater
Sense.EXAMPLE: the rate at which the pension builds up
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 养老金的增长速度

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The museum has built up a fine art collection.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家博物馆已经积累了一批艺术藏品。

Sense.DEF: to make something develop or form

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s built up the family firm into a multinational company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他把家族企业发展成了一家跨国公司。

Sense.DEF: if a feeling builds up, or if you build it up, it increases gradually over a period of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: If you don’t express your feelings, frustration and anger can build up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你如果不把自己的感受表达出来﹐沮丧和愤怒的情绪就会越积越多。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You have to build up trust.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你必须建立起信任。

Sense.DEF: to make someone well and strong again, especially after an illness
Sense.EXAMPLE: Taking exercise will build up your strength.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 锻炼可以增强你的体力。

Sense.DEF: to praise someone or something so that other people think they are really good, or so that they have more confidence
Sense.EXAMPLE: The coach has been building his men up before the match.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 教练已经在赛前给队员们打过气了。

Sense.DEF: to unfairly encourage someone to think that they will get what they hope for
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t build your hopes up too much.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要抱太大的希望。

Sense.DEF: to prepare for a particular moment or event
Sense.TRAN: 为〔某个时刻或某件事〕做准备
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could tell she was building up to some kind of announcement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我看得出她有什么事情准备向大家宣布。

Sense.DEF: the shape and size of someone’s body
Sense.EXAMPLE: a woman of slim build
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 身材苗条的女子
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’re a surprisingly strong swimmer for one of such a slight build .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你个子这么瘦小﹐想不到竟是游泳高手。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I wanted a more athletic and muscular build .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想拥有更加健壮﹑结实的体格。

Sense.DEF: a person or a company that builds or repairs buildings
Sense.TRAN: 建筑工人﹔建筑商﹔建造者

Sense.DEF: a structure such as a house, church, or factory, that has a roof and walls
Sense.EXAMPLE: The offices are on the top two floors of the building.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 办公室在大楼最高的两层。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a farmhouse and other farm buildings
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 农舍以及其他的农场建筑

Sense.DEF: the process or business of building things
Sense.EXAMPLE: There is a limited supply of land for building.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 建筑用地供应有限。
Sense.EXAMPLE: stone, timber, and other building materials
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 石料﹑木材及其他建筑材料

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The enquiry recommended the building of a tunnel.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 调查结果建议修建一条隧道。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They keep pulling down the old buildings and putting up new ones.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们不停地拆旧楼建新楼。

Collocate.COLLOC: pull down/knock down/tear down a building
Collocate.EXAMPLE: All the medieval buildings were torn down.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有中世纪的建筑都被拆除了。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: pull it down
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Permission is needed to demolish listed buildings.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 拆除列入文物保护范围的建筑要得到许可。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The park was surrounded by tall buildings.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 公园四周高楼林立。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: very tall with many floors

Collocate.EXAMPLE: That low building is a stable block.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 那处低矮的建筑是马廐。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 办公楼/校舍/医院大楼等
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Our office building is just ten minutes’ walk from where I live.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的办公楼离我的住处步行十分钟即到。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The town has a number of interesting public buildings, including the old town hall.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 镇上有一些很有趣的公共建筑﹐包括旧市政厅。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: with two, three etc floors
with only one floor
an old building of historical interest
a historic building that is protected by a government order
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 被列入文物保护范围的建筑物
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The school is actually a listed building.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学校其实是一处文物保护建筑。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: empty and in very bad condition
in bad condition
old and almost falling down
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The farm was surrounded by tumbledown buildings.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个农场周围都是摇摇欲坠的老建筑。

Sense.DEF: a block of wood or plastic for young children to build things with
the pieces or parts that together make it possible for something big or important to exist
Sense.EXAMPLE: Amino acids are the building blocks of protein.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 氨基酸是构成蛋白质的基本成分。

Sense.DEF: someone whose job is to organize the building of a house, office, factory etc
a place where a house, factory etc is being built
a type of bank that you pay money into in order to save it and earn interest, and that will lend you money to buy a house or apartment
Sense.TRAN: 购房[房屋]互助协会〔接受会员存款并付给利息﹑会员购房时提供贷款的商业机构〕

Sense.DEF: an increase over a period of time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a heavy build-up of traffic on the motorway
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 高速公路上交通流量的大幅增长

Sense.DEF: a description of someone or something before an event, in which you say they are very special or important
Sense.EXAMPLE: The presenter gave her a big build-up .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 节目主持人为她大造声势。

Sense.DEF: the length of time spent preparing an event
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was running 20 miles a week in my build-up for the race.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 赛前准备阶段我一星期跑20英里。

Sense.DEF:
the past tense and past participle of
build
used to describe someone’s size or shape
Sense.EXAMPLE: She is built like a dancer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她有舞蹈演员的身材。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a heavily built man
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一名身材壮实的男子

Sense.DEF: places where there are buildings and roads, and not the countryside
Sense.TRAN: 建筑环境〔指有建筑物﹑有道路的地方﹐而不是乡野〕

Sense.DEF: forming a part of something that cannnot be separated from it
Sense.TRAN: 构成固定组成部分的；嵌入结构里﹔内置的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a built-in microphone
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 内置麦克风

Sense.DEF: a built-up area has a lot of buildings and not many open spaces
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was fined for speeding in a built-up area.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因为在建筑物密集的地区超速行驶而被罚款。

Sense.DEF: the glass part of an electric light, that the light shines from
Sense.EXAMPLE: a 100-watt bulb
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个100瓦的灯泡

Sense.DEF: a root shaped like a ball that grows into a flower or plant
Sense.EXAMPLE: tulip bulbs
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 郁金香球茎

Sense.DEF: fat, round, and unattractive
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bulbous nose
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蒜头鼻

Sense.DEF: a curved mass on the surface of something, usually caused by something under or inside it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The gun made a bulge under his jacket.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 手枪从他的夹克里面鼓了出来。

Sense.DEF: a sudden temporary increase in the amount or level of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bulge in the birthrate
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出生率的激增

Sense.DEF: to stick out in a rounded shape, especially because something is very full or too tight

GramExa.EXAMPLE: His pockets were bulging with candy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的口袋里鼓鼓囊囊塞满了糖果。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He fell heavily to the floor, his eyes bulging wide with fear.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他重重地摔在地上﹐吓得双眼圆睁。

Sense.DEF:
an illness in which a person cannot stop themselves from eating too much, and then
vomit s
in order to control their weight
the main or largest part of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bulk of consumers are based in towns.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数消费者都是城镇居民。

Sense.DEF: a big mass or shape of something
Sense.TRAN: 巨大的一团﹔巨大的形状
Sense.EXAMPLE: the great bulk of a building
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 建筑物的巨大形状

Sense.DEF: the size of something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The dough will rise until it is double in bulk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 面团会发酵到原来的两倍大。

Sense.DEF: if you buy goods in bulk, you buy large amounts each time you buy them
the buying etc of goods in large quantities at one time
bulk goods are sold or moved in large quantities
Sense.EXAMPLE: bulk flour for commercial bakeries
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 向商业面包店供应的大批量面粉

Sense.DEF: if you send something bulk mail, you send large amounts of it for a smaller cost than normal
to be the main or most important part of something
to make something bigger or thicker by adding something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: We can bulk out the report with lots of diagrams.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们可以加进许多图表﹐使报告的内容更充实。

Sense.DEF: to increase the amount of muscle you have
a wall that divides the structure of a ship or aircraft into sepate parts
Sense.TRAN: 〔船或飞机的〕舱壁﹐隔离壁﹐隔板

Sense.DEF: something that is bulky is bigger than other things of its type, and is difficult to carry or store
Sense.TRAN: 庞大的﹐笨重的﹐体积大的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bulky parcel
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 笨重的包裹

Sense.DEF: someone who is bulky is big and heavy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Andrew is a bulky man.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 安德鲁是个大块头。

Sense.DEF: an adult male animal of the cattle family
Sense.EXAMPLE: a herd of cows with one bull
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一群母牛加一头公牛

Sense.DEF:
the male of some other large animals such as the
elephant
or
whale
Sense.TRAN: 〔象、鲸等大型动物的〕雄性动物

Sense.LEXUNIT: take the bull by the horns
Sense.DEF: to bravely or confidently deal with a difficult, dangerous, or unpleasant problem
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nora decided to take the bull by the horns and organize things for herself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 诺拉决定迎难而上﹐自己来安排事情。

Sense.DEF: nonsense or something that is completely untrue
Sense.EXAMPLE: What a load of bull!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 真是胡说八道！

Sense.LEXUNIT: like a bull in a china shop
Sense.DEF: if you are like a bull in a china shop, you keep knocking things over, dropping things, breaking things etc

Sense.LEXUNIT: like a bull at a gate
Sense.DEF: if you move somewhere like a bull at a gate, you move there very fast, ignoring everything in your way
an official statement from the Pope

the centre of a
target
that you are shooting at

someone who buys
share s
because they expect prices to rise

Crossrefto.REFLEX: like a red rag to a bull

Sense.DEF: used to say that you do not believe or agree with what someone has said
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bull! Where did you get that idea?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 胡扯！ 你怎么会有那种想法？

Sense.DEF: a set of metal bars fixed to the front of a large vehicle such as a Jeep or Land Rover, in order to protect it from damage
a powerful dog with a large head, a short neck, and short thick legs
a small metal object that shuts tightly to hold papers together
to destroy buildings etc with a bulldozer
to push objects such as earth and rocks out of the way with a bulldozer
to force someone to do something that they do not really want to do
a powerful vehicle with a broad metal blade, used for moving earth and rocks, destroying buildings etc
a small piece of metal that you fire from a gun
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was killed by a single bullet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被一枪打死。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bullet wound in the shoulder
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 肩上的枪伤
Sense.EXAMPLE: Several bullet holes could be seen beside a window.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 窗户边可以看到几个弹孔。

Sense.DEF: a news report on radio or television
an official statement that tells people about something important
a letter or printed statement that a group or organization produces to tell people its news
Sense.TRAN: 〔某团体或机构出版的〕简报，会刊

Sense.DEF: a board on the wall that you put information or pictures on
a place in a computer information system where you can read or leave messages
a thing in a list that consists of a word or short phrase, with a small printed symbol in front of it
Sense.TRAN: 点句项目；点句符；项目符号

Sense.DEF: something that is bullet-proof is designed to stop bullets from going through it
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inch-thick wall of bullet-proof glass
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一英寸厚的防弹玻璃墙

Sense.DEF:
a type of entertainment popular in Spain, in which a person fights and kills a
bull
a small grey and red European bird

a kind of large
frog
that makes a loud noise
determined to get what you want without really thinking enough about it
a piece of equipment that you hold up to your mouth to make your voice louder
bars of gold or silver
Sense.EXAMPLE: gold bullion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 金条

Sense.DEF: feeling confident about the future
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s very bullish about the company’s prospects.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他对公司的前景充满信心。

Sense.DEF:
in a business market that is bullish, the prices of
share s
are rising or seem likely to rise
Sense.TRAN: 股票行情看涨的﹐牛市的

Sense.DEF:
a
stock market
in which the price of
share s
is going up and people are buying them
having a short and very thick neck
a young male cow that cannot breed

the area in a baseball field in which
pitcher s
practise throwing

the
pitcher s
of a baseball team

the place where a
bullfight
is held
an occasion when a group of people meet to talk in a relaxed and friendly way
Sense.TRAN: 闲聊﹐轻松而友好的交谈
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-night bull session
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 彻夜漫谈

Sense.DEF:
the centre of a
target
that you try to hit when shooting or in games like
dart s
a large hard round sweet
something that is stupid and completely untrue
Sense.EXAMPLE: Forget all that bullshit and listen to me!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别理那些废话﹐听我说！
Sense.EXAMPLE: What he told me was a load of bullshit .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他对我说的是一大堆废话。

Sense.DEF: to say something stupid or completely untrue, especially in order to deceive someone or make them think you are important
a strong short-haired dog
Sense.TRAN: 斗牛㹴（一种体格结实的短毛犬）

Sense.DEF: someone who uses their strength or power to frighten or hurt someone who is weaker
Sense.TRAN: 恃强凌弱者﹐以大欺小者﹔流氓﹐暴徒
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bullies are often cowards.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 恃强凌弱者往往是懦夫。

Sense.DEF: to threaten to hurt someone or frighten them, especially someone smaller or weaker
Sense.TRAN: 欺侮﹐恐吓〔尤指以大欺小﹐恃强凌弱〕

Sense.DEF: to put pressure on someone in order to make them do what you want

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t let them bully you into working on Saturdays.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要让他们逼你星期六上班。
