RunOn.EXAMPLE: an attempt to tackle the problem of bullying in schools
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 解决校园里恃强凌弱问题的尝试

Sense.DEF:
to start a game of
hockey
used when you do not think that someone has done anything special but they want you to praise them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Yes, I know you’ve done all the dishes. Bully for you!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 是的﹐我知道你把碗碟都洗了。 有啥了不起的！

Sense.DEF: someone who behaves in a violent and threatening way
a tall plant that looks like grass and grows by water
something that protects you from an unpleasant situation

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a bulwark against dictatorship
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 反对独裁的堡垒

Sense.DEF:
the sides of a boat or ship above the
deck
a strong structure like a wall, built for defence
the part of your body that you sit on
someone, especially a man, who has no home or job, and who asks people for money
Sense.TRAN: 流浪乞丐﹔无业游民〔尤指男子〕

Sense.DEF:
someone who spends all their time on the beach,
ski ing
etc without having a job
Sense.TRAN: （无业的）流连海滩者/滑雪迷等

Sense.DEF: someone who is very lazy
to make a large number of people go to see a film, play, sports match etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s the kind of star who will put bums on seats.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是那种很有票房号召力的明星。

Sense.DEF: to make someone leave a place, especially a public place, quickly
Sense.TRAN: 驱赶某人〔尤指离开公共场所〕

Sense.DEF: to ask someone for something such as money, food, or cigarettes
Sense.EXAMPLE: She bummed a little cash off me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她向我讨了一点钱。

Sense.DEF: to spend time lazily doing nothing
to travel around, living very cheaply, without having any plans
Sense.EXAMPLE: He spent a year bumming around Australia.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在澳大利亚游荡了一年。

Sense.DEF: bad and useless
Sense.EXAMPLE: The orchestra was excellent. No one played a bum note.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这支管弦乐队非常棒﹐谁都没错一个音。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Jim got a bum deal
unfair treatment
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉姆受了委屈。

Sense.DEF:
an injured
ankle
, leg etc
a small bag that you wear around your waist to hold money, keys etc
to speak in a confused way, so that no one can understand you
Sense.EXAMPLE: What was Karl bumbling on about?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卡尔嘀嘀咕咕地在说什么呀？

Sense.DEF: to move in an unsteady way

a large hairy
bee
behaving in a careless way and making a lot of mistakes
Sense.EXAMPLE: a kind bumbling man with a gentle smile
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个心地善良、脸上带着亲切笑容的粗心男人

Sense.DEF: boring written information that you have to read
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got loads of bumf about the introduction of the euro.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我收到一摞又一摞关于推行欧元的无聊传单。

Sense.DEF: a situation that is disappointing or annoying
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was a real bummer being ill on holiday.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在假期里生病真扫兴。

Sense.DEF: to hit or knock against something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I ran after him, bumping against people in my hurry.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在后面追他﹐匆忙间撞到了别人身上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Tim was a clumsy boy, always bumping into the furniture.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 蒂姆是个笨手笨脚的孩子﹐老是撞到家具上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She bumped her arm on the table.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的手臂撞到了桌子上。

Sense.EXAMPLE:
The roof was so low he bumped his head
his head hit the roof
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 屋顶很低﹐他都碰到头了。

Sense.DEF: to move up and down as you move forward, especially in a vehicle
Sense.EXAMPLE: A police car bumped down the track.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一辆警车颠簸着行驶在小路上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The plane was bumping along the runway.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机在跑道上颠簸着滑行。

Sense.DEF: to push or pull something somewhere in an irregular or unsteady way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Flora was bumping her bags down the steps.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗洛拉正拖着她的行李走下台阶。

Sense.DEF: to move someone or something into a different class or group, or to remove them from a class or group altogether
Sense.EXAMPLE: The flight was overbooked, and Dad was the first one to be bumped.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 航班超额预订﹐爸爸是第一个被挤掉的。

GramExa.PROPFORM: bump sb up to/out of/from etc sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The reforms bumped many families off the state-provided health care list.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 改革把许多家庭挤出了公费医疗名单。

Sense.DEF: to move a radio or television programme to a different time
Sense.TRAN: 改变〔广播或电视节目的时间〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Married with Children’ will be bumped from Sundays to Saturdays.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 《拖家带口》将从星期天改到星期六播映。

Sense.DEF: to meet someone who you know, when you were not expecting to
Sense.EXAMPLE: I bumped into Jean in town.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在城里碰见了琼。

Sense.DEF: to kill someone
to suddenly increase something by a large amount
Sense.TRAN: 使突然大幅度提高﹐使激增
Sense.EXAMPLE: Prices were bumped up by 10 percent last week.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 上星期价格暴涨了10%。

Sense.DEF: an area of skin that is raised because you have hit it on something
Sense.EXAMPLE: She has a bump on the back of her head.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的后脑勺上肿起了一块。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had a few injuries, mostly bumps and bruises.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有几处受了伤﹐大都是肿块和瘀青。

Sense.DEF: a small raised area on a surface
Sense.EXAMPLE: The car hit a bump on the road.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汽车撞到了路上一块凸起之处。

Sense.DEF: the sound or sudden movement of something hitting a hard surface
Sense.EXAMPLE: We heard a bump in the next room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们听到隔壁房间传来砰的一声。

GramExa.PROPFORM: fall/sit down etc with a bump
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Rose fell, landing with a bump.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗丝砰的一声摔倒在地上。

Sense.DEF: a small accident in which your car hits something but you are not hurt
a bar fixed on the front and back of a car to protect it if it hits anything
bumper-to-bumper traffic is very close together and moving slowly
unusually large
Sense.EXAMPLE: We hope readers will enjoy this bumper issue of ‘Homes and Gardens’.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望读者会喜欢这一期特大号的《家园》。

Sense.DEF:
a small electric car that you drive in a special area at a
funfair
and deliberately try to hit other cars
a small sign on the bumper of a car, with a humorous, political, or religious message
Sense.TRAN: 保险杠贴纸〔贴在汽车保险杠上的小标语﹐内容幽默﹐涉及政治或宗教话题〕

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
bumf
someone from the countryside who is considered to be stupid

a dance in which people move parts of their body, especially their
hip s
, together in a sexually exciting way
too proud of your abilities in a way that annoys other people
Sense.TRAN: 自吹自擂的﹐自高自大的﹐自负的

Sense.DEF: a bumpy surface is flat but has a lot of raised parts, so it is difficult to walk or drive on it
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bumpy road
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 凹凸不平的路
Sense.EXAMPLE: The ground is bumpy in places.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地上有些地方高低不平。

Sense.DEF: a bumpy journey by car or plane is uncomfortable, with movements up and down because of bad road or weather conditions
Sense.EXAMPLE: The plane made a bumpy landing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机颠簸着降落了。

Sense.DEF: having a lot of problems for a long time
Sense.TRAN: 一段坎坷的时期﹐一段困难时期
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shareholders have had a bumpy ride.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 股民日子难过。

Sense.DEF: a small round sweet cake
Sense.EXAMPLE: a sticky bun
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个黏糊糊的小圆甜点心

Sense.DEF: a small round type of bread
Sense.EXAMPLE: a hamburger bun
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用来做汉堡包的圆面包

Sense.DEF: if a woman has her hair in a bun, she fastens it in a small round shape at the back of her head
the two round parts of a person’s bottom

Sense.LEXUNIT: have a bun in the oven
Sense.DEF:
to be
pregnant
– used humorously
a group of things that are fastened, held, or growing together

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll send her a bunch of flowers .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我会给她送去一束鲜花。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He had a bunch of keys on his belt.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他皮带上挂了一串钥匙。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a bunch of grapes
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一串葡萄

Sense.DEF: a group of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: The ancient Egyptians were a clever bunch.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古埃及人很聪明。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a friendly bunch of people
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一群友好的人

Sense.DEF: the best among a group of people or things
Sense.TRAN: 佼佼者﹐出类拔萃的人[事物]

Sense.DEF: a large number of people or things, or a large amount of something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There’s a whole bunch of places I want to visit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想去的地方太多了。

Sense.DEF: if a girl wears her hair in bunches, she ties it together at each side of her head
to stay close together in a group, or to make people do this
Sense.EXAMPLE: The children bunched together in small groups.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们三五成群地聚在一起。
Sense.EXAMPLE: John stopped, forcing the rest of the group to bunch up behind him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰停下脚步﹐使得其他人在他身后挤作一团。

Sense.DEF: to make part of your body tight, or to become tight like this
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sean bunched his fists.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 肖恩握紧拳头。

Sense.DEF: to pull material together tightly in folds
Sense.EXAMPLE: She bunched the cloth up and threw it away.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她把布揉成一团扔了。

Sense.DEF: to hold or tie things together in a bunch
a group of things such as papers, clothes, or sticks that are fastened or tied together

GramExa.EXAMPLE: bundles of newspapers
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一捆捆报纸

Sense.EXAMPLE: a small bundle containing mostly clothing
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个小包袱﹐里面主要是衣服

Sense.DEF: a number of things that belong or are dealt with together
Sense.TRAN: 〔属于同一类或需要一起处理的〕一批

GramExa.EXAMPLE: bundles of data
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 数据包

Sense.DEF: computer software, and sometimes other equipment or services that are included with a new computer at no extra cost
a lot of money
Sense.EXAMPLE: College evening classes cost a bundle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大学的夜间课程收费很高。
Sense.EXAMPLE: A company can make a bundle by selling unwanted property.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司出售多余资产可以赚一大笔钱。

Sense.DEF: to be very nervous
an expression meaning a person or situation that is fun or makes you laugh, often used jokingly when they are not fun at all
Sense.TRAN: 〔指人或情况〕很有意思〔常为戏谑说法，表示并不有趣〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Being a teenager isn’t a bundle of laughs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 十几岁的年龄可不是好玩的时候。

Sense.LEXUNIT: not go a bundle on sth/sb
Sense.DEF: to not like something or someone very much
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jim never drank, and certainly didn’t go a bundle on gambling.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉姆从不喝酒﹐当然也不热衷于赌博。

Sense.DEF: to quickly push someone or something somewhere because you are in a hurry or you want to hide them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They bundled Perez into the car and drove off.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们把佩雷斯塞进汽车就开走了。

Sense.DEF: to move somewhere quickly in a group

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Six of us bundled into a taxi.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们六个人匆匆挤进了一辆出租车。

Sense.DEF: to include computer software or other services with a new computer at no extra cost
Sense.TRAN: 〔销售新计算机时〕搭售﹐捆绑销售〔计算机软件或其他服务〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Microsoft can bundle Windows Vista at discounted prices with its popular desktop application programs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 微软公司可以用优惠的价格将Windows Vista和其畅销的桌面应用程序捆绑销售。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company offered customers a single computer solution, bundling together hardware and software.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司捆绑销售硬件和软件﹐为客户提供一套完整的计算机解决方案。

Sense.DEF: to send someone somewhere quickly without asking them if they want to go
to make a bundle by tying things together
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bundle up the newspapers and take them to the skip.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把这些报纸捆好扔进废物桶。

Sense.DEF: to put different things together so that they are dealt with at the same time
Sense.EXAMPLE: The lawsuit bundles together the claims of many individuals into one big case.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场官司把许多人的诉讼请求汇成一个大案子。

Sense.DEF: to put warm clothes on someone or yourself because it is cold
Sense.TRAN: （因寒冷而）给…穿上暖和的衣服
Sense.EXAMPLE: People sat bundled up in scarves, coats, and boots.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们坐着﹐身上裹着围巾和大衣﹐脚上穿着靴子。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: spectators bundled up against the cold
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 为御寒而裹得严严实实的观众

Sense.DEF:
someone who collects money from different people and gives it to a political party to help with its
campaign
Sense.TRAN: 〔政党竞选〕经费募集人﹐“打包机”

Sense.DEF: an argument
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was a bunfight over who should pay for the damage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对应该由谁来赔偿损害发生了争执。

Sense.DEF: a party with food, arranged by an organization
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Rugby Club is planning a bunfight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 橄榄球俱乐部在筹划一个派对。

Sense.DEF: a round piece of rubber, wood etc used to close the top of a container
money given to someone secretly, and usually illegally, to make them do something
to put something somewhere quickly and carelessly

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can you bung these clothes in the washing machine?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你把这些衣服扔进洗衣机好吗？

Sense.DEF: to block something, especially a hole
to find it difficult to breathe because you have a cold
Sense.TRAN: 〔因感冒而鼻子〕不通气﹐呼吸不通

Sense.DEF: a house that is all on ground level
a small house that is often on one level
a sport in which you jump off something very high with a long length of special rope that stretches tied to your legs, so that you go up again without touching the ground
to fail to do something properly, because you have made stupid mistakes – used especially in news reports
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole police operation was bungled.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方的整个行动都给弄砸了。

Sense.DEF: a painful lump on the first joint of your big toe
a narrow bed that is attached to the wall, for example on a train or ship
one of two beds that are attached together, one on top of the other
to suddenly leave a place without telling anyone
nonsense
Sense.EXAMPLE: What a load of bunk!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 真是胡说八道！

Sense.DEF: to sleep somewhere, especially in someone else’s house
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can bunk down on the sofa for tonight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天晚上你可以睡在沙发上。

Sense.DEF: to stay away from somewhere such as school or to leave somewhere early without permission
Sense.EXAMPLE: John and I used to bunk off school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰和我过去经常逃学。

Sense.DEF: a strongly built shelter for soldiers, usually underground
a large hole on a golf course filled with sand
a place where you store coal, especially on a ship or outside a house
to hit a golf ball into a bunker

a bomb that goes deep into the ground before exploding, and that is used to destroy
bunker s
a building where workers sleep
a word for a rabbit, used especially by or to children
a woman who is always thinking and worrying about whether her husband or boyfriend loves her, and is willing to deceive or threaten him so that he will do what she wants him to
Sense.TRAN: 变态爱人〔指老是担心丈夫或男朋友是否爱自己的女子﹐为了达到目的不惜欺骗或威逼对方〕

Sense.DEF:
the area of a mountain where people learn to
ski

the Japanese art of puppet theatre, which is performed using very large
puppet s
models of a person or animal that you move by pulling wires

a piece of equipment that produces a hot gas flame, for scientific
experiment s
Sense.TRAN: 本生灯〔做科学实验用的一种煤气灯〕

Sense.DEF: to deliberately hit the ball a short distance in a game of baseball
small flags on strings, used to decorate buildings and streets on special occasions
Sense.TRAN: 〔穿在绳子上在节庆时悬挂的〕小彩旗

Sense.DEF: an object that floats on the sea, a lake etc to mark a safe or dangerous area
to make someone feel happier or more confident
Sense.EXAMPLE: The party is buoyed up by the latest opinion poll results.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该党因为最近一次民意测验的结果而受到鼓舞。

Sense.DEF: to keep profits, prices etc at a high level
Sense.TRAN: 维持〔利润﹑价格等〕的高水平
Sense.EXAMPLE: Increased demand for computers buoyed their profits.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 计算机需求量的增加使他们的利润维持在很高的水平。

Sense.DEF: to keep something floating
the ability of an object to float
the power of a liquid to make an object float
Sense.EXAMPLE: Salt water has more buoyancy than fresh water.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 盐水的浮力比淡水大。

Sense.DEF: a feeling of happiness and a belief that you can deal with problems easily
the ability of prices, a business etc to quickly get back to a high level after a difficult period
Sense.TRAN: 〔价格、生意等的〕恢复力，复苏力

Sense.DEF: happy and confident
Sense.EXAMPLE: Phil was in a buoyant mood.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 菲尔心情愉快。

Sense.DEF: buoyant prices etc tend to rise
Sense.EXAMPLE: a buoyant economy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 欣欣向荣的经济

Sense.DEF: able to float or keep things floating
Sense.EXAMPLE: Cork is very buoyant.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 软木浮性很好。

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
burr 1
to talk about something in a confused way that is difficult to understand
Sense.TRAN: 嘟嘟囔囔地说﹔语无伦次地唠叨

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I had to listen for an hour while she burbled away.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我只得听她唠叨了一个小时。

Sense.DEF: to make a sound like a stream flowing over stones

the
suburb s
areas around a city, where people live
something difficult or worrying that you are responsible for
Sense.EXAMPLE: His family responsibilities had started to become a burden.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 家庭责任已开始成为他的负担。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The burden of taxation has risen considerably.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 税务负担大大加重了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I don’t like being a burden on other people.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不想成为别人的负担。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If things go wrong he will bear the burden of guilt.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果有什么差错﹐他就会背上内疚的包袱。

Sense.DEF: the duty to prove that something is true
something that is carried
to have a lot of problems because of a particular thing
Sense.TRAN: 被某事所困扰﹔承受某事的负担
Sense.EXAMPLE: a company burdened with debt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 债务缠身的公司

Sense.DEF: to be carrying something heavy
Sense.TRAN: 负载着某物﹐背负着某物

Sense.DEF: causing problems or additional work
Sense.TRAN: 成为负担的﹐累赘的﹔令人烦恼的
Sense.EXAMPLE: These charges are particularly burdensome for poor parents.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些收费对于没钱的家长负担尤其沉重。

Sense.DEF: an office or organization that collects or provides information
Sense.TRAN: 〔收集或提供信息的〕办事处﹐机构
Sense.EXAMPLE: an employment bureau
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 职业介绍所
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Citizens Advice Bureau
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公民咨询局

Sense.DEF: a government department or a part of a government department in the US
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Federal Bureau of Investigation
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 联邦调查局

Sense.DEF: an office of a company or organization that has its main office somewhere else
Sense.EXAMPLE: the London bureau of the Washington Post
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 《华盛顿邮报》驻伦敦办事处

Sense.DEF: a large desk or writing table
a piece of furniture with several drawers, used to keep clothes in
a complicated official system that is annoying or confusing because it has a lot of rules, processes etc
Sense.TRAN: 官僚制度﹔官僚作风﹔官僚主义
Sense.EXAMPLE: the reduction of unnecessary bureaucracy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 消除不必要的官僚体制

Sense.DEF: the officials who are employed rather than elected to do the work of a government, business etc
Sense.TRAN: 官僚〔指政府﹑企业等中雇用而非选举产生的官员的总称〕

Sense.DEF: someone who works in a bureaucracy and uses official rules very strictly
Sense.TRAN: 官僚﹔官僚主义者﹔官僚作风的人

Sense.DEF: involving a lot of complicated official rules and processes
a shop where you can change foreign money

a glass tube with measurements on it, used in scientific
experiment s
to grow or develop quickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: the burgeoning market for digital cameras
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 快速发展的数码相机市场

Sense.DEF:
a flat round piece of finely cut
beef
, which is cooked and eaten, or one of these served in a bread
bun

a
borough
– used in Scotland
Sense.TRAN: 自治[镇]﹔城市的行政区〔苏格兰用语〕

Sense.DEF: someone who lives in a particular town
someone who goes into houses, shops etc to steal things
a piece of equipment that makes a loud noise when someone tries to get into a building illegally
to go into a building and steal things
the crime of getting into a building to steal things
Sense.EXAMPLE: Burglaries have risen by 5%.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 入室盗窃案上升了5%。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was charged with burglary .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因入室盗窃被起诉。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most burglaries happen at night.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 入室盗窃案多数发生在夜间。

Sense.DEF: to go into a building and steal things
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve been burgled three times.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们已经三次被盗。

Sense.DEF: red or white wine from the Burgundy area of France
a dark red colour

the act or ceremony of putting a dead body into a
grave
the act of burying something in the ground

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the burial of solid waste
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 掩埋粪便

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
burqa
a type of thick rough cloth
speech, acting, or writing in which a serious subject is made to seem silly or an unimportant subject is treated in a serious way
Sense.TRAN: 滑稽讽刺讲话[演出﹐文章]

Sense.DEF:
a performance involving a mixture of
comedy
and
striptease
, popular in America in the past
Sense.TRAN: 〔美国过去流行的〕滑稽娱乐表演

Sense.DEF: a burly man is big and strong
Sense.EXAMPLE: a burly policeman
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一名身材魁梧的警察

Subsense.DEF: if a fire burns, it produces heat and flames
Subsense.EXAMPLE: There was a fire burning in the fireplace.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 壁炉里烧着火。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: An average household candle will burn for about six hours.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般的家用蜡烛可以点六小时左右。

Subsense.DEF: if something is burning, it is producing flames and being damaged or destroyed by fire
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Parts of the building are still burning.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大楼的有些地方仍在燃烧。

Sense.DEF: to destroy or damage something with fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: I burnt all his old letters.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把他以前的信全烧了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Cars were burned and shops were looted during the rioting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 暴乱期间﹐汽车被焚﹐商店遭抢劫。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Grand Hotel had burnt to the ground .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 格兰德大酒店被大火夷为平地。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Make sure the iron isn’t too hot or you’ll burn the cloth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 注意熨斗温度不能过高﹐免得烫坏布料。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He dropped his cigarette and burnt a hole in the carpet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的香烟掉下来﹐把地毯烫了一个洞。

Sense.DEF: to hurt yourself or someone else with fire or something hot
Sense.EXAMPLE: I burned my hand on the oven door.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的手被烤箱门烫伤了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was badly burned in a road accident.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在一次交通事故中被严重烧伤。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Sixteen passengers were burned to death
died in a fire
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有16名乘客被烧死。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
A family of five were burned alive in their home last night
died in a fire
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 昨晚有一五口之家在家中被活活烧死。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Heretics were burnt at the stake
burnt in a fire as a punishment
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 异教徒被绑在火刑柱上烧死。

Sense.DEF: if the sun burns your skin, or if your skin burns, it becomes red and painful from the heat of the sun
Sense.EXAMPLE: I burn quite easily.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很容易晒伤。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t forget you can still get burnt when you’re swimming or when it’s cloudy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别忘了﹐就是在游泳或阴天的时候还是会晒伤的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her face and neck were quite badly burned .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的脸和颈部晒伤严重。

Sense.DEF: to spoil food by cooking it for too long, or to become spoiled in this way
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m afraid I’ve burnt the pizza.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我怕是把比萨饼烤糊了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The meat was burned to a crisp.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那肉给烤焦了。

Sense.DEF: to damage or destroy something by a chemical action
Sense.EXAMPLE: Quite a lot of household chemicals can burn your skin.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多家用化学品都会烧伤皮肤。

Sense.DEF:
if you burn a
fuel
, or if it burns, it is used to produce power, heat, light etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The boiler burns oil to produce heat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 锅炉烧油产生热量。
Sense.EXAMPLE: greenhouse gases caused by the burning of fossil fuels
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 燃烧矿物燃料产生的温室气体

Sense.DEF:
if you burn fat or
calorie s
, you use up energy stored in your body by being physically active
Sense.EXAMPLE: Taking a brisk walk every morning is a great way to burn calories.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每天早上快走是消耗热量的好办法。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a fat-burning exercise
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 消耗脂肪的运动

Sense.DEF: if a light or lamp burns, it shines or produces light
Sense.EXAMPLE: A lamp was burning in the kitchen window.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 厨房窗户里亮着一盏灯。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hall light was still burning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大厅里依然灯火通明。

Sense.DEF: if a part of your body burns, or if something burns it, it feels unpleasantly hot
Sense.TRAN: （使）〔身体部位〕灼痛﹐（使）火辣辣地痛
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whisky burned my throat as it went down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 威士忌喝下去的时候﹐我感到喉咙火辣辣的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My eyes were burning from the smoke.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的眼睛被烟熏得刺痛。

Sense.DEF: if your face or cheeks are burning, they feel hot because you are embarrassed or upset
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could feel my cheeks burning as I spoke.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我说话的时候感觉到自己的脸烧得发烫。

Sense.DEF:
if you burn a
CD
or
DVD
, you record music, images, or other information onto it using special computer equipment
to feel a particular emotion very strongly
Sense.TRAN: 满腔怒火/满怀强烈的欲望等
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was burning with curiosity.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她怀着强烈的好奇心。

Sense.DEF: to want to do or find out something very much
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was burning to know how he had got on in New York.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我急切地想知道他在纽约的情况。

Subsense.DEF: to be emotionally hurt by someone or something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Take things slowly – don’t get burned again.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 慢慢来﹐别让自己再受到伤害了。

Subsense.DEF: to lose a lot of money
Subsense.TRAN: 遭受巨大损失﹐亏损巨大
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The company got badly burned in the dot.com collapse.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 网络行业崩溃的时候﹐公司遭受了巨大亏损。

Sense.LEXUNIT: burn your fingers/get your fingers burned
Sense.DEF: to suffer the unpleasant results of something that you have done
Sense.EXAMPLE: I tried a dating agency once, but got my fingers badly burnt – I’ll never do it again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我找过一次婚姻介绍所﹐结果吃了大亏——我以后再也不这样做了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: burn a hole in your pocket
Sense.DEF: if money burns a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you can
Sense.TRAN: 有钱烧得慌﹐有钱就花光

Sense.DEF: to do something with the result that you will not be able to return to a previous situation again, even if you want to
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m really tempted to take up that job offer in Washington, but I don’t want to burn my boats with this company.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很想接受华盛顿的那份工作﹐可又不想和这家公司闹得不愉快。

Sense.LEXUNIT: burn the candle at both ends
Sense.DEF: to get very tired by doing things until very late at night and getting up early in the mornings
Sense.TRAN: 一根蜡烛两头烧﹐起早贪黑而疲惫不堪

Sense.DEF: to work or study until late at night
used to say that something makes someone feel angry or jealous
Sense.EXAMPLE: It really burns me the way they treat us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们这样对待我们﹐我非常气愤。

Sense.DEF: to travel very fast

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a sports car burning up the motorway
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 在高速公路上疾驰的一辆跑车

Exponent.DEF: to produce heat and flames
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The fire was still burning.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 火还在燃烧着。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: A pile of branches was burning in the yard.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 院子里一堆树枝在燃烧。

Exponent.DEF: if a building, car, piece of clothing etc is on fire, it is burning and being damaged
Exponent.TRAN: 〔建筑物﹑汽车﹑衣物等〕着火﹐起火
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Before long, the neighbouring houses were on fire too.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 没过多久﹐相邻的房子也着火了。

Exponent.DEF: if something is alight, it is burning
Exponent.EXAMPLE: By the time the fire engines got there, the whole building was already alight.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 等消防车到那里时﹐整栋大楼都已经燃着了。

Exponent.DEF: if something is ablaze, it is burning with a lot of flames, so that it is seriously damaged
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Twelve hours after the bombing raid, many parts of the city were still ablaze.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 空袭过了12小时后﹐城市的许多地方仍燃烧着熊熊大火。

Exponent.DEF: to burn very brightly with a lot of flames and heat
Exponent.EXAMPLE: A big log fire was blazing in the fireplace.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 壁炉里用原木生的火烧得正旺。

Exponent.DEF: to burn slowly and continuously, producing smoke but no flames
Exponent.EXAMPLE: A cigarette smouldered in the ashtray.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 一支香烟在烟灰缸内闷燃。

Exponent.DEF: to start burning accidentally
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We were worried the house would catch fire.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们担心房子会失火。

Exponent.DEF: to suddenly start burning and produce a lot of flames that cause serious damage
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The plane crashed into the side of the mountain and burst into flames.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机撞上山腰﹐熊熊燃烧起来。

Exponent.DEF: if a chemical or gas ignites, it starts burning
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The compound ignites at 450 degrees Celsius.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种化合物在450摄氏度燃烧。

Exponent.DEF: to damage or destroy something with fire or heat
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She lit a fire and burned his letters one by one.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她点起火﹐把他的来信一封接一封地烧掉。

Exponent.DEF: to make something start burning so that it gets damaged
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Vandals set fire to an empty warehouse.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 破坏分子放火焚烧一处空仓库。

Exponent.DEF: to damage the surface of something by burning it so that a dark mark is left on it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Having the iron on a very high heat can scorch the fabric.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 熨斗温度太高会烫焦衣料。

Exponent.DEF: to damage hair, wool, paper etc by burning it slightly so that the ends or edges are burnt
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The flames were hot enough to singe your eyebrows.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 火焰烫得都能把眉毛燎焦。

Exponent.DEF: to burn your skin with very hot liquid or steam
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The coffee was so hot it nearly scalded his tongue.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 咖啡热得差点烫伤了他的舌头。

Exponent.DEF: to make something such as a fire, cigarette, or candle stop burning
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It took firefighters four hours to put out the blaze.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 消防员花了四个小时才把大火扑灭。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I put out my cigarette and went back into the house.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我熄灭香烟﹐走回屋内。

Exponent.DEF: to make something such as a fire, cigarette, or candle stop burning
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He managed to extinguish the flames with his coat.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他用自己的外套设法把火扑灭了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Customers who smoke will be asked to extinguish their cigarettes or leave the premises.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 吸烟的顾客会被要求熄灭香烟或离开。

Exponent.DEF: to make a flame or fire stop burning by blowing on it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He blew out the candle and went to sleep.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他吹熄蜡烛去睡觉了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The wind blew out the fire.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 风把火吹灭了。

Sense.DEF: if something burns away or is burned away, it is destroyed by fire

GramExa.EXAMPLE: All her hair had been burnt away.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的头发全部烧光了。

Sense.DEF: if a building burns down or is burned down, it is destroyed by fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was worried that the house might burn down while they were away.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她担心他们不在的时候房子会被烧毁。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The old town hall was burnt down in the 1970s.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 旧市政厅在 20世纪70年代的时候被大火烧毁了。

Sense.DEF: if a fire burns down, the flames become weaker and it produces less heat
to remove something by burning it
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can use a blowlamp to burn off the old paint.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以用喷灯把原来的油漆烧掉。

Sense.DEF: to use energy that is stored in your body by doing physical exercise
Sense.EXAMPLE: I decided to go for a run to try and burn off a few calories.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我决定去跑跑步﹐消耗一点热量。

Sense.DEF: if a fire burns out or burns itself out, it stops burning because there is no coal, wood etc left
Sense.EXAMPLE: He left the fire to burn itself out .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他让火自行熄灭。

Sense.DEF: if a building or vehicle is burnt out, the inside of it is destroyed by fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hotel was completely burnt out. Only the walls remained.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅馆完全烧空了﹐仅余四壁。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We passed several burnt out cars.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们从几辆被烧成空壳的汽车旁边经过。

Sense.DEF: to remove something by burning it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The cancer cells are burnt out using a laser beam.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用激光束把癌细胞烧死。

Sense.DEF: to work so hard over a period of time that you become unable to continue working because you are tired, ill, or unable to think of any new ideas
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a high-pressure job and you could burn out young.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是份压力很大的工作﹐年纪轻轻就会身心疲惫。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was almost burnt out by the time he was 21.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他21岁的时候差不多就已江郎才尽。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She’s in danger of burning herself out.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她可能会把自己累垮的。

Sense.DEF: if an engine or electric wire burns out or is burnt out, it stops working because it has been damaged by getting too hot
Sense.EXAMPLE: The plugs are wired so that if one burns out, the others will still start the engine.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 火花塞由电线相连﹐因此要是一个烧坏﹐其他几个仍能将引擎发动起来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I think you’ve burnt out one of the gaskets.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想你是把其中一个密封垫烧坏了。

Sense.DEF:
if a
rocket
or
jet
burns out, it stops working because all its
fuel
has been used
Sense.TRAN: 〔火箭或喷气式飞机〕燃油耗尽

Sense.DEF: if something burns up or is burnt up, it is completely destroyed by fire or heat
Sense.EXAMPLE: The satellite will burn up as it re-enters the Earth’s atmosphere.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卫星在返回到地球大气层时将会焚毁。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Most of the woodland has now been burnt up.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在大多数林地都被烧光了。

Sense.DEF: to use a lot of something in a careless way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most household appliances burn up loads of electricity.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数家用电器耗电量很大。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He just burns up money!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他花钱如流水！

Sense.DEF: if someone is burning up, they are very hot, usually because they are ill
Sense.EXAMPLE: Feel his forehead – he’s burning up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 摸摸他的额头——他发烧了。

Sense.DEF: to make someone very angry
Sense.EXAMPLE: The way he treats her really burns me up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那样对待她﹐实在让我很光火。

Sense.DEF: to use energy that is stored in your body, by being physically active
Sense.EXAMPLE: As we get older, our body becomes less efficient at burning up calories.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 随着年龄的增长﹐我们人体消耗热量的能力越来越弱。

Sense.DEF: an injury caused by fire, heat, the light of the sun, or acid
Sense.TRAN: 〔因火﹑高温﹑太阳光或酸引起的〕烧伤﹔灼伤﹔烫伤
Sense.EXAMPLE: His body was covered in cigarette burns.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他身上全是烟头烫伤。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She was taken to the hospital with serious burns.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她严重烧伤﹐被送进医院。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Several of the survivors suffered severe burns .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有几名幸存者被严重烧伤。

Sense.EXAMPLE: She is being treated for minor burns .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她轻度烧伤﹐正在接受治疗。

Sense.DEF: a mark on something caused by fire or heat
Sense.EXAMPLE: The desk was covered with graffiti and burn marks .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 书桌上涂满了乱七八糟的东西﹐还有火烫的痕迹。

Sense.DEF: a painful mark on the skin caused by it rubbing hard against something rough
a painful hot feeling in your muscles when you exercise a lot
Sense.TRAN: 〔大量锻炼使肌肉产生的〕酸痛感
Sense.EXAMPLE: Go for the burn.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 让肌肉锻炼一下。

Sense.DEF: a small stream

the part of an
oven
or heater that produces heat or a flame
Sense.EXAMPLE: a gas burner
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 煤气燃烧器

Sense.DEF:
one of the round parts on the top of a
cooker
that produce heat

Sense.LEXUNIT: put/leave sth on the back burner
Sense.DEF: to delay doing something until a later time
Sense.TRAN: 推迟做某事﹐把某事往后搁
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government quietly put the scheme on the back burner.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府悄悄地把这个计划搁置起来了。

Sense.DEF: on fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was rescued from a burning building.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她被人从着火的大楼里救了出来。

Sense.DEF: feeling very hot
Sense.EXAMPLE: Claudia put her hands to her burning face.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 克劳迪娅双手捂住自己发烫的脸。

Sense.DEF:
a burning
ambition
, desire, need etc is very strong
Sense.TRAN: 勃勃的雄心/熊熊欲望/迫切需要等
Sense.EXAMPLE: My burning ambition is to be world champion.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我雄心勃勃要当世界冠军。

Sense.DEF:
a burning
issue
or question is very important and urgent
Sense.EXAMPLE: Education has become a burning issue in this election.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 教育成了本届选举的当务之急。

Sense.DEF: burning eyes look at you very hard or show very strong feeling
very hot
to polish metal or another substance until it shines
to work hard in order to improve something
Sense.EXAMPLE: He missed no opportunity to burnish his image.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他时刻不忘美化自己的形象。

Sense.DEF: the feeling of always being tired because you have been working too hard
Sense.TRAN: 〔因拼命工作导致的〕精疲力竭
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many of the teachers are suffering from burnout.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多老师劳累过度。

Sense.DEF:
the time when a
rocket
or
jet
has finished all of its
fuel
and stops operating
Sense.TRAN: 〔火箭或喷气式飞机的〕熄火﹐燃油耗尽

Sense.DEF:
the past tense and past participle of
burn
damaged or hurt by burning
Sense.EXAMPLE: burnt toast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤焦的面包片

Subsense.DEF:
something that is offered as a gift to a god by being burnt on an
altar
Subsense.TRAN: 燔祭品〔祭坛上焚烧以祭神的东西〕

Subsense.DEF: food that you accidentally burnt while you were cooking it

Sense.DEF: to pass gas loudly from your stomach out through your mouth
to help a baby to do this, especially by rubbing or gently hitting its back
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指按摩或轻拍背部〕使〔婴儿〕打嗝

Sense.DEF: a long piece of clothing worn by Muslim women in some countries, which covers the head, face, and body, with only a small square to see through
Sense.TRAN: 布尔卡〔某些穆斯林女性穿的包头蒙面长衫﹐只在眼睛部位留有小孔〕

Sense.DEF: the seed container of some plants, covered with sharp points that make it stick to things
a way of pronouncing English with a strong ‘r’ sound
a fairly quiet regular sound like something turning quickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: the burr of a motor
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马达的呼呼声

Sense.DEF: a rough spot on a piece of metal

a Mexican dish made with a
tortilla
flat thin bread
folded around meat or beans with cheese
Sense.TRAN: 墨西哥玉米面饼卷〔以肉﹑豆﹑干酪等为馅〕

Sense.DEF:
a small
donkey
to make a hole or passage in the ground

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mother turtles burrow into the sand to lay their eggs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 母龟在沙里挖洞产卵。

Sense.DEF: to press your body close to someone or under something because you want to get warm or feel safe

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The child stirred and burrowed deeper into the bed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那孩子翻了个身﹐又往被窝里钻了钻。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She burrowed her head into his shoulder.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她把头偎在他肩上。

Sense.DEF: to search for something that is hidden in a container or under other things

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Helen burrowed in her bag for a handkerchief.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 海伦在包里翻找手帕。

Sense.DEF:
a passage in the ground made by an animal such as a rabbit or
fox
as a place to live
Sense.TRAN: 〔兔子、狐狸等动物所掘的〕洞穴

Sense.DEF: someone at a school or college who deals with the accounts and office work
Sense.TRAN: 〔学校或大学的〕财务主管，事务员

Sense.DEF: an amount of money given to someone so that they can study at a university or college
if something bursts, or if you burst it, it breaks open or apart suddenly and violently so that its contents come out
Sense.TRAN: （使）破裂﹔（使）爆裂﹔（使）胀破﹔ （使）爆炸
Sense.EXAMPLE: The pipes had burst and the house was under two feet of water.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 水管爆裂﹐房子被水淹了两英尺。

Sense.DEF: to have a lot of something or be filled with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: John was bursting with ideas and good humour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰主意多﹐脾气好。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The shops are bursting with food.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 商店里摆满了各种食品。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Your mum’s bursting with pride for you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你妈妈为你感到无比骄傲。

Sense.DEF: to move somewhere suddenly or quickly, especially into or out of a place

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Jo burst into the room.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔冲进房间。

Sense.DEF: to open suddenly
Sense.EXAMPLE: The door burst open and Tom ran into the room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 门突然打开﹐汤姆跑进了房间。

Sense.DEF: to want to do something very much
Sense.EXAMPLE: Zach was bursting to tell them something.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扎克迫不及待地想要告诉他们什么事。

Subsense.DEF: to need to go to the toilet very soon
to be so full that nothing else can fit inside

Sense.DEF: to make someone suddenly realize that something is not as good as they thought it was
Sense.EXAMPLE: Steve was so happy I couldn’t bear to burst his bubble.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 史蒂夫这么开心﹐我实在不忍心让他失望。

Sense.DEF: if a river bursts its banks, water from it goes onto the land
to interrupt someone or something by entering a room, in a way that embarrasses you or other people
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m sorry to burst in on you like this.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对不起﹐我这样闯进来打扰你。

Sense.DEF: to suddenly begin to make a sound, especially to start singing, crying, or laughing
Sense.TRAN: 突然…起来〔尤指唱歌﹑哭﹑笑等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Claire looked as if she were about to burst into tears .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 克莱尔看上去好像就要哭出来了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Suddenly, the group burst into laughter .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 突然﹐这群人哄然大笑起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lydia burst into song .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 莉迪娅忽然唱起歌来。

Sense.DEF: to suddenly start to burn very strongly
Sense.TRAN: 突然起火﹐猛烈燃烧起来
Sense.EXAMPLE: Their car crashed and burst into flames.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们的汽车猛烈撞击后突然燃起大火。

Sense.DEF: to suddenly appear and become very successful
Sense.TRAN: 突然出现在…〔指突然成功〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The band burst onto the music scene in 1997.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 1997 年该乐队突然在乐坛上一炮而红。

Sense.DEF: to suddenly start to laugh, cry etc
Sense.TRAN: 突然大笑/大哭/大唱起来等
Sense.EXAMPLE: Everyone burst out laughing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每个人都大笑起来。

Sense.DEF: to suddenly say something in a forceful way
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘I don’t believe it!’ she burst out angrily.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “我不信！”她愤然说道。

Sense.DEF: the act of something bursting or the place where it has burst
Sense.EXAMPLE: a burst in the water pipe
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 水管上的裂口

Subsense.DEF: a short sudden effort or increase in activity

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The van gave a sudden burst of speed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 小货车突然加速。

Subsense.DEF: a short sudden and usually loud sound

GramExa.EXAMPLE: sharp bursts of machine gun fire
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一阵阵刺耳的机关枪扫射声

Subsense.DEF: a sudden strong feeling or emotion

GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 怒火/热情/脾气等的爆发

Sense.DEF:
a
burden
lost, broken, or dead

to put someone who has died in a
grave

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was buried in the churchyard of St Mary’s.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被安葬在圣玛丽教堂的墓地里。

Sense.DEF: to put something under the ground, often in order to hide it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Electric cables are buried beneath the streets.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 电缆埋在街道的下面。

Sense.DEF: to fall on top of someone or something, usually harming or destroying them
Sense.TRAN: 将…埋在下面〔一般造成伤害或破坏〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The skiers were buried under the snow.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 滑雪者被埋在积雪下面。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Fifty-seven miners were buried alive .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: . 57名矿工被活埋。

Sense.DEF: to cover something so that it cannot be found
Sense.EXAMPLE: His glasses were buried under a pile of papers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的眼镜埋在一堆报纸下面。

Sense.DEF: to ignore a feeling or memory and pretend that it does not exist
Sense.TRAN: 把〔感情或记忆〕埋在心里
Sense.EXAMPLE: a deeply buried memory
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 深埋的记忆

Sense.DEF: to press your face etc into something soft
Sense.TRAN: 把脸/头等埋在（某物）里面
Sense.EXAMPLE: Noel buried his face in the pillow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 诺埃尔把脸埋在枕头里。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bury your face/head in your hands
Sense.DEF: to cover your face with your hands because you are very upset

Sense.LEXUNIT: bury your head in the sand
Sense.DEF: to ignore an unpleasant situation and hope it will stop if you do not think about it
Sense.TRAN: 采取鸵鸟政策﹐逃避现实

Sense.DEF: to agree to stop arguing about something and become friends
to push something, especially something sharp, into something else with a lot of force

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The dog buried its teeth in my leg.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 狗使劲咬住我的腿。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The bullet buried itself in the wall.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 子弹射进了墙里。

Sense.LEXUNIT: bury yourself in your work/studies etc
Sense.DEF: to give all your attention to something
Sense.EXAMPLE: After the divorce, she buried herself in her work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 离婚后﹐她埋头工作。

Sense.DEF: to put information in a document in a place where it is unlikely to be noticed, or to not make it available to people
Sense.EXAMPLE: The story was buried at the back of the paper.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这篇报道被掩藏在报纸的最后面。

Sense.DEF: to have someone you love die
Sense.EXAMPLE: She had buried her husband, two sons, and a daughter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她失去了丈夫﹑两个儿子和一个女儿。

Sense.DEF: a large vehicle that people pay to travel on

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There were a lot of people on the bus.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公共汽车上有许多人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The best way to get there is by bus.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 去那里最好的方式是乘公共汽车。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I took a bus to San Francisco.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我乘公共汽车去旧金山。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Buses run at 15 and 30 minutes past the hour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公共汽车在每小时的15分和30分时发车。

Sense.DEF:
a
circuit
that connects the main parts of a computer so that signals can be sent from one part of the computer to another

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I usually go to work by bus.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我通常乘公共汽车上班。

Collocate.COLLOC: go on the bus/use the bus
Collocate.COLLGLOSS: travel by bus
Collocate.EXAMPLE: It's easier to go on the bus than to drive.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 出行乘坐公共汽车比自己开车方便。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Can we get a bus from here to Reading?
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们能从这里乘公共汽车到雷丁吗？

Collocate.EXAMPLE: It was the first time Craig had ridden a bus downtown by himself.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是克雷格第一次独自乘公共汽车去市中心。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Several more passengers got on the bus.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 又有几名乘客上了公共汽车。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: be too late to get on a bus
go at regular times

Collocate.EXAMPLE: It's a 20-minute bus ride into town.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 乘公共汽车进城要20分钟。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a place where a bus stops for passengers
Collocate.EXAMPLE: She got off at the next bus stop.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在下一个公共汽车站下了车。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a small covered area where you wait for a bus
a service that provides regular buses
the money you pay for a bus journey
a card that allows you to make several bus journeys
a place where buses start and finish their journeys
a part of the road where only buses are allowed to drive
one that makes regular short journeys between two places
one with two levels for passengers
one without a roof, used for showing tourists a town etc

Sense.DEF: to take a person or a group of people somewhere in a bus

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Casey was bussed to the school.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯西乘公共汽车上学。

Sense.DEF: to take away dirty dishes from the tables in a restaurant
Sense.TRAN: 收拾〔餐馆饭桌上的脏碗碟〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shelley had a job bussing tables .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 谢利在餐馆干一份收盘子的工作。

Sense.DEF: a young man whose job is to take away dirty dishes from the tables in a restaurant
Sense.TRAN: 餐馆打杂工〔负责收拾碗碟的小伙子〕

Sense.DEF: a tall fur hat worn by some British soldiers
Sense.TRAN: 〔一些英国士兵戴的〕毛皮高顶帽

Sense.DEF: a plant with many thin branches growing up from the ground
Sense.EXAMPLE: a rose bush
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玫瑰丛
Sense.EXAMPLE: The child was hiding in the bushes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那孩子躲在灌木丛里。

Sense.DEF: wild country that has not been cleared, especially in Australia or Africa
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指澳大利亚或非洲的〕荒野

Sense.DEF: a bush of hair is a lot of thick untidy hair
very tired

Sense.LEXUNIT: hide your light under a bushel
Sense.DEF: to not tell anyone that you are good at something
badly done or of such bad quality that it is not acceptable
Sense.EXAMPLE: bush league reporting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蹩脚的报道

Sense.DEF:
someone who belongs to a southern African tribe who live in the
bush
wild country
to push or cut your way through thick trees or bushes
Sense.TRAN: 在丛林中开（道）﹐披荆斩棘

Sense.DEF: bushy hair or fur grows thickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bushy tail
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毛茸茸的尾巴

Sense.DEF: bushy plants grow thickly, with a lot of branches and leaves
in a busy way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Students were busily writing notes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学生们正忙着记笔记。

Sense.SIGNPOST: buying or selling goods or services
Sense.DEF: the activity of making money by producing or buying and selling goods, or providing services
Sense.EXAMPLE: Students on the course learn about all aspects of business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这门课程的学生要学习商业活动的各个方面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Carl began in the music business by running a recording studio.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卡尔是从经营录音棚开始干音乐这一行的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We do business with a number of Italian companies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们和一些意大利公司做生意。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He has a wide range of business interests.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的生意面很广。

Sense.DEF: an organization such as a company, shop, or factory that produces or sells goods or provides a service
Sense.EXAMPLE: She now has her own $25 million home-shopping business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她现在自己有一家资产为2,500万美元的居家购物公司。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They don’t know how to run a business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们不知道如何经营企业。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company began as a small family business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家公司是从一个家族小企业起家的。

Sense.SIGNPOST: how much work a company has
Sense.DEF: the amount of work a company does or the amount of money it makes
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re now doing twice as much business as we did last year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们现在的生意是去年的两倍。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Exports account for 72% of overall business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出口占贸易总额的72%。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Business is slow during the summer.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 夏天生意清淡。

GramExa.GLOSS: try to get more work for you or your company
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Perot was in Europe, drumming up business for his new investment company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 佩罗在欧洲为他新开的投资公司拉生意。

Sense.DEF: work that you do as part of your job
Sense.EXAMPLE:
She’s in New York this week on business
for her work
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她这个星期在纽约公干。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hi Maggie! Is this phone call business or pleasure ?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 嗨﹐玛吉﹐这个电话是公事还是私事？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We discussed the idea over a business lunch.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在一次商务午餐中讨论了这个想法。

Sense.EXAMPLE: useful business contacts
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生意上有用的人脉关系

Sense.SIGNPOST: what someone should be involved in

Subsense.DEF: if something is not your business or none of your business, you should not be involved in it or ask about it
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It was not her business, she decided, to ask where the money came from.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 最后她想﹐她不该过问这笔钱的来历。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It’s none of your business how much I weigh.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我体重多少跟你无关。
Subsense.EXAMPLE:
‘Who’s that girl you were with?’ ‘ Mind your own business
Don’t ask questions about something that does not concern you
!’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “和你在一起的那个女孩是谁？”“少管闲事！”
Subsense.EXAMPLE:
‘Are you going out with Kate tonight?’ ‘That’s my business’
it doesn’t concern you, so don’t ask me questions about it
.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你今天晚上是不是要和凯特出去？”“那是我的事。”

Subsense.DEF: if it is someone’s business to do something, it is their duty or responsibility to do it

GramExa.PROPFORM: it is the business of sb to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: It is the business of government to listen to the various groups within society.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 倾听不同社会团体的声音是政府的职责。

Sense.DEF: things that need to be done or discussed
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Okay, let’s get down to business
start doing or discussing something
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好吧﹐我们干正事吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Is there any other business ?’ the chairman asked.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “还有其他事情吗？”主席问道。

Sense.DEF: a situation or activity, especially one that you have a particular opinion about or attitude towards
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指你有某种看法或态度的〕事情﹐事件

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Leon regards keeping fit as a serious business.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利昂把健身当成是正事。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Tanya found the whole business ridiculous.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 塔尼娅认为整件事很可笑。

Subsense.DEF: to be involved in business activities
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The company has been in business for over 30 years.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司已经营了30多年。

Subsense.DEF: to have all that you need to start doing something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’ve just got to buy the paint and then we’re in business.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我只要把油漆买来﹐我们就一切准备就绪了。

Sense.DEF: if a company goes out of business, or something puts it out of business, it stops operating, especially because of financial problems
Sense.EXAMPLE: Higher interest rates will drive small firms out of business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 调高利息将会迫使小公司倒闭。

Sense.DEF: to be working or operating in a normal way again
Sense.EXAMPLE: The band are back in business after a long break.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这支乐队沉寂了很长一段时间后重返舞台。

Sense.LEXUNIT: sb was (just) minding their own business
Sense.DEF: used to say that someone was not doing anything unusual or wrong at the time when something unfair or bad happened to them
Sense.TRAN: 某人（正）干着自己的事〔指某人并没有做错什么却遭遇了不好的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was driving along, minding my own business, when the police stopped my car.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我好端端地开着车﹐警察就把我拦了下来。

Sense.DEF: to do the things that you normally do
Sense.TRAN: 忙自己的事﹐做通常做的事
Sense.EXAMPLE: The street was full of ordinary people going about their business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 街上全是各忙各的普通人。

Sense.LEXUNIT: make it your business to do sth
Sense.DEF: to make a special effort to do something
Sense.TRAN: 把做某事当成自己的职责﹐认为是自己应做的事
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ruth made it her business to get to know the customers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 露丝决定亲自去了解客户。

Sense.DEF: to be serious about doing something even if it involves harming someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The border is guarded by troops who mean business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 边境由严于职守的军队守卫着。

Sense.DEF: something you need to discuss further with someone or a situation that has not yet reached a satisfactory solution
Sense.TRAN: 未竟事宜﹐尚未了结的事情
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sudden death of a loved one can often leave the bereaved with an agonising sense of unfinished business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 亲人的突然离世﹐常常会让家属产生一种心愿未了的痛苦心理。

Sense.DEF: used to say that profit is the most important thing to consider
Sense.TRAN: 公事就是公事﹐公事公办
Sense.EXAMPLE: We can’t afford to employ someone who isn’t good at the job – business is business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们没钱雇一个不称职的人——公事归公事嘛。

Sense.DEF: when someone or something is still working or operating normally when you think they might not be
Sense.EXAMPLE: Despite last night’s scare, it was business as usual in the White House today.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尽管昨晚经历一场恐慌﹐今天白宫还是一切照常。

Sense.LEXUNIT: have no business doing sth/have no business to do sth
Sense.DEF: to do something you should not be doing
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was drunk and had no business driving.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他喝醉了就不该开车。

Sense.LEXUNIT: not be in the business of doing sth
Sense.DEF: to not be intending to do something because you think it is a bad idea
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m not in the business of selling my best players.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我可不想把我最好的球员转让出去。

Sense.DEF: and other things of the same general kind
Sense.EXAMPLE: She handles the publicity and all that business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她负责宣传等方面的事务。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something is very good or works well
Sense.EXAMPLE: Have you seen David’s new car? It’s the business!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你见过戴维的新汽车吗？ 很不错啊！

Subsense.DEF: to do what you are expected to do or what people want you to do
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Come on, then, and do the business.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那么来吧﹐做正事吧。

Subsense.DEF: to have sex

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 - Meaning 义项 1

Collocate.EXAMPLE: A lot of firms are keen to do business in Japan.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多公司都很想在日本做生意。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: do business
Collocate.EXAMPLE: It is not a sensible way to conduct business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这不是做生意的明智之道。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: start working in business
Collocate.EXAMPLE: A lot of university graduates want to go into business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多大学毕业生想进入商界。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The bank gave me a loan to help me set up in business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 银行给我一笔贷款帮助我创业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: continue operating and not become bankrupt
stop doing business because of financial problems
Collocate.EXAMPLE: In a recession smaller firms often go out of business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济衰退时﹐小公司往往就维持不下去了。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 音乐/娱乐/计算机等行业
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He started out working in the computer business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他最早从事的是电脑行业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: an occasion when you buy or sell something
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Negotiation is the most important part of a business deal.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 谈判是生意中最重要的环节。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: His wife refused to get involved in his business activities.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他妻子拒绝参与他的商务活动。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: business activities, or shares in companies
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Both companies have substantial business interests in Indonesia.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 两家公司都在印度尼西亚有很多业务。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: people who work in business
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There was pressure on the government from the business community.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府面临来自商界的压力。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: You need to be flexible in today’s highly competitive business world.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 在今天这个竞争激烈的商场﹐你需要善于变通。

ErrorBox.HINTTRAN: Do not say 不要说 ‘make business’. Say 而要说 do business.

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 - Meaning 义项 2

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Nick owned a software business in Boston.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼克在波士顿拥有一家软件公司。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: manage it
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There’s plenty of advice available on how to run your own business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于如何自己经营企业，有许多建议可供参考。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: When you’re starting a business, you have to work longer hours.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 创业期间﹐你不得不加班加点。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: buy it or start running it
Collocate.EXAMPLE: When my father retired, I took over the business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 父亲退休后﹐我接管了企业。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He spent years trying to build a business in Antigua.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他费了多年时间试图在安提瓜建立企业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: stops operating
that employs only a few people
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Many small businesses have been badly hit by the recession.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多小企业在经济衰退中遭受严重打击。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: His girlfriend runs a catering business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的女朋友在经营一家餐饮公司。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: owned and controlled by one family
Collocate.EXAMPLE: For many years the hotel was a family business.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家酒店有许多年一直是一个家族企业。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 成功的/赢利的/生意兴旺的企业

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is likely to be successful
someone who shares a business with you
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 业务合作伙伴﹐生意合伙人
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Margie was his wife and also his business partner.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛吉是他的妻子﹐也是他的生意合伙人。

Sense.DEF: a card that shows a business person’s name, position, company, address etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔印有姓名﹑职务﹑公司﹑地址等的〕商务名片

Sense.DEF:
travelling conditions on an aircraft that are more expensive than
tourist class
, but not as expensive as
first class
the end of a tool or weapon that does the work or causes the damage
Sense.TRAN: 〔工具或武器〕起作用的一端﹐实用部分
Sense.EXAMPLE: the business end of a gun
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 枪口

Sense.DEF: the normal hours that shops and offices are open
effective and practical in the way that you do things
Sense.TRAN: 处事务实的﹐有效率的﹐讲究实际的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a businesslike manner
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 务实的态度

Sense.DEF: a man who works in business
an area where many companies and businesses have buildings and offices
a person who works in business
a document that explains what a company wants to do in the future, and how it plans to do it
a college or part of a college where students can study economic and financial subjects and learn about managing a business
a course of study on economic and financial subjects and managing a business
a suit that someone wears during the day at work
Sense.TRAN: 〔指日常工作穿的〕西服﹐西装﹔职业装

Sense.DEF: a woman who works in business
Sense.TRAN: 女商人﹔女企业家﹐女实业家

Sense.DEF: a system in the US in which students ride buses to schools that are far from where they live, so that a school has students of different races
Sense.TRAN: 跨区校车接送〔美国的一种制度，即学生乘校车跨区上学﹐使得学校融合不同种族的学生〕

Sense.DEF: to play music in a public place in order to earn money
a part of a wide road that only buses are allowed to use
Sense.TRAN: 公共汽车专用车道，公交专用车道

Sense.DEF: an amount of people on a bus that is full
a holiday spent doing the same work as you do in your job – often used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 照常工作的节假日﹐有名无实的假日〔常为幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: a special ticket giving cheap or free bus travel
Sense.TRAN: 公共汽车乘车证〔乘车可享有优惠或免费〕

Sense.DEF: to kiss someone in a friendly rather than sexual way
Sense.EXAMPLE: politicians bussing babies
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 亲吻婴儿的政治家

Sense.DEF: a plural of bus
a small structure with a roof that keeps people dry while they are waiting for a bus
a place where buses start and finish their journeys
a place at the side of a road, marked with a sign, where buses stop for passengers
to break something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I bust my watch this morning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天早上我把手表摔坏了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tony busted the door down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 托尼把门砸烂了。

Subsense.DEF: if the police bust someone, they charge them with a crime
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He was busted by US inspectors at the border.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在边境被美国巡官拘捕。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Davis got busted for drugs .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 戴维斯因涉毒被起诉。

Subsense.DEF: if the police bust a place, they go into it to look for something illegal
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Federal agents busted several money-exchange businesses.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 联邦探员突击搜查了几家货币汇兑店。

Sense.DEF: to try extremely hard to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I bust a gut trying to finish that work on time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我拼着老命想按时完成那项工作。

Sense.DEF: to use too much money, so that a business etc must stop operating
Sense.EXAMPLE: The trip to Spain will probably bust our budget.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次西班牙之行可能会超出我们的预算。

Sense.DEF: used with nouns to show that a situation is being ended or an activity is being stopped
Sense.TRAN: 打击犯罪的/破坏工会的/耗尽预算的等
Sense.EXAMPLE: crime-busting laws
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 打击犯罪的法律

Sense.DEF: used to say that you will try very hard to go somewhere or do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Idaho or bust!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 非去爱达荷州不可！

Sense.DEF: to give someone a lower military rank as a punishment
to escape from a place, especially prison
if people bust up, they end their relationship or friendship
Sense.EXAMPLE: They bust up after six years of marriage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们结婚六年后离异了。

Sense.DEF: to prevent an illegal activity or bad situation from continuing
Sense.TRAN: 阻止〔非法活动或恶劣形势继续下去〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: A couple of teachers stepped in to bust up the fight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有几个老师前去劝架。

Sense.DEF: to damage or break something
Sense.EXAMPLE: A bunch of bikers busted up the bar.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一群摩托车手把酒吧砸了。

Sense.DEF: to start laughing a lot
Sense.EXAMPLE: Elaine busted up laughing at the sight of him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伊莱恩一见到他就笑个没完。

Sense.DEF: a model of someone’s head, shoulders, and upper chest, usually made of stone or metal
Sense.TRAN: 〔通常用石头或金属制作的〕半身塑像

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a bust of Beethoven
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 贝多芬半身像

Sense.DEF: a woman’s breasts, or the part of her clothes that covers her breasts
a measurement around a woman’s breast and back
Sense.EXAMPLE: a 36-inch bust
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 36英寸的胸围

Sense.DEF: a situation in which the police go into a place in order to catch people doing something illegal
Sense.EXAMPLE: a drug bust
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毒品突击搜查

Sense.DEF: a business that goes bust cannot continue operating
broken
Sense.EXAMPLE: The television’s bust again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 电视机又坏了。

Sense.DEF: broken
Sense.EXAMPLE: a busted arm
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一条断臂

Sense.DEF: caught doing something wrong and likely to be punished
Sense.EXAMPLE: You guys are so busted!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们这些家伙这下可被逮到了！

Sense.DEF: used to speak to a man who is annoying you or who you do not respect
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’re under arrest, buster!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小子﹐你被捕了！

Sense.DEF: used with nouns to mean someone or something that ends a situation or stops an activity
Sense.TRAN: 打击犯罪/耗尽预算/打破制裁的人[事物]等

Sense.DEF: a tight piece of clothing that women wear on the top half of the body, which does not cover their shoulders or arms
to move around quickly, looking very busy

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Madge bustled round the room, putting things away.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛奇忙着在房间里收拾东西。

Sense.DEF: busy and usually noisy activity

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a continual bustle of people coming and going
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 川流不息的来往人群

Sense.DEF: a frame worn by women in the past to hold out the back of their skirts
a bustling place is very busy

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The flower market was bustling with shoppers.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 花市里熙熙攘攘﹐挤满了顾客。

Sense.DEF: the end of a relationship

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the bust-up of their marriage
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们婚姻的破裂

Sense.DEF: a very bad quarrel or fight
Sense.EXAMPLE: Cathy and I had a real bust-up yesterday.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 昨天我和凯茜大吵了一场。

Sense.DEF: a woman who is busty has large breasts
if you are busy, you are working hard and have a lot of things to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s busy now – can you phone later?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她现在正忙﹐你稍后打来好吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: a busy mother of four
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个忙忙碌碌﹑育有四个孩子的妈妈

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mr Haynes is busy with a customer at the moment.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 海恩斯先生此时正忙着接待一位顾客。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Rachel’s busy studying for her exams.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 蕾切尔正忙着备考。

Sense.EXAMPLE: There were lots of activities to keep the kids busy .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有很多活动可以让孩子们不闲着。

Sense.DEF: a busy period of time is full of work or other activities
Sense.EXAMPLE: December is the busiest time of year for shops.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 十二月份是一年中商店最繁忙的时期。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a busy day
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 繁忙的一天
Sense.EXAMPLE: He took time out of his busy schedule to visit us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在百忙之中抽空来看望我们。

Sense.DEF: a busy place is very full of people or vehicles and movement
Sense.EXAMPLE: We live on a very busy road .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们住在一条非常热闹的大街上。

Sense.DEF: if a telephone you are calling is busy, it makes a repeated sound to tell you that the person you are calling is talking on their telephone
Sense.EXAMPLE: I called Sonya, but her line was busy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给索尼娅打过电话﹐但是占线。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I keep getting a busy signal .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我总是听到忙音。

Sense.DEF: a pattern or design that is busy is too full of small details – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 〔图案或设计〕繁杂的﹐复杂的〔含贬义〕

Exponent.DEF: if you are busy, you have a lot of things you need to do
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Sorry I haven’t called you, but I’ve been really busy.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 抱歉我没有打电话给你﹐我实在很忙。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a busy housewife
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 忙碌的家庭主妇

Exponent.DEF: very busy and in a hurry, because you have too many things to do
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We’ve been absolutely rushed off our feet getting ready for our son’s birthday party.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们为准备儿子的生日派对忙得团团转。

Exponent.DEF: so busy that you can hardly deal with all the work you have to do
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I can’t stop for lunch today – I’m completely snowed under.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天我没有时间吃午饭了﹐我实在是忙得不可开交。

Exponent.EXP: up to your ears/neck in sth
Exponent.DEF: extremely busy because you have a lot of work to deal with
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Teachers say they are up to their ears in paperwork and don’t have enough time for teaching.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 教师们说他们忙于应付文书工作﹐都没有足够时间教学了。

Exponent.DEF: busy in your job, so that you cannot do anything else
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’m sorry, but he’s tied up at the moment. Could you call back later?
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 很抱歉﹐他此刻忙得走不开﹐你能稍后再打来吗？

Exponent.DEF: to have to do a lot of things, so that you need to hurry or work hard
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Let’s get started – we have a lot to do.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们开始吧﹐有许多事要做呢。

Exponent.DEF: to be busy, especially because you have arranged to do a lot of things during a particular period
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤指某个时期〕有很多事等着要做
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’ve got a lot on this weekend.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这周末我有很多事等着要做。

Exponent.DEF: use this about times when you have a lot of things you need to do
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We have a busy day ahead of us tomorrow.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 明天将是我们忙碌的一天。

Exponent.DEF: a hectic time or situation is extremely busy, so that you are always in a hurry and often feel excited or worried
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It was really hectic at work today.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天上班真是又忙又乱。

Exponent.DEF: the time in the morning and evening when a lot of people are travelling to or from work
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The buses are so crowded during the rush hour you never get a seat.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 高峰时间公共汽车上挤得很﹐从来都找不到座位。

Sense.DEF: to use your time dealing with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: He busied himself with answering letters.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他忙着回复信件。

Sense.DEF: someone who is too interested in other people’s private activities – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 好管闲事的人﹐好事的人〔含贬义〕

Sense.DEF: a small plant with bright flowers
work that gives someone something to do, but that is not really necessary
used to connect two statements or phrases when the second one adds something different or seems surprising after the first one
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s an old car, but it’s very reliable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是一辆旧车﹐但是性能非常可靠。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They rushed to the hospital, but they were too late.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们急忙赶到医院﹐但是已经太迟了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve invited the boss, but she may decide not to come.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们邀请过老板﹐但她有可能决定不来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an expensive but extremely useful book
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 价钱很贵却是非常有用的一本书
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Has he got any experience?’ ‘No, but he’s keen to learn.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “他有经验吗？”“没有﹐但他非常好学。”

Sense.DEF: used to introduce a statement that explains why the thing you have mentioned did not happen or is not possible
Sense.TRAN: 可是〔用于说明某事没有发生或不可能的原因〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d like to go but I’m too busy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很想去﹐可是我太忙了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They would have married sooner, but they had to wait for her divorce.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们是想马上结婚的﹐但是得先等她离婚。

Sense.DEF: used after a negative to emphasize that it is the second part of the sentence that is true
Sense.TRAN: 而是〔用于否定句之后﹐强调第二句是真实的〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: He lied to the court not just once, but on several occasions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在法庭上撒谎不止一次﹐而是好多次了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The purpose of the scheme is not to help the employers but to provide work for young people.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个计划不是为了帮助雇主﹐而是为了给年轻人提供工作机会。

Sense.DEF: except
Sense.EXAMPLE: What can we do but sit and wait?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们除了坐着等﹐还能做什么呢？
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had no choice but to accept the challenge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我别无选择﹐只有接受挑战。
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Not a day goes by but I think of dear old Larry
I think of him every day
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没有一天不想念亲爱的老拉里。

Subsense.DEF: used when you are saying that something would have happened if something or someone else had not prevented it
Subsense.EXAMPLE: But for these interruptions, the meeting would have finished earlier.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要不是几次被打断﹐会议早就开完了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The score could have been higher but for some excellent goalkeeping by Simon.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要不是西蒙几次出色的扑救﹐比分还会更高。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I might never have got to university but for you.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要是没有你的话﹐我可能永远也上不了大学。

Subsense.DEF: except for something or someone
Subsense.EXAMPLE: All was silent but for the sound of the wind in the trees.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 万籁俱寂﹐只有风吹树林的沙沙声。

Subsense.DEF: used when you are adding a statement that says almost the opposite of what you have just said
Subsense.EXAMPLE: John might be ready to help us, but then again, he might not.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰可能愿意帮我们﹐但也可能不愿意。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: You feel really sorry for him. But then again, it’s hard to like him.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你很同情他﹐可是很难喜欢他。

Subsense.DEF: used when you are adding a statement that makes what you have just said seem less surprising
Subsense.TRAN: 不过〔用于补充﹐使之前说的话不那么令人震惊〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Dinah missed the last rehearsal, but then she always was unreliable, wasn’t she?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 黛娜上次排练没来﹐不过﹐她这人一向靠不住﹐对吗？

Sense.DEF: used when you are replying to someone and expressing strong feelings such as anger, surprise etc
Sense.TRAN: 嘿﹐天哪〔用于回复某人﹐表示强烈的情感﹐如愤怒﹑惊讶等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: But that’s marvellous news!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 喔﹐这真是好消息啊！
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘They won’t even discuss the problem.’ ‘But how stupid!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “他们甚至都不会讨论这个问题。”“那真是愚蠢啊！”

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone has to do something or cannot stop themselves from doing it
Sense.TRAN: 某人不得不做某事﹔某人禁不住要做某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could not but admire her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不得不佩服她。

Sense.DEF: used when disagreeing with someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘It was a good idea.’ ‘But it didn’t work.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “这是个好主意。”“可是也没有用呀。”

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize a word or statement
Sense.TRAN: 〔用来加强词语或陈述的语气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’ll be a great party – everyone, but everyone, is coming.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这将是一个大聚会——每个人﹐对﹐每个人都会来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They’re rich, but I mean rich.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们很有钱﹐非常非常有钱。

Sense.DEF: used to change the subject of a conversation
Sense.TRAN: 无论如何﹐反正﹐好〔用于改变话题〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: But now to the main question.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好﹐现在谈谈主要问题。
Sense.EXAMPLE: But tell me, are you really planning to retire?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那你告诉我﹐你真的打算退休吗？

Sense.DEF: used after expressions such as ‘Excuse me’ and ‘I’m sorry’
Sense.EXAMPLE: Excuse me, but I’m afraid this is a no-smoking area.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对不起﹐这里是无烟区。

Exponent.DEF: used when linking two words or phrases that seem opposite or very different in meaning. Don’t use but at the beginning of a sentence in written English
Exponent.TRAN: 但是﹐然而〔用于连接两个意思相反或不同的单词或短语﹔书面语中不要用于句首〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The plant’s leaves are big, but its flowers are quite small.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种植物叶子很大﹐但花很小。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Her books are fascinating but often rather disturbing.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的书妙趣横生﹐但也往往令人不安。

Exponent.DEF: used when contrasting one clause with another in the same sentence
Exponent.TRAN: 虽然﹐尽管〔用于比较同一句子中的两个分句〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Although you are in the middle of the city, you feel as if you are in the countryside.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 虽然你是在市中心﹐却有身处乡间的感觉。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I enjoyed German although I wasn’t very good at it.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我喜欢德语﹐虽然我说得不好。

Exponent.DEF: used when saying something that seems different or surprising after your previous statement. It is usually used in the middle of a sentence, separated from the rest of the sentence by commas. It can also come at the beginning.
Exponent.TRAN: 不过﹐但是〔一般用于句中﹐以逗号隔开﹐也可以用于句首〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Jack and his family managed to escape before the soldiers arrived. Other families in the village, however, were less lucky.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰克和他家人赶在士兵到来之前逃走了﹐但其他人家就没那么幸运了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The town is a long way from the nearest big city. However, there is a good bus service.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 该镇离最近的大城市很远﹐不过坐公共汽车很方便。

Exponent.DEF: used when saying something that seems different or surprising after your previous statement. It is used at the beginning or end of a sentence
Exponent.TRAN: 然而﹐尽管如此〔用于句首或句末〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It was certainly a terrible accident. Nevertheless, air travel is still the safest form of transport.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那次事故的确很可怕﹐不过乘飞机旅行仍然是最安全的交通方式。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The weather turned bad early in the day, but the festival was a great success nonetheless.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那天一大早天气很糟﹐尽管如此﹐节庆活动仍然非常成功。

Exponent.DEF: used when making comparisons and saying that something is true of one person, thing, or situation, but it is different for another. They are used when contrasting one clause with another in the same sentence
Exponent.TRAN: 然而﹐可是 〔用于比较同一句子中的两个分句〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Some people visit their doctor once every few weeks, while others may not visit a doctor for several years.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些人隔几周就去看一趟医生﹐但也有些人可能好几年都不看一次。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Whereas in most of the world they drive on the right, in the UK and Japan they drive on the left.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 世界上大部分地方都是靠右行驶﹐但在英国和日本则是靠左行驶。

Exponent.DEF: used when making comparisons and saying that a person, thing, or situation is very different from the one you have just mentioned. It is used when referring back to the previous sentence
Exponent.TRAN: 相反﹐相比之下〔用于重提前句中的人﹑事物或情况并作比较〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The surface temperature on Venus is higher than the boiling point of water. Mars, by contrast, is very cold.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 金星的表面温度要高于水的沸点﹐相反火星表面则非常寒冷。

Sense.DEF: apart from
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could come any day but Thursday.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 除了星期四﹐我哪天都能来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s no one here but me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这里除了我没有别人。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could still see nothing but the spirals of desert dust.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 除了盘旋扬起的沙尘﹐我仍然什么也看不见。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was unable to swallow anything but liquids.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他除了流质什么都咽不下去。

Sense.LEXUNIT: the last but one/the next but two etc
Sense.DEF: the last or next thing or person except for one, two etc
Sense.EXAMPLE:
Pauline and Derek live in the next house but one
they live two houses away from us
.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保利娜和德里克住的地方和这里相隔一栋房子。

Sense.DEF: only
Sense.EXAMPLE: This is but one example of what can happen when things go badly wrong.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 倒霉的时候就会发生这样的事﹐这只不过是其中一例。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s going to be difficult. Anyway, we can but try.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这将会很难﹐但是无论如何﹐我们只能试试。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We have relationships of many different sorts – with our children, our parents, our boss and our friends, to name but a few.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们有各式各样的人际关系——和子女的关系﹑和父母的关系﹑和老板的关系以及和朋友的关系﹐这些只是其中的几类。

Sense.DEF: reasons that someone gives for not doing something or agreeing with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘I don’t want to hear any buts,’ Jo snapped.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “我不想听什么借口。”乔没好气地说。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He is the best player – no ifs, ands, or buts about that.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是最好的球员——这一点是毫无疑问的。

Sense.DEF: a gas stored in liquid form, used for cooking and heating
Sense.TRAN: 丁烷〔一种液化储存的气体用于煮食和取暖〕

Sense.DEF: a woman who is butch looks, behaves, or dresses like a man
Sense.TRAN: 〔女子外表﹑举止﹑穿着〕男性化的﹐男人腔的

Sense.DEF: a man who is butch seems big and strong, and typically male
Sense.TRAN: 〔男子〕男性特征明显的，男子气的

Sense.DEF: someone who owns or works in a shop that sells meat
a shop where you can buy meat
someone who has killed someone else cruelly and unnecessarily, especially someone who has killed a lot of people
to have a look at something
to kill animals and prepare them to be used as meat
to kill someone cruelly or unnecessarily, especially to kill a lot of people
to spoil something by working carelessly
Sense.EXAMPLE: That hairdresser really butchered my hair!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那名理发师把我的头发弄得一塌糊涂！

Sense.DEF: cruel and unnecessary killing
Sense.EXAMPLE: the butchery of battle
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 战场上的血腥屠杀

Sense.DEF: the preparation of meat for sale
the main male servant of a house

a group of
holiday camp s
in various seaside towns in the UK. They were started by Sir Billy Butlin (1899–1980) with the aim of providing inexpensive holidays for ordinary working people, and they were especially popular in the 1950s and 1960s.
Sense.TRAN: 巴特林度假胜地〔遍布英国各海滨城镇﹑以普通工薪族为对象的度假营地﹐由比利·巴特林爵士（1899–1980）首创﹐在20世纪50–60年代尤为流行〕

Sense.DEF: the part of your body that you sit on
Sense.EXAMPLE: a baby’s soft little butt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宝宝软软的小屁股

Crossrefto.REFLEX: be a pain in the butt

Sense.DEF: the end of a cigarette after most of it has been smoked
to be the person or thing that other people often make jokes about
Sense.EXAMPLE: Paul quickly became the butt of everyone’s jokes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保罗很快成了大家的笑柄。

Sense.DEF: the thick end of the handle of a gun
Sense.EXAMPLE: a rifle butt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 步枪的枪托

Sense.DEF: used to rudely tell someone to go somewhere or do something
Sense.TRAN: 别老坐着,快起来〔粗鲁地告诉某人去某处或做某事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Kevin, get your butt over here!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯文﹐你给我过来！

Sense.DEF: to work, play etc very hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: I worked my butt off in college.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在大学里非常用功。

Sense.DEF: a large round container for collecting or storing liquids
Sense.EXAMPLE: a rainwater butt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 接雨水的大桶

Sense.DEF: the act of hitting someone with your head
to hit or push against something or someone with your head
if an animal butts someone, it hits them with its horns
to interrupt a conversation rudely
Sense.EXAMPLE: Stop butting in!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别插嘴！

Sense.DEF: to become involved in a private situation that does not concern you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They don’t want outsiders butting in on their decision-making.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们不希望有外人插手他们的决策。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone rudely that you do not want them to be involved in a conversation or situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: This has nothing to do with you, so just butt out!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这件事与你无关﹐别瞎管！

Sense.DEF: a hill with steep sides and a flat top in the western US
Sense.TRAN: 〔美国西部有陡坡和平顶的〕孤山﹐孤峰﹐地垛

Sense.DEF: a solid yellow food made from milk or cream that you spread on bread or use in cooking

Sense.LEXUNIT: butter wouldn’t melt in sb’s mouth
Sense.DEF: used to say that someone seems to be very kind and sincere but is not really
to spread butter on something
Sense.EXAMPLE: buttered toast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 涂了黄油的烤面包片

Sense.DEF: to say nice things to someone so that they will do what you want
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t think you can butter me up that easily.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要以为你这么容易就能讨好我。

Sense.DEF: a large pale yellow bean
a soft mixture of butter and sugar used inside or on top of cakes
Sense.TRAN: 〔蛋糕里面或表面的〕奶油糖霜
